title: Free cumulants and freeness for unitarily invariant random tensors

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We address the question of the asymptotic description of random tensors that are localunitary invariant, that is, invariant by conjugation by tensor products of independent unitary matrices. We consider both the mixed case of a tensor with $D$ inputs and $D$ outputs, and the case where there is a factorization between the inputs and outputs, called pure, which includes the random tensor models extensively studied in the physics literature.

The finite size and asymptotic moments are defined using correlations of certain invariant polynomials encoded by $D$-tuples of permutations, up to relabeling equivalence. Finite size free cumulants associated to the expectations of these invariants are defined through invertible finite size moment-cumulants formulas.

Two important cases are considered asymptotically: pure random tensors that scale like a complex Gaussian, and mixed random tensors that scale like a Wishart tensor. In both cases, we derive a notion of tensorial free cumulants associated to first order invariants, through moment-cumulant formulas involving summations over non-crossing permutations. The pure and mixed cases involve the same combinatorics, but differ by the invariants that define the distribution at first order. In both cases, the tensorial free-cumulants of a sum of two independent tensors are shown to be additive. A preliminary discussion of higher orders is provided.

Tensor freeness is then defined as the vanishing of mixed first order tensorial free cumulants. The equivalent formulation at the level of asymptotic moments is derived in the pure and mixed cases, and we provide an algebraic construction of tensorial probability spaces, which generalize non-commutative probability spaces: random tensors converge in distribution to elements of these spaces, and tensor freeness of random variables corresponds to tensor freeness of the subspaces they generate.

# 1 Introduction 

In this paper, tensors $A$ are arrays of complex numbers of the form $A_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} ; j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}$, where all indices take value in $\{1, \ldots, N\}$ for some $N \geqslant 1$. Tensors for which the components factor as $T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}} \bar{T}_{j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}$ are called pure, in which case $A=T \otimes \bar{T}$, and tensors for which they do not are called mixed. We study in this paper random tensors whose probability measure is localunitary invariant, or LU-invariant, that is, invariant upon conjugation by a tensor product of $D$ unitary matrices: $A$ and $\left(U_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}\right) \cdot A \cdot\left(U_{1}^{\dagger} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}^{\dagger}\right)$ have the same distribution for any $U_{1}, \ldots, U_{D} \in U(N)$, where $U(N)$ is the set of $N \times N$ unitary matrices. For $D=1$, the case of unitarily invariant random matrices is recovered [1-3].

Examples of such probability distributions include the pure complex Gaussian [4-7] as well as perturbed Gaussian models, for which the probability density function of the Gaussian is altered by the addition of an invariant potential, see e.g. [8-18]. Regarding random tensors, see also [19-30]. Such models were initially studied because they provide generating functions for random triangulations, relevant in random geometry and quantum gravity $[7,11,16]$. Example of mixed distributions include Wishart tensors formed by partially tracing pure tensors [31,32], tensor product of $D$ random matrices $[33,34]$, or a GUE random matrix with subdivided indices.

Another important motivation for studying LU-invariant distributions comes from quantum entanglement. Consider a $D$-partite quantum system. Its state space is a Hilbert space with a tensor product structure $\mathcal{H}=\mathcal{H}_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathcal{H}_{D}$, and we assume that for all $c \in\{1, \ldots D\}, \mathcal{H}_{c} \cong \mathbb{C}^{N}$ for some $N \geqslant 1$. Seen as density matrices, pure quantum state are projectors $|\psi\rangle\langle\psi|$, and fixing an orthonormal basis $\left\{\left|i_{c}\right|\right\}_{1 \leqslant i_{c} \leqslant N}$ in each factor $\mathcal{H}_{c},|\psi\rangle \in \mathcal{H}$ decomposes as:

$$
|\psi\rangle=\sum_{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{D}=1}^{N} T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}}\left|i_{1}\right\rangle \otimes \cdots \otimes\left|i_{D}\right\rangle
$$

Component-wise, a pure density matrix $|\psi\rangle\langle\psi|$ corresponds to a pure tensor $T \otimes \bar{T}$, with a normalization condition. A mixed density matrix $\rho$ is a positive semi definite operator:

$$
\rho=\sum_{\text {all indices }}^{N} A_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} ; j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}\left|i_{1}\right\rangle \otimes \cdots \otimes\left|i_{D}\right\rangle \otimes\left\langle j_{1}\right| \otimes \cdots \otimes\left\langle j_{D}\right|
$$

with a normalization condition. Thus, mixed density matrices correspond to certain normalized mixed tensors. This explains the terminology.

Local-unitary invariance plays an important role in quantum information: such transformations - which correspond to local changes of orthonormal basis in each $\mathcal{H}_{c}$ - do not affect the entanglement between the $D$ subsystems. In fact, local-unitary invariance is sometimes introduced as a definition of equivalent entanglement [35-38], although depending on the context, a more operational definition of equivalent entanglement is often preferred. In any case, local-unitary invariance always plays an important role in multipartite entanglement: entanglement measures are LU-invariant, two-ways LOCC is equivalent to LU-equivalence, and so on. In order to study the entanglement properties of classes of quantum states that are equivalently entangled, one may introduce distributions on the tensor coefficients of the states and, since LU-transformations do not affect entanglement, it is necessary to require that these distributions are LU-invariant. Regarding random quantum states, see e.g. $[24,27,31,32,39-50]$.

In this paper, we address the question of the appropriate notion of moments for characterizing LU-invariant tensor distributions. Results in invariance theory justify our choice to define the

moments for such finite size distributions as the expectations of the invariant homogeneous polynomials [51-58], which we call trace-invariants. Our purpose is however to ultimately study the distributions asymptotically, when the size of the index set (or the dimension) $N$ goes to infinity, while the number of indices (or subsystems) $D$ stays constant. Generalizing the approach of [3], we discuss which quantities play the role of asymptotic moments, a choice which generally differs for mixed and pure random tensors. A notion of order is introduced, related to how the finite quantities must be rescaled in order to obtain the asymptotic moments. First order asymptotic moments are those which require the strongest rescaling. For classical random matrices, they are given by the expectations of powers of the matrix, while for the tensors considered, a subset of invariants called melonic is singled out [4-18].

For non-commutative random variables, freeness, or free independence, is a notion of independence which is weaker than the usual independence [1,3,59-62]. Usual independence can be formulated as the vanishing of classical cumulants. For random matrices, asymptotic freeness in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$ can be characterized by the vanishing of free cumulants (or first order free cumulants) [62], a sequence of numbers which represent the same information as the sequence of first order asymptotic moments. Such free cumulants are defined as sums of products of first order asymptotic moments. The summations involve non-crossing partitions, and by Möebius inversion one can write the first order asymptotic moments in terms of the free cumulants $[1,61,62]$.

Independent unitarily invariant random matrices are known to be asymptotically free, which implies that their free cumulants are additive. This gives access to the spectrum of the sum of two independent unitarily invariant random matrices whose spectra are known (asymptotic random Horn problem). Freeness plays a role in the study of random quantum states, see [31,32,48-50].

The pure complex Gaussian tensor ensemble $T, \bar{T}$ is obtained by requesting the coefficients of $T$ to be independent and identically distributed complex Gaussian variables. Appropriately normalized, the vector $|\psi\rangle \propto \sum_{i_{1} \ldots i_{D}=1}^{N} T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}}|i_{1}\rangle \otimes \cdots \otimes\left|i_{D}\right\rangle$ can be written as $|\psi\rangle=U|0\rangle$ where $|0\rangle$ is a fixed pure state and $U$ is a Haar distributed random unitary matrix: the pure complex Gaussian tensor corresponds in this interpretation to taking a uniform distribution on pure quantum states. We call Wishart tensor the mixed tensor obtained by summing one of the indices of $T$ with the corresponding index of $\bar{T}$ of the same position (color) $c$. This corresponds to partially tracing the associated density matrix over one of the subsystems $\mathcal{H}_{c}$, obtaining the density matrix induced on the remaining subsystems.

The pure random tensors distributions whose asymptotic behavior we study here are assumed to scale at large $N$ like the pure complex Gaussian, in the sense that their asymptotic moments are obtained with the same rescaling at large $N$. However, no other assumption is made on the asymptotic moments. The mixed tensors considered are those which scale like the Wishart tensor.

With these assumptions, using Weingarten calculus $[2,63,64]$, we derive a notion of finite size free cumulants by studying the expansion of the generating function of the classical cumulants (related to the tensor HCIZ integral, see [33,34]) on the trace-invariants which play the role of moments for LU-invariant random tensors. Taking the asymptotics of these relations, we obtain combinations of first order asymptotic moments which define first order free cumulants for any random tensor satisfying our scaling assumptions. By construction, these tensorial free cumulants are additive for independent random tensors. These formulas involve the same combinatorial restriction in the pure and the mixed case considered, but the asymptotic distributions differ by the classes of invariants that arise at first order. These relations can be inverted in the lattice product of non-crossing partitions: knowing the first order free cumulants is equivalent to knowing the asymptotic distribution at first order.

Having derived the tensorial free cumulants, asymptotic tensor freeness can then be defined (at first order) as the vanishing of (first order) free cumulants involving free tensors. We then study the formulation of asymptotic tensor freeness in terms of asymptotic moments, both in the pure and mixed cases which requires centering certain subgraphs of the first-order trace-invariants by subtracting their asymptotic expectations. Due to their tree structure, multiplications of tensors corresponding to these subgraphs are seen to be elements of generalizations of unital algebras introduced in the last section. Tensorial probability spaces are defined as a pair consisting in such a space, together with a trace. By construction, the pure and mixed random tensors we consider converge in distribution to elements of tensorial probability spaces, and tensor freeness can be formulated for elements of tensorial probability spaces, or for the spaces they generate.

This paper is just a first step in a vast program of study of freeness for random tensors. Further work is needed to pursue the generalization of free probability to random tensors, as well as its applications to quantum information theory, and so on. See the related works [29,30] addressing the question of free cumulants for real symmetric tensors (and freeness, for [30]).

## 2 Notations and prerequisites

Partitions and permutations. We will denote by $S_{n}$ be the group of permutations of $n$ elements, and $S_{n}^{D}$ the set of $D$-tuples of permutations $\left(\sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{D}\right), \sigma_{c} \in S_{n}$. The cyclic permutation $(1, \cdots n)$ will be denoted by $\gamma_{n}$, and id denotes the identity permutation. For $\sigma \in S_{n}, \# \sigma$ denotes the number of disjoint cycles of $\sigma$ and $|\sigma|$ the minimal number of transpositions required to obtain $\sigma$ and $\# \sigma+|\sigma|=n$.

We let $\mathcal{P}(n)$ be the set of all partitions $\pi$ of $n$ elements. The notation $\# \pi$ is used for the number of blocks of $\pi \in S_{n}, B \in \pi$ denotes the blocks, and $|B|$ the cardinal of $B$. The refinement partial order is denoted by $\leqslant: \pi^{\prime} \leqslant \pi$ if all the blocks of $\pi^{\prime}$ are subsets of blocks of $\pi$. Furthermore, $\vee$ denotes the joining of partitions: $\pi \vee \pi^{\prime}$ is the finest partition which is coarser than both $\pi$ and $\pi^{\prime} .1_{n}$ and $0_{n}$ respectively denote the one-block and the $n$ blocks partitions of $\{1, \ldots, n\}$. The partition induced by the cycles of the permutation $\nu$ is denoted by $\Pi(\nu)$, hence $\# \Pi(\nu)=\# \nu$. If $\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n)$ is such that $\pi \geqslant \Pi(\sigma)$ and if $B \in \pi, \sigma_{\mid_{B}}$ refers to the permutation induced by $\sigma$ on $B$. The number of partitions of $n=\sum_{i \geqslant 1} i d_{i}$ elements with $d_{i}$ parts of size $i$ is $\frac{n!}{\prod_{i \geqslant 1} d_{i}!(i!)^{d_{i}}}$.

In particular we will encounter bipartite partitions of bipartite sets $\{1, \ldots n, \overline{1}, \ldots \bar{n}\}$. They are partitions of such sets for which each block has the same number of elements in $\{1, \ldots n\}$ and in $\{\overline{1}, \ldots \bar{n}\}$. We denote $\mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n})$ the set of such partitions. Due to this last condition, a bipartite partition $\Pi$ can also be seen as a partition $\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n)$ having the same number of blocks as $\Pi$, together with a permutation $\eta \in S_{n}$ which to each $s$ associates an element $\overline{\eta(s)}$, up to relabelings of the elements in the preimages of the blocks of $\pi$. In detail, defining $\eta \sim_{\pi} \eta^{\prime}$ if $\eta=\eta^{\prime} \nu$ for

some permutation $\nu$ with $\Pi(\nu) \leqslant \pi$ and denoting by $S_{n} / \sim_{\pi}$ the set of equivalence classes of permutations under the relation $\sim_{\pi}$, we have $\Pi \Leftrightarrow(\pi,[\eta])$, where the blocks are mapped as:

$$
G \in \Pi \Leftrightarrow G=B \cup \bar{B}, \text { with } B \in \pi, \bar{B}=\{\overline{\eta(s)}, s \in B\}
$$

independently on the choice of representative $\eta$ of the class $[\eta] \in S_{n} / \sim_{\pi}$. As the number of partitions of $n=\sum_{i \geqslant 1} i d_{i}$ elements with $d_{i}$ parts of size $i$ is $\frac{n!}{\prod_{i \geqslant 1} d_{i}!(i!)^{d_{i}}}$ and the cardinal of $S_{n} / \sim_{\pi}$ is $\frac{n!}{\prod_{i \geqslant 1}(i!)^{d_{i}}}$, the number of bipartite partitions of a bipartite set with $n+n$ elements having $d_{i}$ parts with $i+i$ elements is $\frac{n!}{\prod_{i \geqslant 1} d_{i}!(i!)^{d_{i}}} \frac{n!}{\prod_{i \geqslant 1}(i!)^{d_{i}}}$. We denote by $1_{n, \bar{n}}$ the bipartite partition with a single block $\{1, \ldots n, \overline{1}, \ldots \bar{n}\}$.

We denote $D$-tuples of permutations by bold face greek symbols, $\left(\sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{D}\right)=\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ and we let $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\Pi\left(\sigma_{1}\right) \vee \ldots \vee \Pi\left(\sigma_{D}\right)$. We call the blocks of $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ the connected components of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ for reasons that will become clear below, and we denote $K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\# \Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and respectively $K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})=\#(\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma}) \vee \Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}))$ if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}$. We say that $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is connected if $K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1$.

Given a $D$-tuple of permutations $\left(\sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{D}\right)=\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$, we sometimes distinguish their domain and co-domain and consider the permutations as maps from $\{1, \ldots, n\}$ to $\{\overline{1}, \ldots, \bar{n}\}$, $s \mapsto \overline{\sigma_{c}(s)}$. In this case, for every color $c, \sigma_{c}$ yields a bipartite partition of the set $\{1, \ldots n, \overline{1} \ldots \bar{n}\}$ into $n$ pairs:

$$
\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\sigma_{c}\right)=\left\{\left\{s, \overline{\sigma_{c}(s)}\right\} \mid 1 \leqslant s \leqslant n\right\}
$$

corresponding with the point of view (2.1) to the partition $0_{n}$ of $\{1, \ldots n\}$ and the permutation $\sigma_{c}$. We denote by $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ the join of this partitions, which is also bipartite: $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\bigvee_{1 \leqslant c \leqslant D} \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\sigma_{c}\right)$. We refer to the parts of $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ as the pure connected components of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ and we denote by $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ their number. We say that $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected if $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1$. The parts of $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and those of $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$, where $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=\left(\sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{D}, \mathrm{id}\right)$ are in one-to-one correspondence: one passes from the parts of $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ to the ones of $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ by identifying $s=\bar{s}$.

The notation $\lambda \vdash n$ denotes that $\lambda$ is an integer partition of the integer $n$, that is, a multiplet of integers $\lambda_{1} \geqslant \ldots \geqslant \lambda_{p}>0$ such that $\sum_{i=1}^{p} \lambda_{i}=n$. The $\lambda_{i}$ are the parts of $\lambda$, and we denote $\lambda=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}\right), p=\# \lambda$ the number of parts of $\lambda$, and $d_{i}(\lambda)$ is the number of parts of $\lambda$ equal to $i$, so that $n=\sum_{i=1}^{n} i d_{i}(\lambda)$ and $p=\# \lambda=\sum_{i=1}^{n} d_{i}(\lambda)$. If $\sigma \in S_{n}, \Lambda(\sigma)$ is the partition of $n$ given by the number of elements of the disjoint cycles of $\sigma$.

Distance between permutations. The map $d: S_{n}^{g} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}, d(\sigma, \tau)=\left|\sigma \tau^{-1}\right|$ defines a distance between permutations (see [61] and e.g. [1], Lecture 23). For $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}$ and $\eta \in S_{n}$, we let $d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})=\sum_{c} d\left(\sigma_{c}, \tau_{c}\right)$ and $d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=\sum_{c} d\left(\sigma_{c}, \eta\right)$. Considering some permutations $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}$, since $d$ is a distance:

$$
\left|\alpha_{1} \alpha_{2}^{-1}\right|+\cdots+\left|\alpha_{n-1} \alpha_{n}^{-1}\right| \geqslant\left|\alpha_{1} \alpha_{n}^{-1}\right|
$$

with equality if and only if these permutations lie on a geodesic $\alpha_{1} \rightarrow \alpha_{2} \ldots \rightarrow \alpha_{n}$. A permutation $\tau \in S_{n}$ satisfying $|\tau|+\left|\tau \gamma_{n}^{-1}\right|=n-1$ is said to be geodesic or non-crossing on $\gamma_{n}$. More generally, we will use the notation $\tau \leq \sigma$ for two permutations saturating the triangular inequality $|\tau|+\left|\tau \sigma^{-1}\right|=|\sigma|$, that is such that $\tau$ lies on a geodesic from the identity to $\sigma$.

Fixing an ordering of $n$ elements, a non-crossing partition $\pi$ has no four elements $p_{1}<q_{1}<$ $p_{2}<q_{2} \in C$ such that $p_{1}, p_{2} \in B$ and $q_{1}, q_{2} \in B^{\prime}$ for $B \neq B^{\prime}$ two blocks of $\pi$. As a consequence of (2.7) below, $\tau \leq \gamma_{n}$ if and only if the partition $\Pi(\tau)$ is non-crossing on $1<\ldots<n$, and the cyclic ordering of the elements of each cycle of $\tau$ agrees with $\gamma_{n}$ in the sense that they are

cyclically increasing. Therefore, the sets $N C(n)$ of non-crossing partitions on $n$ ordered elements and $S_{\mathrm{NC}}\left(\gamma_{n}\right)=\left\{\tau \leq \gamma_{n}\right\}$ are isomorphic posets (see Prop. 23.23 in [1]). Changing $\gamma_{n}$ to another cycle with $n$ elements amounts to changing the ordering of the $n$ elements.

From (2.7) it also follows that the condition $\tau \leq \sigma$ is equivalent to $\Pi(\tau) \leqslant \Pi(\sigma)$, and for each cycle $B \in \Pi(\sigma),\left.\tau\right|_{B}$ is non-crossing on the cycle $\sigma_{\mid B}$. If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}$, the notation $\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}$ indicates that for all $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D, \tau_{c} \leq \sigma_{c}$ and if $\eta \in S_{n}$, the notation $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta$ means that for all $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D, \tau_{c} \eta \leq \sigma_{c} \eta$.

The number of $\tau \in S_{n}$ such that $\tau \leq \gamma_{n}$ is the Catalan number $C_{n}$ :

$$
C_{n}=\frac{1}{n+1}\binom{2 n}{n}
$$

This is also the number of non-crossing pairings (partitions into blocks of two elements) of $2 n$ elements, and there exists an explicit bijection between non-crossing pairings of $2 n$ elements and non-crossing partitions of $n$ elements. ${ }^{1}$ The Möbius function on the lattice of non-crossing partitions is:

$$
\mathrm{M}(\pi)=\prod_{p \geqslant 1}\left[(-1)^{p-1} C_{p-1}\right]^{d_{p}(\pi)}
$$

where $d_{p}(\pi)$ is the number of blocks of $\pi$ with $p$ elements and we let $\mathrm{M}(\nu)=\mathrm{M}(\Pi(\nu))$.
Genus. If $\sigma, \tau \in S_{n}$, the Euler characteristics of $(\sigma, \tau)$ is:

$$
\# \sigma+\# \tau+\#\left(\sigma \tau^{-1}\right)-n=2 K(\sigma, \tau)-2 g(\sigma, \tau)
$$

where $g(\sigma, \tau) \geqslant 0$ is the genus of $(\sigma, \tau)$. Such a pair of permutations is called a "bipartite map". Up to simultaneous conjugation of $\sigma$ and $\tau$, bipartite maps bijectively encode isomorphism classes of embeddings of bipartite graphs on orientable surfaces of genus $g$, where white and black vertices are respectively associated to the cycles of $\sigma$ and $\tau$ and the edges are labeled from 1 to $n$. One may express (2.6) as:

$$
|\tau|+\left|\tau \sigma^{-1}\right|-|\sigma|=2 g(\sigma, \tau)+2(\# \sigma-K(\sigma, \tau))
$$

and since $\# \sigma \geqslant K(\sigma, \tau)$ with equality if and only if $\Pi(\tau) \leqslant \Pi(\sigma)$, we see that a non-crossing permutation $\tau \leq \gamma_{n}$ corresponds to a planar bipartite map with one white vertex while $\tau \leq \sigma$ corresponds to a planar bipartite map $(\sigma, \tau)$ with only one white vertex per connected component.

For each cycle of $\sigma$, the restriction of $\tau$ induces a non-crossing permutation

Classical moment-cumulant formula. The classical cumulants of some random variables $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{p}$ are defined in terms of the expectations as:

$$
k_{n}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\sum_{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n)} \lambda_{\pi} \prod_{G \in \pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{i \in G} x_{i}\right]
$$

with $\lambda_{\pi}=(-1)^{\# \pi-1}(\# \pi-1)$ ! the Möebius function on the lattice of partitions. If all $x_{i}$ are equal to $x$, we use the notation $k_{n}(x)$. By Möbius inversion in the lattice of partitions, we have:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[x_{1} \cdots x_{n}\right]=\sum_{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n)} \prod_{G \in \pi} k_{|G|}\left(\left\{x_{i}\right\}, i \in G\right)
$$

A particular case we need to consider is the case of a complex variable $f_{s}, \bar{f}_{s}$, with the additional assumption that only the expectations and cumulants with the same number of $f \mathrm{~s}$ and $\bar{f} \mathrm{~s}$ are non zero. In that case, the sums above are restricted to bipartite partitions of bipartite sets: ${ }^{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[f_{1} \ldots f_{n} \bar{f}_{\bar{1}} \ldots \bar{f}_{\bar{n}}\right] & =\sum_{\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n})} \prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} k_{|B|}\left(\left\{f_{i}\right\}_{i \in B},\left\{\bar{f}_{\bar{j}}\right\}_{\bar{j} \in \bar{B}}\right) \\
k_{n}\left[f_{1}, \ldots f_{n}, \bar{f}_{\bar{1}}, \ldots \bar{f}_{\bar{n}}\right] & =\sum_{\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n})} \lambda_{\Pi} \prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{i \in B} f_{i} \prod_{\bar{j} \in \bar{B}} \bar{f}_{\bar{j}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The exact same holds for bipartite distributions of a couple of random variables. Below we will often use the notation $T, \bar{T}$ to designate such bipartite couples of variables: while sometimes we will specify $\bar{T}$ to be the complex conjugate of $T$, unless otherwise specified, the formulas apply for both cases.

Weingarten functions. The Weingarten functions appear when integrating over unitary matrices $[2,64]$. One has for $n \leqslant N$ :

$$
\int d U U_{i_{1} a_{1}} \cdots U_{i_{n} a_{n}} \overline{U_{j_{1} b_{1}} \cdots U_{j_{n} b_{n}}}=\sum_{\sigma, \tau \in S_{n}}\left(\prod_{s=1}^{n} \delta_{i_{s}, j_{\sigma(s)}}\right)\left(\prod_{s=1}^{n} \delta_{a_{s}, b_{\sigma(s)}}\right) W^{(N)}\left(\sigma \tau^{-1}\right)
$$

where $d U$ is the normalized Haar measure on the group $U(N)$ of $N \times N$ unitary matrices, and the $W^{(N)}$ are the Weingarten functions [64]:

$$
W^{(N)}(\nu)=N^{-n} \sum_{k \geqslant 0} \sum_{\substack{\rho_{1}, \ldots, \rho_{k} \in S_{n} \backslash \mathrm{id} \\ \rho_{1} \cdots \rho_{k}=\nu}}(-1)^{k} N^{-\sum_{i=1}^{k}\left|\rho_{i}\right|}
$$

which at large $N$ behave as:

$$
W^{(N)}(\nu)=\mathrm{M}(\nu) N^{-n-|\nu|}\left(1+O\left(N^{-2}\right)\right)
$$

We note that the Weingarten functions are class functions $W(\nu)=W\left(\eta \nu \eta^{-1}\right)$ for any $\eta \in S_{n}$.

    $$

# 3 Unitarily invariant random matrices 

In this section we follow [3]. A unitarily invariant random matrix $M=\left\{M_{i, j}\right\}_{1 \leqslant i, j \leqslant N}$ is such that for any $U \in U(N), M$ and $U M U^{\dagger}$ have the same distribution.

### 3.1 Moments of unitarily invariant random matrices

Trace-invariants of matrices. The trace-invariants of a matrix $M=\left\{M_{i, j}\right\}_{1 \leqslant i, j \leqslant N}$ are the products of traces of powers of that matrix: $\operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{1}}\right) \cdots \operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{p}}\right), \lambda_{1} \geqslant \ldots \geqslant \lambda_{p}>0$. We denote this product in a more compact manner as $\operatorname{Tr}_{\lambda}(M)$, where $\lambda_{1} \geqslant \ldots \geqslant \lambda_{p}>0$ are the parts of the integer partition $\lambda \vdash n$. If $\sigma \in S_{n}$ and the cycle-type of $\sigma$ is $\Lambda(\sigma)=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}\right)$, then we let $\operatorname{Tr}_{\sigma}(M)=\operatorname{Tr}_{\Lambda(\sigma)}(M)$.

The trace-invariants are unitarily invariant homogeneous polynomials in the matrix entries $M_{i, j}$ and $\operatorname{Tr}_{\lambda}(M), \lambda \vdash n \leqslant N$ form a basis in the ring of unitarily invariant polynomials of $M$, and by extension of sufficiently regular unitarily invariant functions ${ }^{3}$.

Finite size moments. Due to the unitary invariance, the appropriate moments for a $N \times N$ unitarily invariant random matrix $M$ are the expectations of the trace-invariants:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\lambda}(M)\right], \quad \lambda \vdash n \leqslant N
$$

This follows from the remark that if $f$ is a polynomial (or by extension, a sufficiently regular function, see Sec. 4.1.2) in the entries of $M$, then there exists a unique set of coefficients $\left\{c_{\lambda}\right\}$ such that: ${ }^{4}$

$$
\mathbb{E}[f(M)]=\sum_{n=1}^{N} \sum_{\lambda \vdash n} c_{\lambda} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\lambda}(M)\right]
$$

### 3.2 Asymptotic moments

Asymptotic characterization of the distribution. In principle one needs the expectations $\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\lambda}(M)\right]$ to describe unitarily invariant formal series. On the other hand, the dominant contributions in the $N \rightarrow \infty$ limit to these expectations usually do not contain more information on the asymptotic distribution than the subset of expectations $\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{n}\right)\right], n \geqslant 1$. This is due to the fact that the random matrix ensembles classically studied, like the $\mathrm{GUE}^{5}$, Ginibre or Wishart ensembles, share the property that the expectations of trace-invariants factorize asymptotically:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{i=1}^{p} \operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{i}}\right)\right] \sim_{N \rightarrow \infty} \prod_{i=1}^{p} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{i}}\right)\right]
$$

In fact, for $\lambda$ having more than one part, one has to dig quite far in the $1 / N$ expansion of $\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\lambda}(M)\right]$ to recover information on the asymptotic correlations between the $\operatorname{Tr}\left(M_{i}^{\lambda}\right)$, which is captured by the dominant contribution to the classical cumulants $k_{p}\left(\operatorname{Tr} M^{\lambda_{1}}, \ldots, \operatorname{Tr} M^{\lambda_{p}}\right)$.

More precisely, for classical random matrix ensembles such as the ones mentionned above, the dominant contribution to the classical cumulants takes the form (see e.g. [3,59]):

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{2-p}} k_{p}\left(\operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{1}}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{p}}\right)\right)=\varphi_{\lambda}(m)
$$

If the polynomial is of degree at most $N$, computing the integral using the Weingarten formula (2.11) yields the desired decomposition. If the polynomial is of degree larger than $N$, one may apply the Cayley-Hamilton theorem.

that is, the classical cumulants scale asymptotically as $N^{2-p}$, and we denoted the asymptotic coefficient as:

$$
\varphi_{\lambda}(m)=\varphi_{\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}}(m)
$$

where $\lambda=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}\right) \vdash n$. If $\lambda$ has only one part we use the notation $\varphi_{n}(m)=\varphi_{\lambda}(m)$.
Recalling that $\Lambda(\sigma)$ denotes the cycle-type of the permutation $\sigma$, we define for $\pi \geqslant \Pi(\sigma)$ the multiplicative extension:

$$
\varphi_{\pi, \sigma}(m)=\prod_{B \in \pi} \varphi_{\Lambda\left(\sigma_{|B}\right)}(m)
$$

and we stress that with this notation, if the cycle type of $\sigma$ is $\Lambda(\sigma)=\lambda=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots \lambda_{p}\right)$, then:

$$
\varphi_{\Pi(\sigma), \sigma}(m)=\prod_{B \in \Pi(\sigma)} \varphi_{\Lambda\left(\sigma_{|B}\right)}(m)=\prod_{i=1}^{p} \varphi_{\lambda_{i}}(m) \neq \varphi_{\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}}(m)=\varphi_{\Lambda(\sigma)}(m)=\varphi_{1_{\alpha}, \sigma}(m)
$$

Below we will also use the notation $\varphi_{\sigma}=\varphi_{1_{\alpha}, \sigma}$.
In the case of several matrices $M_{1}, \ldots, M_{n}$, we generalize the notation in the obvious manner. For instance, for $\tau \in S_{n}, \pi \in \mathcal{P}(n)$ with $\pi \geqslant \Pi(\tau)$ we have the following scaling:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{2 \# \pi-\# \tau}} \prod_{G \in \pi} k_{\#\left(\tau \mid_{G}\right)}\left(\left\{\operatorname{Tr}\left(\prod_{s \in \tau_{i}} M_{s}\right)\right\}_{\tau_{i} \text { cycle of } \tau \mid_{G}}\right)=\varphi_{\pi, \tau}\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)
$$

where the matrix product inside the trace follows the cyclic ordering of the elements in the $\tau_{i}$.
Order of dominance. We define the order of dominance of a classical cumulant as 2 minus its dominant scaling in $N$. If (3.4) is satisfied, the order of dominance of $k_{p}\left(\operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{1}}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{p}}\right)\right)$ is $p$. By definition the invariants with the largest scaling are of order 1 , while the order of the other invariants indicates how much more they are suppressed in scaling than the dominant invariants. We have that:

- the asymptotic distribution is described at first order by $\left\{\varphi_{n}(m)\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$, the limits of the rescaled expectations $\frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{n}\right)\right]$. This first order information fixes for instance the asymptotic spectrum of $M$, if $M$ is a normal matrix;
- the fluctuations of order $p$ (the correlations between $p$ eigenvalues) are encoded in the order $p$ invariants $\varphi_{\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}}(m)$.

The factorization of the expectations is seen as follows. The expectations of products of appropriately normalized traces admit $N \rightarrow \infty$ limits:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{n}\right)\right]=\varphi_{n}(m) \quad \text { and } \quad \lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{p}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\lambda}(M)\right]=\prod_{i} \varphi_{\lambda_{i}}(m)
$$

and going further in the $1 / N$ expansion, we find that the classical cumulant contributes to the corresponding normalized expectation at a lower $1 / N$ order:

$$
\frac{1}{N^{p}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\lambda}(M)\right]=\prod_{i} \varphi_{\lambda_{i}}(m)+\cdots+\frac{1}{N^{p}} k_{p}\left(\operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{1}}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{p}}\right)\right)
$$

where all the terms apart from the first one are $O(1 / N)$, and the rightmost term is the most suppressed (of order $\frac{1}{N^{2(p-1)}}$ ).

The Wishart ensemble. A particular example we will be interested in below is that of a Wishart random matrix. Let $X$ be a $N \times N^{\prime}$ random matrix with independent and identically distributed complex Gaussian entries (a Ginibre matrix) satisfying ${ }^{6} \mathbb{E}\left[X_{i_{1}, i_{2}} X_{j_{1}, j_{2}}\right]=\delta_{i_{1}, j_{1}} \delta_{i_{2}, j_{2}} / N$, and assume that $N^{\prime} \sim t N$ asymptotically for some $t \in(0, \infty)$. The moments of the Wishart random matrix $W=X X^{\dagger}$ are (see e.g. [32]):

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr} W^{n}\right]=\sum_{\tau \in S_{n}} N^{\#\left(\gamma_{n} \tau^{-1}\right)-n} N^{\prime \# \tau}=\sum_{\tau \in S_{n}} N^{\#\left(\gamma_{n} \tau^{-1}\right)+\# \tau-n} t^{\# \tau}
$$

where we recall that $\gamma_{n}$ is the cycle $(12 \ldots n)$. From Sec. 2, we have that $\#\left(\gamma_{n} \tau^{-1}\right)+\# \tau \leqslant 1+n$, with equality if and only if $\tau \leq \gamma_{n}$, hence $\frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr} W^{n}\right] \sim \varphi_{n}\left(w_{t}\right)$, where:

$$
\varphi_{n}\left(w_{t}\right)=\sum_{\tau \leq \gamma_{n}} t^{\# \tau}
$$

is the $n$th moment of the Marčenko-Pastur law of parameter $t$. For the square Wishart, $t=1$, one gets the Catalan number:

$$
\varphi_{n}(w)=C_{n}
$$

where $w=w_{1}$. The asymptotic behavior of the cumulants $k_{p}\left(\operatorname{Tr} W^{\lambda_{1}}, \ldots, \operatorname{Tr} W^{\lambda_{p}}\right)$ is the sum (3.11) with a connectivity condition (see for instance [59]):

$$
k_{p}\left(\operatorname{Tr}\left(W^{\lambda_{1}}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}\left(W^{\lambda_{p}}\right)\right)=\sum_{\substack{\tau \in S_{n} \\\Pi(\tau) \vee \Pi\left(\gamma_{\lambda}\right)=1_{n}}} N^{\#\left(\gamma_{\lambda} \tau^{-1}\right)+\# \tau-n} t^{\# \tau}
$$

where $\lambda=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}\right)$ and $\gamma_{\lambda}$ is a permutation of cycle-type $\lambda$. Applying (2.6) to the map $\left(\tau, \gamma_{\lambda}\right)$, which is connected, yields $\#\left(\gamma_{\lambda} \tau^{-1}\right)+\# \tau-n=2-p-2 g\left(\tau, \gamma_{\lambda}\right) \leqslant 2-p$, hence we reproduce the scaling advertised in (3.4) with:

$$
\varphi_{\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}}\left(w_{t}\right)=\sum_{\substack{\tau \in S_{n} \\\Pi(\tau) \vee \Pi\left(\gamma_{\lambda}\right)=1_{n} \\ g\left(\tau, \gamma_{\lambda}\right)=0}} t^{\# \tau}
$$

# 3.3 Free cumulants and first order freeness 

Free cumulants. The free cumulants are the central tools of free probability. For a $N \times N$ unitarily invariant random matrix $M$, they are defined through the relations:

$$
\kappa_{n}(m)=\sum_{\tau \leq \gamma_{n}} \varphi_{\Pi(\tau), \tau}(m) \mathrm{M}\left(\gamma_{n} \tau^{-1}\right)
$$

where we recall that if $\tau$ has cycle-type $\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}\right)$ then $\varphi_{\Pi(\tau), \tau}(m)=\prod_{i} \varphi_{\lambda_{i}}(m)$, and M is the Möbius function on the lattice of non-crossing partitions (2.5). By Möbius inversion [1], we have:

$$
\varphi_{n}(m)=\sum_{\tau \leq \gamma_{n}} \kappa_{\Pi(\tau), \tau}(m)
$$

where, for $\tau$ having cycle-type $\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}\right)$, we let $\kappa_{\Pi(\tau), \tau}(m)=\prod_{i=1}^{p} \kappa_{\lambda_{i}}(m)$. These are the so-called free moment-cumulant formulas. They generalize in the obvious manner to $n$ distinct matrices $M_{1}, \ldots, M_{n}$, yielding $\kappa_{n}\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$.

The information encoded in the free cumulants $\left\{\kappa_{n}(m)\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$ is equivalent to that encoded in the first order asymptotic moments $\left\{\varphi_{n}(m)\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$. For a Wishart random matrix for instance, comparing (3.12) and (3.13) to (3.17) we have:

$$
\kappa_{n}\left(w_{t}\right)=t, \quad \text { and } \quad \kappa_{n}(w)=1
$$

while for the GUE we have $\kappa_{n}(m)=\delta_{n, 2}$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{6}$ Equivalently with probability measure $e^{-N \operatorname{Tr}\left(X X^{\dagger}\right)} \prod_{a b} d X_{a b} d X_{a b}$.

Freeness. Just like two random variables $x, y$ are independent if and only if their mixed (classical) cumulants vanish, some non-commutative random variables $a, b, \ldots$ are said to be free, if the free cumulants involving two different variables from this set at least vanish, that is, $\kappa_{n}\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)=0$ if $a_{i} \neq a_{j}$ for some $i, j$. From the free moment-cumulant formulas, one can equivalently formulate freeness by the vanishing of centered mixed moments, see Sec. 7.1 for more details. The original definition in the moments formulation is due to Voiculescu [60], and the equivalent definition in terms of free cumulants to Speicher [62]. Two random matrices $A, B$ converging to free non-commutative variables are said to be asymptotically free. As an easy consequence, since the free cumulants are multilinear, just like classical cumulants are additive for independent random variables, two free random variables $a, b$ satisfy:

$$
\kappa_{n}(a+b)=\kappa_{n}(a)+\kappa_{n}(b)
$$

Voiculescu proved [60] that two independent random matrices $A, B$ which almost surely have asymptotic spectra, such that the distribution of $B$ is invariant under conjugation by unitary matrices are asymptotically free. As a consequence, their free cumulants satisfy (3.19).

Higher order free cumulants. Higher order free cumulants play the same role as $\left\{\kappa_{n}(m)\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$ for $\left\{\varphi_{n}(m)\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$, but for higher order asymptotic moments $\left\{\varphi_{\lambda}(m)\right\}_{\lambda \vdash n}$. Higher order free moment-cumulant formulas [3] define the higher order free cumulants $\kappa_{\lambda}(m)=\kappa_{\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}}(m)$ for $\lambda=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}\right) \vdash n$, and fixing some $q \geqslant 2$, the sets of cumulants $\left\{\kappa_{\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}}(m)\right\}_{\lambda_{1} \geqslant \ldots \geqslant \lambda_{p}>0}$ for $p \leqslant q$ and corresponding moments $\left\{\varphi_{\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{p}}(m)\right\}_{\lambda_{1} \geqslant \ldots \geqslant \lambda_{p}>0}$ for $p \leqslant q$ encode equivalent data on the asymptotic distribution of $M$. The higher order free moment-cumulant formulas are more complicated than the first order ones, see $[3,65]$.

# 3.4 Moment-cumulant relations at finite $N$ 

We have so far discussed the asymptotic moments and free cumulants. The free moment-cumulant formulas of first and higher orders are obtained as the $N \rightarrow \infty$ limits of finite-size momentcumulant relations.

Let $\tau \in S_{n}, \pi \geqslant \Pi(\tau)$, and for $G \in \pi$, denote by $p_{G}$ the number of cycles of $\tau_{\mid G}$ and $\lambda_{1}^{G} \geqslant \ldots \geqslant \lambda_{p_{G}}^{G}$ the ordered list of the number of elements of these cycles. Following [3], we define the finite $N$ multiplicative extension of the classical cumulants:

$$
\Phi_{\pi, \tau}[M]=\prod_{G \in \pi} k_{p_{G}}\left(\operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{1}^{G}}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}\left(M^{\lambda_{p_{G}}^{G}}\right)\right)
$$

With this notation, the classical moment-cumulant formulas read:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\tau}(M)\right]=\sum_{\substack{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi \geqslant \Pi(\tau)}} \Phi_{\pi, \tau}[M], \quad \Phi_{1_{n}, \tau}[M]=\sum_{\substack{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi \geqslant \Pi(\tau)}} \lambda_{\pi} \prod_{B \in \pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\tau \mid B}(M)\right]
$$

with $\lambda_{\pi}$ the Möebius function on the lattice of partitions. Naturally, $\Phi_{1_{n}, \tau}[M]=\Phi_{\tau}[M]$ is just the classical cumulant corresponding to the integer partition $\Lambda(\tau)$. For $n$ distinct matrices $M_{1}, \ldots, M_{n}$, denoting $\widehat{M}=\left(M_{1}, \ldots, M_{n}\right)$, we extend the notation to:

$$
\Phi_{\pi, \tau}[\widehat{M}]=\prod_{G \in \pi} k_{p_{G}}\left(\left\{\operatorname{Tr}\left(\prod_{j \in \tau_{i}} M_{j}\right)\right\}_{\tau_{i} \text { cycle of } \tau_{\mid G}}\right)
$$

The finite $N$ precursors of the free cumulants are then defined for $\sigma \in S_{n}$ and $\pi \geqslant \Pi(\sigma)$ (see [3], (24) and (14)) via:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\pi, \sigma}[\widehat{M}]=\sum_{\substack{\pi \in S_{n} \\ \pi \geqslant \pi^{\prime} \geqslant \Pi(\tau)}} \sum_{\substack{\pi^{\prime} \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi \geqslant \pi^{\prime} \geqslant \Pi(\sigma)}} \Phi_{\pi^{\prime}, \tau}[\widehat{M}] \sum_{\substack{\pi^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi \geqslant \pi^{\prime \prime} \geqslant \Pi(\sigma) \vee \pi^{\prime}}} \lambda_{\pi^{\prime \prime}, \pi} \prod_{G \in \pi^{\prime \prime}} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{\left.\right|_{G}} \tau_{\left.\right|_{G}}^{-1}\right)
$$

where the $W^{(N)}$ are the Weingarten functions and $\lambda_{\pi^{\sigma}, \pi}$ for $\pi^{\prime \prime} \leqslant \pi$ is again the Möebius function $\lambda_{\pi^{\sigma}, \pi}=\left.\prod_{B \in \pi}\left(\left|\pi^{\sigma}\right|_{B}\right|-1\right)!(-1)^{\left|\pi^{\sigma}\right|_{B} \mid-1}$. The precursors of the free cumulants can also be written directly in terms of expectations of traces. For instance, for $\mathcal{K}_{1_{n}, \sigma}[M]=\mathcal{K}_{\sigma}[M]$, we have:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\sigma}[M]=\sum_{\tau \in S_{n}} \sum_{\substack{\pi^{\prime} \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi^{\prime} \geqslant \Pi(\tau)}} \Phi_{\pi^{\prime}, \tau}[M] \sum_{\substack{\pi^{\sigma} \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi^{\sigma} \geqslant \Pi(\sigma) \vee \pi^{\prime}}} \lambda_{\pi^{\sigma}} \prod_{G \in \pi^{\sigma}} W^{(N)}\left(\left.\sigma\right|_{G} \tau_{\mid G}^{-1}\right)
$$

and exchanging the sums we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}_{\sigma}[M] & =\sum_{\tau \in S_{n}} \sum_{\substack{\pi^{\sigma} \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\
\pi^{\sigma} \geqslant \Pi(\sigma) \vee \Pi(\tau)}} \lambda_{\pi^{\sigma}} \prod_{G \in \pi^{\sigma}} W^{(N)}\left(\left.\sigma_{\mid G} \tau_{\mid G}^{-1}\right) \sum_{\substack{\pi^{\prime} \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\
\pi^{\sigma} \geqslant \pi^{\prime} \geqslant \Pi(\tau)}} \Phi_{\pi^{\prime}, \tau}[M]\right. \\
& =\sum_{\tau \in S_{n}} \sum_{\substack{\pi^{\sigma} \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\
\pi^{\sigma} \geqslant \Pi(\sigma) \vee \Pi(\tau)}} \lambda_{\pi^{\sigma}} \prod_{G \in \pi^{\sigma}} W^{(N)}\left(\left.\sigma_{\mid G} \tau_{\mid G}^{-1}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\tau_{\mid G}}(M)\right]\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

The relations between classical and free cumulants in (3.23) can be inverted as [3]:

$$
\Phi_{\pi, \sigma}[\tilde{M}]=\sum_{\substack{\tau \in S_{n}, \pi^{\prime} \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi \geqslant \pi^{\prime} \geqslant \Pi(\tau)} \mathcal{K}_{\pi^{\prime}, \tau}[\tilde{M}] \cdot N^{\#(\sigma \tau^{-1})}
$$

The finite $N$ classical cumulant $\Phi_{\pi, \sigma}[\tilde{M}]$ is of order $N^{2 \# \pi-\# \sigma}$ and the precursor $\mathcal{K}_{\pi, \sigma}[\tilde{M}]$ of the free cumulant $\kappa_{\pi, \sigma}(\vec{m})$ is of order $N^{2 \# \pi-\# \sigma-n}$. Their rescaled limits converge to the asymptotic versions we defined previously:

$$
\varphi_{\pi, \sigma}(\vec{m})=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{\# \sigma-2 \# \pi} \Phi_{\pi, \sigma}[\tilde{M}], \quad \kappa_{\pi, \sigma}(\vec{m})=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{\# \sigma+n-2 \# \pi} \mathcal{K}_{\pi, \sigma}[\tilde{M}]
$$

The free moment-cumulant formulas of arbitrary order are recovered [3,65] by taking the $N \rightarrow \infty$ limit of the finite $N$ relations (3.23) and (3.26).

# 4 Local-unitary invariant random tensors 

We will consider throughout this paper two classes of random tensors ensembles:

- Mixed ensembles. The first case consists in a complex random tensor of the form $A=$ $\left\{A_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} ; j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}\right\}$ with $1 \leqslant i^{c}, j^{c} \leqslant N$. The distribution is local-unitary invariant if for any $U_{1}, \ldots, U_{D} \in U(N)$, the random tensors $A$ and $\left(U_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}\right) A\left(U_{1}^{\dagger} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}^{\dagger}\right)$ have the same distribution. Mixed random tensors are adapted for describing random operators, or random mixed quantum states, on a $D$-partite Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathcal{H}_{D}$. Note that $A$ is not a priori assumed to be Hermitian.
- Pure ensembles. The second case is that of a pair of tensors $T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}}$ and $\bar{T}_{j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}$. Despite the notation, just as $A$ is not a priori assumed to be Hermitian, we generally assume that $T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}}$ and $\bar{T}_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}}$ are independent, and explicitly say so otherwise ${ }^{7}$. The distribution is local-unitary invariant if $T, \bar{T}$ and $\left(U_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}\right) T, \bar{T}\left(U_{1}^{\dagger} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}^{\dagger}\right)$ have the same distributions. Pure random tensors are adapted for describing random pure quantum states on a $D$-partite Hilbert space. The case where $T$ is a complex Gaussian (Ginibre) tensor and the components of $\bar{T}$ are the conjugate of those of $T$ is the ensemble that has been studied the most in the literature.

Both in the mixed and in the pure case, we call the indices $i$ on which the unitary matrices $U$ act output indices, and the indices $j$ on which the Hermitian conjugates $U^{\dagger}$ act the input indices. We sometimes use the shorthand notation $\vec{i}$ to denote the $D$-tuple of indices $i^{1} \ldots i^{D}$.

It is sometimes useful to regard the pure case as a factorized version of the mixed one $A=T \otimes \bar{T}$, or component wise $A_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} ; j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}=T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}} \bar{T}_{j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}$. Below we will often first discuss the mixed case and then adapt the various notions to the pure one.

### 4.1 Trace-invariants and moments of invariant distributions of finite size

We discuss a family of invariant polynomials which generalize the traces of powers of matrices to tensors.

### 4.1.1 Trace-invariants

Similarly to invariant matrix functions, a function $f$ of the tensor $A$ is said to be local-unitary invariant (LU-invariant), if for any $U_{1}, \ldots, U_{D} \in U(N)$,

$$
f(A)=f\left(\left(U_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}\right) A\left(U_{1}^{\dagger} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}^{\dagger}\right)\right)
$$

We call trace-invariants the homogeneous local-unitary invariant polynomials in the tensor components [11] such that all the output indices $i^{c}$ are identified and summed (contracted) with input indices $j^{c}$ respecting the color $c=1, \ldots D$.

Graphical representation. The trace-invariants can be represented as edge colored graphs. In the mixed case we represent a tensor $A$ by a pair consisting in a white and a black vertex connected by a thick edge to which we assign a color $D+1$. The input (resp. output) indices of color $c, j^{c}$ (resp. $i^{c}$ ) are represented by half-edges of color $c$ connected to the black (resp. white) vertex. This is depicted in Fig. 2, on the left. In the pure case we represent a tensor $T$ as a white vertex with output half-edges $i^{c}$, and a tensor $\bar{T}$ as a black vertex with input half-edges $j^{c}$, as depicted in Fig. 2, on the right.
