Figure 2: Left: a mixed tensor $A_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} ; j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}$ with input indices $j^{c}$ (resp. output $i^{c}$ ) represented as half-edges of color $c$ attached to the black (resp. white) vertex. Right: the pure case with $T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}}$ and $\bar{T}_{j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}$.

The pairing of a half-edge of color $c$ on a white vertex with a half-edge of color $c$ on a black one to form an edge of color $c$ represents the identification and summation of the two corresponding indices $i^{c}$ and $j^{c}$.

As illustrated in Fig. 3, the resulting graphs are bipartite $(D+1)$-edge-colored graphs in the mixed case (simply $(D+1)$-colored graphs below), while in the pure case they are $D$-colored, as there are no thick edges.
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 3: Left: a trace-invariant for a mixed tensor $A$ with $D=3$ inputs and 3 outputs. Right: a similar invariant for the pure case with two tensors, $T$ with $D=3$ outputs and $\bar{T}$ with 3 inputs.

The trace-invariants are in one-to-one correspondence with the non-isomorphic non-labeled bipartite edge colored graphs with $n$ white and $n$ black vertices. Due to the presence of the extra edges, the invariance under relabeling in the mixed case differs from the one of the pure case.

Encoding via permutations. Trace-invariants are encoded by permutations. In the mixed case we label 1 to $n$ the copies of the tensor $A$, and we consider the $D$ permutations $\boldsymbol{\sigma}=$ $\left(\sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{D}\right), \sigma_{c} \in S_{n}$ obtained by setting $\sigma_{c}(s)=s^{\prime}$ if the output index $i^{c}$ of the tensor labeled $s$ is identified and summed with the input index $j^{c}$ of the tensor labeled $s^{\prime}$. Denoting $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)$ the labeled trace-invariants, we have:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)=\sum_{\text {all indices }}\left(\prod_{s=1}^{n} A_{i_{\sigma}^{1} \ldots i_{\sigma}^{D} ; j_{\sigma}^{1} \ldots j_{\sigma}^{D}}\right) \prod_{c=1}^{D}\left(\prod_{s=1}^{n} \delta_{i_{\sigma}^{c} ; j_{\sigma_{c}(s)}^{c}}\right)
$$

In the pure case we label 1 to $n$ the tensors $T$ and $\overline{1}$ to $\bar{n}$ the tensors $\bar{T}$, and we set $\sigma_{c}(s)=s^{\prime}$ if the output index $i^{c}$ on the white vertex $s$ is connected with the input index $j^{c}$ on the black vertex $\overline{s^{\prime}}$ :

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})=\sum_{\text {all indices }}\left(\prod_{s=1}^{n} T_{i_{\sigma}^{1} \ldots i_{\sigma}^{D}} \bar{T}_{j_{\sigma}^{1} \ldots j_{\sigma}^{D}}\right) \prod_{c=1}^{D}\left(\prod_{s=1}^{n} \delta_{i_{\sigma}^{c} ; j_{\sigma_{c}(s)}^{c}}\right)
$$

The summation convention is represented in Fig. 4. Remark that if $A=T \otimes \bar{T}$, then $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)=$ $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})$.

![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Figure 4: Convention adopted for encoding index summations with permutations, mixed on the left and pure on the right.

The connected components of the $(D+1)$-edge colored graph obtained in the mixed case correspond to the blocks of the partition $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\Pi\left(\sigma_{1}\right) \vee \cdots \vee \Pi\left(\sigma_{D}\right)$, and we denoted their number by $K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\# \Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$. This follows by observing that the cycles of the permutation $\sigma_{c}$ correspond to the bi-colored cycles of edges with colors $(c, D+1)$ in the graph. We call these the mixed connected components of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$.

The connected components of the $D$-edge colored graph obtained in the pure case (also called pure connected components) correspond to the blocks of the bipartite partition $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=$ $\bigvee_{1 \leqslant c \leqslant D} \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\sigma_{c}\right)$ discussed in Sec. 2, whose number we denoted by $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$. If $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1$, we say that $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected.

Relabeling. We let for $\eta, \nu \in S_{n}$ :

$$
\eta \boldsymbol{\sigma} \nu=\left(\eta \sigma_{1} \nu, \ldots, \eta \sigma_{D} \nu\right)
$$

The trace-invariants do not depend on the labels of the tensors. The mixed and pure cases behave slightly differently:

- The mixed case. In the mixed case a relabeling of the $n$ tensors $A$ corresponds to a simultaneous conjugation of all the $\sigma_{c}$ by the same permutation $\eta \in S_{n}$, that is:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)=\operatorname{Tr}_{\eta \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}}(A)
$$

In this case a non-labeled trace-invariant is an equivalence class (orbit in $S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{m}}$ ) of labeled bipartite $(D+1)$-edge colored graphs with the equivalence relation:

$$
\boldsymbol{\sigma} \sim_{\mathrm{m}} \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \exists \eta \in S_{n} \mid \boldsymbol{\sigma}=\eta \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \eta^{-1}
$$

- The pure case. In the pure case the white and black vertices can be relabeled independently, that is for any $\eta, \nu \in S_{n}$ :

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\eta \boldsymbol{\sigma} \nu}(T, \bar{T})
$$

In this case a non-labeled trace-invariant is an equivalence class (orbit in $S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{p}}$ ) of labeled bipartite $D$-edge colored graphs (with no thick edges) with the equivalence relation:

$$
\boldsymbol{\sigma} \sim_{\mathrm{p}} \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \exists \eta, \nu \in S_{n} \mid \boldsymbol{\sigma}=\eta \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \nu
$$

Remark 4.1. It is obvious that $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \sim_{\mathrm{m}} \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}$ implies $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \sim_{\mathrm{p}} \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}$, but the converse is not true in general. What holds however is the following:

$$
\boldsymbol{\sigma} \sim_{\mathrm{p}} \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \text { in } S_{n}^{D} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}} \sim_{\mathrm{m}} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\prime} \text { in } S_{n}^{D-1}
$$

where $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=\left(\sigma_{1} \sigma_{D}^{-1}, \ldots, \sigma_{D-1} \sigma_{D}^{-1}\right) \in S_{n}^{D-1}$, that is one can treat a pure invariant like a mixed one with one less color by declaring the edges of color $D$ of the pure invariant to be thick.

Matrices. The $D=1$ mixed case reproduces the matrix trace-invariants discussed in Sec. 3.1. Indeed, for $D=1$ a mixed trace-invariant is a collection of cycles with thick edges of color 2 and thin edges of color 1. Labeling the matrices $M$ corresponds to labeling the thick edges and (4.2) becomes $\operatorname{Tr}_{\sigma}(M)$. Relabeling the matrices corresponds to conjugating $\sigma$ by some permutation and a non-labeled trace-invariant corresponds to the conjugacy class of $S_{n} / \sim_{\mathrm{m}}$ of permutations of fixed cycle type.

The $D=2$ pure case is also matricial: one has matrices $X$ and $\bar{X}$, typically the conjugate of $X$. A trace-invariant corresponds to a collection of alternating cycles with white and black vertices and thin edges of color 1 and 2. The trace-invariants are functions of $X X^{\dagger}$.

# 4.1.2 Theory of invariants 

In this section, we show that asymptotically at large $N$ the trace-invariants generate the set localunitary invariant polynomials and are linearly independent. The results we derive are weaker than the results for unitarily invariant matrices, and it should be possible to improve them. While similar results have already been obtained in the literature [52-58,66], due to differences in vocabulary and methods we find it useful to re-derive them here.

Distance between orbits. In the mixed case, a distance $d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right)$ between two equivalence classes $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{m}}$ is defined by:

$$
d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right)=\min _{\eta_{1}, \eta_{2} \in S_{n}} \sum_{c=1}^{D}\left|\eta_{1} \sigma_{c} \eta_{1}^{-1} \eta_{2} \tau_{c}^{-1} \eta_{2}^{-1}\right|=\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \sum_{c=1}^{D}\left|\sigma_{c} \eta \tau_{c}^{-1} \eta^{-1}\right| \geqslant 0
$$

and it is well defined as it is independent on the particular representatives $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ and $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ of the classes $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}}$ and $[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}$.

In the pure case, a distance $d_{\mathrm{p}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}\right)$ between two equivalence classes $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{p}}$ is defined by:

$$
d_{\mathrm{p}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}\right)=\min _{\eta, \nu \in S_{n}} \sum_{c=1}^{D}\left|\sigma_{c} \eta \tau_{c}^{-1} \nu\right| \geqslant 0
$$

which is again a class function. The two functions are non-negative, symmetric and respect the triangle inequality. For instance, for any $\alpha$ and any $\gamma$ we have $\left|\sigma \eta \tau^{-1} \eta^{-1}\right| \leqslant\left|\sigma \gamma \alpha^{-1} \gamma^{-1}\right|+$ $\left|\gamma \alpha \gamma^{-1} \eta \tau^{-1} \eta^{-1}\right|$ and we take the minimum first over $\gamma$ and then over $\eta$. Furthermore, if $\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \sum_{c}\left|\sigma_{c} \eta \tau_{c}^{-1} \eta^{-1}\right|$ vanishes, then there exists $\eta$ such that for all $c,\left|\sigma_{c} \eta \tau_{c}^{-1} \eta^{-1}\right|=0$, that is, $\boldsymbol{\sigma}=\eta \boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}$, and similarly in the pure case. Therefore:
Lemma 4.2. The functions $d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right) \in \mathbb{N}$ and $d_{\mathrm{p}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}\right) \in \mathbb{N}$ are distance functions between the equivalence classes, in particular:

$$
d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right)=0 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \exists \eta, \boldsymbol{\sigma}=\eta \boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}, \quad \text { that is } \quad \boldsymbol{\sigma} \sim_{\mathrm{m}} \boldsymbol{\tau}
$$

and analogously for $d_{\mathrm{p}}$ and $S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{p}}$.
A spanning family. Let $P$ be a local-unitary invariant polynomial of degree $n$ in the tensor entries:

$$
P(A)=\sum_{q=0}^{n} \sum_{i, j} P_{i\left[\ldots i_{1}^{D} ; j_{1}^{1} \ldots j_{1}^{D} \mid \ldots \mid i_{q}^{1} \ldots i_{q}^{D} ; j_{q}^{1} \ldots j_{q}^{D}\right.} \prod_{v=1}^{q} A_{i_{v}^{\prime} \ldots i_{v}^{D} ; j_{v}^{\prime} \ldots j_{v}^{D}}
$$

where the coefficients are complex numbers. Since $P(A)$ is local-unitary invariant:

$$
P(A)=\int d U_{1} \cdots d U_{D} P\left(\left(U_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}\right) A\left(U_{1}^{\dagger} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}^{\dagger}\right)\right)
$$

with $d U_{c}$ the Haar measure on $N \times N$ unitary matrices and using the Weingarten formula (2.11) we get:

$$
P(A)=\sum_{q=0}^{n} \sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{q}^{D}} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(A) \sum_{\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{q}^{D}} \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}\right) \sum_{i, j} P_{i\left[\ldots i_{1}^{D} ; j_{1}^{1} \ldots j_{1}^{D} \ldots \ldots j_{q}^{1} \ldots i_{q}^{D} \ldots j_{q}^{D} \ldots\right.}
$$

Proceeding similarly in the pure case we establish the following lemma.
Lemma 4.3. The trace-invariants of a tensor $A \in M_{N}(\mathbb{C})^{\otimes D}$ are a spanning family for the localunitary invariant polynomials of degree $n \leqslant N$. More precisely, for any LU-invariant polynomial $P$ of degree $n \leqslant N$, there exists a set of complex coefficients $\left\{C_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}\right\}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m} \in S_{q}^{D} / \sim_{m}, q \leqslant n}$ such that:

$$
P(A)=\sum_{q=1}^{n} \sum_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m} \in S_{q}^{D} / \sim_{m}} C_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}} \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}(A)
$$

where $\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}(A)=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(A)$ for any representative $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}$.
In the pure case, for any LU-invariant polynomial $P(T, \bar{T})$ of degree $n \leqslant N$ in each of $T$ and $\bar{T}$, there exists a set of complex coefficients $\left\{C_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}}\right\}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p} \in S_{q}^{D} / \sim_{p}, q \leqslant n}$ such that:

$$
P(T, \bar{T})=\sum_{q=1}^{n} \sum_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p} \in S_{q}^{D} / \sim_{p}} C_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}} \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}}(T, \bar{T})
$$

where $\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}}(T, \bar{T})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(T, \bar{T})$ for any representative $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}$.
Remark 4.4. For a matrix, the statement is easily extended to polynomials of any degree using the Cayley-Hamilton Theorem. For tensors, the statement can be extended to polynomials whose degree is exponential in the system size, by application of a result by Deksen [66], see also [57], where the bound is explicitly computed for the local-unitary case ${ }^{8}$.

Linear independence. In what concerns the linear independence of the trace-invariants, the following holds.

Theorem 4.5. For any $n_{\max }$, there exists $N_{n_{\max }}$ such that for any $N \geqslant N_{n_{\max }}$ the families of functionals below are linearly independent on $\mathbb{C}$ :

- Mixed case:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}: M_{N}(\mathbb{C})^{\otimes D} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}, \quad[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{m}, n \leqslant n_{\max }
$$

- Pure case:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{p}}:\left(\mathbb{C}^{N}\right)^{\otimes D} \times\left(\mathbb{C}^{N}\right)^{\otimes D} \mapsto \mathbb{C}, \quad[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{p} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{p}, n \leqslant n_{\max }
$$

Proof. The theorem is proved in Appendix A.1.
Note that, in order to include all the trace-invariants of degree up to $n_{\max }$, one needs to choose a $N_{n_{\max }}$ larger than the number of all such invariants, which scales super exponentially with $n_{\max }$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{8}$ L.L. thanks Michael Walter for mentioning this fact.

Scalar products between orbits. In the course of the proof of Thm. 4.5 in the appendix we establish the following two instructive propositions.

Proposition 4.6 (Mixed case). We consider $A$ a Ginibre random tensor, that is, the $N^{2 D}$ components $A_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} \cdot j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}$ are independent complex Gaussian variables ${ }^{9}$ with covariance $\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{A}_{\bar{i}, \bar{j}} A_{\bar{k}, \bar{l}}\right]=$ $\prod_{c=1}^{D} \delta_{i^{c}, k^{c}} \delta_{j^{c}, l^{c}} / N^{D}$. For $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{m}}$, we define the matrix:

$$
\left\langle[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right\rangle_{\mathrm{m}}=\mathbb{E}_{M}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}}}(\bar{A}) \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}}(A)\right]=C_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}} N^{-d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right)}\left(1+O\left(N^{-1}\right)\right)
$$

where $d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right)=\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \sum_{c=1}^{D}\left|\sigma_{c} \eta \tau_{c}^{-1} \eta^{-1}\right|$ is the distance between orbits in the mixed case; $C_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}}>0$ is the number of permutations $\eta \in S_{n}$ for which $\sum_{c=1}^{D}\left|\sigma_{c} \eta \tau_{c}^{-1} \eta^{-1}\right|=$ $d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right)$ and $C_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}}}=C_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}}}$ is the cardinal of the centralizer of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. For $N$ large enough, the form $\left\langle[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right\rangle_{\mathrm{m}}$ is symmetric positive-definite and in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$ the orbits are asymptotically orthogonal:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty}\left\langle[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right\rangle_{\mathrm{m}}=C_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}}} \delta_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}}
$$

Proposition 4.7 (Pure case). Let $T_{1}, T_{2} \in\left(\mathbb{C}^{N}\right)^{\otimes D}$ be two independent Ginibre random tensors with $\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{T}_{\bar{i}} T_{\bar{k}}\right]=\prod_{c=1}^{D} \delta_{i^{c}, k^{c}} / N^{D / 2}$. For $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{p}}$ the matrix:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}\right\rangle_{\mathrm{p}} & :=\mathbb{E}_{T_{1}, T_{2}}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}}}\left(\bar{T}_{2}, \bar{T}_{1}\right) \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}}\left(T_{1}, T_{2}\right)\right] \\
& =D_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}} N^{-d_{\mathrm{p}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}\right)}\left(1+O\left(N^{-1}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d_{\mathrm{p}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}=\min _{\eta, \nu \in S_{n}} \sum_{c=1}^{D}\left|\sigma_{\nu} \eta \tau_{c}^{-1} \nu\right|\right.$ is the distance function in the pure case; $D_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}}$ is the number of couples of permutations $\eta, \nu \in S_{n}$ for which $d_{\mathrm{p}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}=\sum_{c=1}^{D}\left|\sigma_{c} \eta \tau_{c}^{-1} \nu\right|\right.$ and we denote $D_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}}}:=D_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}}}$. For $N$ large enough, the form $\left\langle[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}\right\rangle_{\mathrm{p}}$ is symmetric positivedefinite, and in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$ the orbits are asymptotically orthogonal:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty}\left\langle[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}\right\rangle_{\mathrm{p}}=D_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}}} \delta_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}}
$$

We have the following remark.
Remark 4.8. In [56] a similar scalar product is considered in the pure case, but for only one Ginibre tensor $T$, that is when $T_{1}=T$ and $T_{2}=\bar{T}$ the complex conjugate, instead of the two independent ones $T_{1}, T_{2}$. In order to eliminate the self contractions on $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})$, the authors introduce a "normal-ordering" $\mathcal{N}$ of the trace-invariants:

$$
\left\langle[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}}\right\rangle_{\mathrm{p}}^{\mathcal{N}}=\mathbb{E}\left[\overline{\mathcal{N}\left(\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})\right)} \mathcal{N}\left(\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(\bar{T}, T)\right)\right]
$$

The use of two independent tensors $T_{1}, T_{2}$ has the effect of precisely eliminating these self contractions without the need for normal-ordering. This small point is essentially the only difference between the complex tensor case and the bipartite distribution of two random tensors. ${ }^{10}$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{9}$ The joint probability measure writes $e^{-N^{D} \operatorname{Tr}\left(A A^{\dagger}\right)} d A d \bar{A}$.
    ${ }^{10}$ Regarding analogous scalar products in the context of real tensors, we also refer to [67] for invariance corresponding to tensor products of independent orthogonal matrices, and to [29] for invariance corresponding to tensor products of a single orthogonal matrix.

Non-polynomial invariants. As $N$ grows, Lemma 4.3 and Thm. 4.5 imply that the traceinvariants are both spanning and linearly independent, hence a basis in the space of invariant polynomials. In the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$, the statement formally extends to sufficiently nice functions. Loosely speaking, the functions we are interested in are series in the components of the tensor:

$$
f(A)=\sum_{q=0}^{+\infty} \sum_{i, j} P_{i\left[\ldots i\left[P_{i}\right]\ldots j\left[P_{i} \ldots j_{q}^{1} \ldots i_{q}^{D} \ldots j_{q}^{1} \ldots j_{q}^{D}\right.} \prod_{v=1}^{q} A_{i\left[\ldots i\left[P_{i}\right]\right] \ldots j_{v}^{D}}
$$

which, rescaling $A$ to $z A$ with $z \in \mathbb{C}$, admit a formal expansion of the form:

$$
f(z ; A)=\sum_{k \geqslant 0} \frac{1}{N^{k}} f_{k}(z ; A), \quad f_{k}(z ; A)=\sum_{n \geqslant 0} c_{k, n, N}(A) z^{n}
$$

where for every $k$ and $A, f_{k}(z ; A)$ is a convergent series in some neighborhood of $z=0$ and each $c_{k, n, N}(A)$ is a homogeneous LU-invariant polynomial of degree $n$. Note that the order $k$ is just the dominant order in $1 / N$ of $c_{k, n, N}(A)$, but $c_{k, n, N}(A)$ can still contain some terms in $O(1 / N)$ which wash out in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$. In this case there exists $N_{n}$ such that for $N \geqslant N_{n}, c_{k, n, N}(A)$ admits a unique expansion in trace-invariants $c_{k, n, N}(A)=\sum_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m} \in S_{q}^{D} / \sim_{m}} C_{k,[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}, N} \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}(A)$. Taking a sequence of tensors $A^{(N)} \in M_{N}(\mathbb{C})^{\otimes D}$ indexed by the size $N$, for every $n \geqslant 0$, we assume that $c_{k, n, N}\left(A^{(N)}\right)$ converges to some finite limit:

$$
c_{k, n}(a)=\sum_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m} \in S_{q}^{D} / \sim_{m}} \lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} C_{k,[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}, N} \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}\left(A^{(N)}\right)
$$

where $a$ captures some information about $A^{(N)}$ at infinite $N$, and for each $k$, the series $f_{k}(z ; a)=$ $\sum_{n \geqslant 0} c_{k, n}(a) z^{n}$ is convergent in some neighborhood of $z=0$. The full expansion $f(z ; A)$ is usually divergent for $z \neq 0$, but for any $k \geqslant 0$, one has a unique convergent expansion of $f_{k}(z, a)$ on asymptotic trace-invariants.

# 4.1.3 Finite size moments 

The appropriate invariant moments for a local-unitary invariant mixed random tensor $A$ for finite $N$ are the expectations of trace-invariants [4-16]:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}(A)\right], \quad[\boldsymbol{\sigma}] \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{m}}
$$

where we do not require any connectivity condition on $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}}$. For a pure tensor this is replaced by $\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{p}}\left(T, T^{\prime}\right)\right]$ with $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{p}}$. Only a finite number of these moments are needed to fully describe the distribution in the sense below. From Lemma 4.3 and Thm. 4.5, one can compute the expectation of any polynomial $P(A)$ in the components of $A$ which is of degree $n \leqslant N$ as:

$$
\mathbb{E}[P(A)]=\sum_{q=1}^{n} \sum_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m} \in S_{q}^{D} / \sim_{m}} c_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}(A)\right]
$$

and the coefficients of this expansion are unique for $N$ large enough, and similarly in the pure case. Indeed, this derives from applying Lemma 4.3 to the LU-invariant function: $\tilde{P}(A)=$ $\int d U_{1} \cdots d U_{D} f\left(U A U^{\dagger}\right)$ where $U=U_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes U_{D}$, together with the fact that $A$ being LU-invariant, $\mathbb{E}_{A}[\tilde{P}(A)]=\mathbb{E}[P(A)]$

This extends to the computation of $\mathbb{E}[f(A)]$ for non-necessarily invariant but sufficiently regular functions $f$ which can be obtained as the limits of sequences of polynomials, but precisely characterizing this class of functions is beyond the scope of this paper.

# 4.2 Finite size free cumulants
### 4.2.1 Linearization: intuitive picture

Our aim is to construct the equivalent of the free cumulants of random matrices discussed in Sec. 3.3 in the tensor case. In particular, the tensor free cumulants should be asymptotically additive for sums of independent random tensors.

The moment-generating function in the mixed and pure cases are:

$$
Z_{A}(B)=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{\operatorname{Tr}\left(B^{T} A\right)}\right], \quad Z_{T, \bar{T}}(J, \bar{J})=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{J \cdot T+\bar{J} \cdot \bar{T}}\right]
$$

where $\operatorname{Tr}\left(B^{T} A\right)=\sum_{\vec{i}, \bar{j}} A_{\vec{i}, \bar{j}} B_{\bar{i}, \bar{j}}$ and $J \cdot T=\sum_{\vec{i}} J_{\vec{j}} T_{\bar{j}}$ respectively $\bar{J} \cdot \bar{T}=\sum_{\bar{J}} \bar{J}_{\bar{j}} \bar{T}_{\bar{J}}$ and the tensors $B$ respectively $J, \bar{J}$ are fixed (commonly called sources in the physics literature). Note that the source terms are chosen so as to ensure that the indices of the sources and the random tensors have the same nature, for instance the indices of $A$ in the first position are summed together with the indices of $B$ in the first position, etc.

From this formulas, it is apparent why the pure case is not just the substitution $A=T \otimes \bar{T}$ : performing this substitution in $Z_{A}(B)$ leads to a generating function with a bi-linear source for $T$ and $\bar{T}$ which is different from the moment-generating function in the pure case (the latter has linear sources).

Let us consider two independent LU-invariant mixed random tensors $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ and the two moment-generating functions $Z_{A_{a}}(B)$. As $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ are independent, the generating function factors:

$$
Z_{A_{1}+A_{2}}(B)=Z_{A_{1}}(B) Z_{A_{2}}(B)
$$

so that the moment-generating functions are additive:

$$
\log Z_{A_{1}+A_{2}}(B)=\log Z_{A_{1}}(B)+\log Z_{A_{2}}(B)
$$

Replacing $B$ by $z B$, differentiating $n$ times with respect to $z$ and setting $z$ to zero, we have:

$$
\left.\frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial z^{n}} \log Z_{A_{1}+A_{2}}(z B)\right|_{z=0}=\left.\frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial z^{n}} \log Z_{A_{1}}(z B)\right|_{z=0}+\left.\frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial z^{n}} \log Z_{A_{2}}(z B)\right|_{z=0}
$$

From the LU-invariance of the measures of $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ it follows that, as functions of $B$, $Z_{A_{a}}(B)$ are LU-invariant, $Z_{A_{1}+A_{2}}$ is LU-invariant, and the three terms in (4.21) are LU-invariant as well. Since they are homogeneous polynomials in $B$ of degree $n$, for $N_{n}$ sufficiently large, they expand uniquely on the set of trace-invariants:

$$
\left.\frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial z^{n}} \log Z_{A_{1}}(z B)\right|_{z=0}=\sum_{\left[\sigma\right]_{m} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{m}} \operatorname{Tr}_{[\sigma]_{m}}(B) \mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{m}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[A_{1}\right]
$$

where the coefficients $\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{m}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$ are explicitly computed below. Due to the linear independence, Eq (4.21) implies that $\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{m}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$ are additive, as formalized in the proposition below.
Proposition 4.9. Let $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ be two sufficiently regular independent random tensors, and consider coefficients $\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{m}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[A_{a}\right]$ for $a=1,2$ as well as $\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{m}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[A_{1}+A_{2}\right]$ defined in (4.22). Then there exists $N_{n}$ such that for any $N>N_{n}$ :

$$
\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{m}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[A_{1}+A_{2}\right]=\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{m}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[A_{1}\right]+\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{m}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[A_{2}\right]
$$

Everything goes through, mutatis mutandis, in the pure case:

$$
\left.\frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial z^{n}} \frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial \bar{z}^{n}} \log Z_{T, \bar{T}}(z J, \bar{z} \bar{J})\right|_{z=0}=\sum_{[\sigma]_{\mu} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mu}} \operatorname{Tr}_{[\sigma]_{\mu}}(J, \bar{J}) \mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{\mu}}[T, \bar{T}]
$$

and for two independent pairs $T_{1}, \bar{T}_{1}$ and $T_{2}, \bar{T}_{2}$ the cumulants are additive for any $N>N_{n}$ :

$$
\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{0}}\left[T_{1}+T_{2}, \bar{T}_{1}+\bar{T}_{2}\right]=\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{\mu}}\left[T_{1}, \bar{T}_{1}\right]+\mathcal{K}_{[\sigma]_{\mu}}\left[T_{2}, \bar{T}_{2}\right]
$$

# 4.2.2 Moment-cumulant relations at finite $N$ 

A trick to derive the finite $N$ versions of the free cumulants in the matrix case is to take the generating function of classical cumulants and to average over the unitary group using Weingarten calculus [3]. We will employ the exact same strategy for tensors, and derive explicit expressions for the coefficients $\mathcal{K}_{\left[\boldsymbol{\sigma}\right]_{n}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$ and $\mathcal{K}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{p}}[T, \bar{T}]$. As these expressions turn out to be invertible, we posit that this coefficients yield the correct generalization of finite size free cumulants for LU-invariant random tensors ${ }^{11}$.

Theorem 4.10. Consider $A$ a mixed LU-invariant random tensor. Then for any fixed tensor $B$, the Taylor coefficients of the logarithm of $Z_{A}(z B)=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{z \operatorname{Tr} B^{\mathrm{T}} A}\right]$ admit the expansion:

$$
\frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial z^{n}} \log Z_{A}(z B)\left.\right|_{z=0}=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(B) \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]
$$

where the mixed finite size free cumulants $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$ are (the natural generalization of (3.25)):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A] & =\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}} \sum_{\substack{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\
\pi \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma}) \vee \Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau})}} \lambda_{\pi} \prod_{G \in \pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{G}}(A)\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c \mid G} \tau_{c \mid G}^{-1}\right) \\
& =\sum_{\substack{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\
\pi \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \lambda_{\pi} \sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D} \\
\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}) \leqslant \pi}} \prod_{G \in \pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{G}}(A)\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c \mid G} \tau_{c \mid G}^{-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In the pure case, we view permutations over $n$ elements as bijections from the set $\{1, \ldots n\}$ of white elements to the set $\{\overline{1}, \ldots \bar{n}\}$ of black elements, $s \rightarrow \overline{\sigma_{c}(s)}$ and denoting $S_{n, \bar{n}}$ the set of such bijections, we have:

$$
\left.\partial_{z}^{n} \partial_{\bar{z}}^{n} \log Z_{T, \bar{T}}(z J, \bar{z} \bar{J})\right|_{z=\bar{z}=0}=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n, \bar{n}}^{D}} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(J, \bar{J}) \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]
$$

where the pure finite size free cumulants are written in terms of bipartite partitions as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}] & =\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n, \bar{n}}^{D}} \sum_{\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n})} \lambda_{\Pi} \prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{B}}(T, \bar{T})\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c \mid B} \tau_{c \mid B}^{-1}\right) \\
& =\sum_{\substack{\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n}) \\
\Pi \geqslant \Pi_{p}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \lambda_{\Pi} \sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n, \bar{n}}^{D} \\
\Pi_{p}(\boldsymbol{\tau}) \leqslant \Pi}} \prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{B}}(T, \bar{T})\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c \mid B} \tau_{c \mid B}^{-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tau_{\mid B}$ is the restriction ${ }^{12}$ of the bijection $\tau:\{1, \ldots n\} \rightarrow\{\overline{1}, \ldots \bar{n}\}$ to the block $B$, which to the labels in the set $B$ maps those in the set $\bar{B}, \sigma_{c \mid B} \tau_{c \mid B}^{-1}$ is a permutation of the elements of $\bar{B}$ having the same cycle type as the permutation $\tau_{c \mid B}^{-1} \sigma_{c \mid B}$ of the elements of $B$, and $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ denotes the bipartite partition into pure connected components corresponding to $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$.

$$

It is self evident that $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$ and $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]$ are class functions for the equivalence relations $\sim_{\mathrm{m}}$ respectively $\sim_{\mathrm{p}}$, and regrouping the sums over $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ into the corresponding equivalence classes and using Proposition 4.9, it follows that $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$ and $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]$ are additive for $N$ large enough.

Observe that in terms of classical cumulants, we may express the relations above in terms of the $\Phi$ (leading to the formulation considered for taking asymptotics):

$$
\prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{l} b}(T, \bar{T})\right]=\sum_{\substack{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \tilde{n}) \\\Pi \geqslant \pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})}} \Phi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}[T, \bar{T}]

and inverse formula (and similar formulas in the mixed case).
Note that for a purely connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ we have not only $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1_{n, \tilde{n}}$ (the one set bipartite partition), but also $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1_{n}$, and therefore:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A] & =\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(A)\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}\right) \\

\end{aligned}
$$

that is the pure cumulants can be obtained from the mixed ones by simply substituting $A=T \otimes \bar{T}$, but this is in general no longer true for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ which is not purely connected (and for non-connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[T \otimes \bar{T}]$ is non in general invariant under $\sim_{\mathrm{p}}$.

For instance for $n=D=2$, consider a complex matrix $M$ and let $A=M \otimes \bar{M}, \mathbf{i d}_{2}=(\mathrm{id}, \mathrm{id}) \in$ $S_{2}^{2}$ (purely connected), and $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{(12)}=((12),(12)) \in S_{2}^{2}$ (connected but not purely connected). Then one explicitly computes:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}_{\mathbf{i d}_{2}}[M, \bar{M}] & =\mathcal{K}_{\mathbf{i d}_{2}}^{\mathrm{m}}[M \otimes \bar{M}]=\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{(12)}}^{\mathrm{m}}[M \otimes \bar{M}]-\frac{1}{N^{4}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}\left(M M^{\dagger}\right)\right]^{2} \\

\end{aligned}
$$

and:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{(12)}}[M, \bar{M}]=\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{(12)}}^{\mathrm{m}}[M \otimes \bar{M}]-\frac{1}{N^{4}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}\left(M M^{\dagger}\right)\right]^{2} \neq \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{(12)}}^{\mathrm{m}}[M \otimes \bar{M}]
$$

# 4.3 Asymptotic moments 

While one needs all the trace-invariants to describe unitarily invariant functions in the limit $N \rightarrow$ $\infty$, similar to random matrices, the dominant contribution of the expectations of these quantities in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$ should not contain more information on the asymptotic distribution than the expectations of the connected ones. This is because one expects again an asymptotic factorization of the expectations of trace-invariants over their connected components, with the non-factorized parts playing a role only at sub-dominant orders.

### 4.3.1 Mixed case

We consider a mixed invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ consisting in several mixed connected components $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}^{\mathrm{m}}, \ldots \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}^{\mathrm{m}}$ corresponding to the blocks of $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and we denote:

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]:=k_{q}\left(\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}^{\mathrm{m}}}(A), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}^{\mathrm{m}}}(A)\right)
$$

the associated finite $N$ classical cumulant. The superscript " $m$ " indicates that the components are connected in the "mixed sense": these are the connected components of the $(D+1)$-edge colored graph, which includes the thick edges, in the representation introduced in Sec. 4.1.1.

The approach we pursue is to study invariant tensor distributions for which an asymptotic scaling function of the classical cumulants $r_{A}: S_{n}^{D} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is given:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r_{A}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)
$$

where the $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)$ are not all vanishing and are called asymptotic moments. The aim is to obtain a theory of (free) probability for all invariant distributions $A, A^{\prime}, \ldots$ that share the same scaling function $r_{A}=r_{A^{\prime}}$, but might have different asymptotic moments. For classical random matrix ensembles for instance, the scaling function is $r_{A}(\sigma)=2-\# \sigma$.

If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is connected (in the mixed sense), the classical cumulant equals the expectation and we have:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r_{A}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)\right]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)
$$

while if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is not connected $\left(K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})>1\right)$, we sometimes render its connected components explicit and denote:

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}^{\mathrm{m}}}^{\mathrm{m}}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}^{\mathrm{m}}^{*}(a)
$$

For $\pi \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$, we define the multiplicative extension of the asymptotic moments:

$$
\varphi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\prod_{G \in \pi} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{G G}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a), \quad \text { so that } \quad \varphi_{1_{n}, \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a), \quad \varphi_{1 \mathrm{~T}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\prod_{i=1}^{q} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}^{\mathrm{m}}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}^{\mathrm{m}}$ are the mixed connected components of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. We use similar notations for the finite $N$ versions $\Phi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$, and for different ensembles $A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}$ we define in the obvious manner the notations $\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[\widehat{A}]=\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right]$ and $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a})$ and their multiplicative extensions.

### 4.3.2 Pure case

In the pure case, the trace-invariants factor over the pure connected components, that is, the connected components of the $D$-edge colored graph described in Sec. 4.1.1. Denoting $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}^{\mathrm{p}}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}^{\mathrm{p}}$ the pure connected components of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ corresponding to the blocks of the bipartite partition $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$,

we have $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})=\prod_{i=1}^{q} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}^{p}}(T, \bar{T})$, and similar to the mixed case, we denote the pure classical cumulants:

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=k_{q}\left(\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}^{p}}(T, \bar{T}), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}^{p}}(T, \bar{T})\right)
$$

We assume that a scaling function $r_{T, \bar{T}}: S_{n}^{D} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is given such that:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r_{T, \bar{T}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})
$$

where the $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})$ are not all vanishing. If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected, $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1$, then:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r_{T, \bar{T}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})\right]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})
$$

and if it is not, we sometimes use the notation $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}^{p}, \ldots \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}^{p}}(t, \bar{t})$. If $\Pi$ is a bipartite partition such that $\Pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$, we define the multiplicative extension:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\varphi_{\Pi, \boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=\prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1 \bar{B}}}(t, \bar{t}) \\
\varphi_{1_{n, n, \boldsymbol{\sigma}}}(t, \bar{t})=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t}), \quad \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=\prod_{i=1}^{q} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}^{p}}(t, \bar{t})
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\sigma_{\mid \bar{B}}$, the restriction of the map $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ to the set $B$ (which is such that $\sigma_{\mid \bar{B}}(B)=\bar{B}$ ) is well defined, as $\Pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$.

The $D=2$ pure case corresponds to matrices $M$ and $\bar{M}$ (where $\bar{M}$ can be the complex conjugate of $M$ or not). The Gaussian scaling is in this case $r_{M, \bar{M}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=2-\#\left(\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2}^{-1}\right)$. The case where $M$ is the pure complex Gaussian $(D=2)$ corresponds to the square Wishart random matrix $(D=1)$, yielding the order $n$ purely connected asymptotic moments:

$$
\varphi_{\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right) \mid K_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right)=1}=C_{n}
$$

For $D \geqslant 3$, pure complex random tensor ensembles with $\bar{T}$ the complex conjugate of $T$ corresponding to LU-invariant perturbed Gaussian distributions have been studied extensively [4-18]. We review them below in Sec. 5.1 and Sec. 5.4. For such models it can be proven [11] that the classical cumulants admit an asymptotic behavior:

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}] \sim N^{D-\Omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})
$$

with $\Omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}) \geqslant 0$. Contrary to the $D=2$ case, for higher $D$ the scaling factor $\Omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}) \geqslant 0$ is not necessarily additive over the pure connected components, with explicit counterexamples are known for $D=6$ (see Sec. 5.3).

# 4.3.3 Order of dominance and asymptotic factorization 

Both in the mixed and in the pure case, denoting $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}, \ldots \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}$ some connected (in the appropriate sense) invariants and $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{G}=\bigcup_{j \in G} \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{j}$, the classical moment cumulant formula writes:

$$
\frac{1}{N \sum_{i=1}^{q} r\left(\sigma_{i}\right)} \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{i=1}^{q} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}}[\cdot]\right]=\sum_{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(q)} \frac{1}{N \sum_{i=1}^{q} r\left(\sigma_{i}\right)-\sum_{G \in \mathrm{e}} r\left(\sigma_{G}\right)} \prod_{G \in \pi} \frac{1}{N^{r\left(\sigma_{G}\right)}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{G}}[\cdot]
$$

By our scaling assumption, $N^{-r\left(\sigma_{G}\right)} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{G}}[\cdot]$ converges to some finite value in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$, and one may therefore deduce from the equation above that:

- all the rescaled expectations generally ${ }^{13}$ have well defined limits when $N \rightarrow \infty$ if and only if the scaling function is subadditive on connected components, that is, for any set of connected components $\left\{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ :

$$
r\left(\bigcup_{i \in I} \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right) \leqslant \sum_{i \in I} r\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)
$$

- the rescaled expectations generally factor at first order:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N \sum_{i} r\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)} \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{i} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}}[\cdot]\right]=\prod_{i} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}}(\cdot)
$$

if and only if the scaling function is strictly subadditive, that is, for any set of connected components $\left\{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ :

$$
r\left(\bigcup_{i \in I} \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)<\sum_{i \in I} r\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)
$$

A scaling function $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=D-\Omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ as in (4.44) is clearly strictly subadditive if $\Omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ is additive (as it is the case for $D=2$ ), but because of the presence of the $D$ factor, it may very well be subadditive even if $\Omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ is not additive, as it is the case for $D=6$ (see Sec. 5.3).

The dominant, or first order invariants are the invariants with maximal $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$; the order of dominance of an invariant is the amount by which its scaling is supressed with respect to the first order ones, that is $1+\max _{\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}} r\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}\right)-r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{13}$ Here we are interested in characterizing appropriate choices of scaling functions that can be used to describe classes of distributions scaling in this manner, for which the values of the asymptotic moments $\varphi$ can a priori take any values. The following statements are meant in this sense, but other choices of scaling could be considered e.g. for distributions whose higher order asymptotic moments vanish.

# 5 The Gaussian scaling 

We discuss the scaling function $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ for some pure LU-invariant random tensors $T, \bar{T}$ with $\bar{T}$ the complex conjugate of $T$. We first discuss the Gaussian case, when the components of $T$ are i.i.d. complex Gaussian random variables (a Ginibre like tensor) and subsequently the case of a LU-invariant perturbed Gaussian distribution. In both cases, the first order asymptotic moments $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(t, t^{\prime}\right)$ corresponding to invariants with maximal scaling $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ are a subclass of the purely connected invariants, called melonic, which we will discuss in detail.

This discussion is also crucial for the rest of the paper. In Sec. 6, we will derive the first order free cumulants for generic ensembles of either pure random tensors that scale like a complex Gaussian tensor, or mixed random tensors that scale like a Wishart tensor. Due to these scaling assumption, such distributions have the same first order invariants as the pure complex Gaussian and Wishart tensors discussed here.

### 5.1 Asymptotic scaling of pure Gaussian tensors

We start by recalling some well-known (see e.g. [8]) results for a Gaussian pure random tensor $T, \bar{T}$, that is, the components of $T$ are i.i.d. complex Gaussian random variables. As shown in [8], a large class of perturbed Gaussian tensor measures fall in the same universality class. The expectation of a function $f$ is:

$$
\mathbb{E}[f(T, \bar{T})]=\int \frac{d T d \bar{T}}{\mathcal{N}} e^{-N^{D-\mathrm{i}} T \cdot \bar{T}} f(T, \bar{T})
$$

where $d T=\prod_{\left\{i_{s}\right\}_{1 \leqslant s \leqslant D}} d T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}}$ and similarly for the complex conjugate, the normalization $\mathcal{N}$ is chosen so that $\mathbb{E}[1]=1$, and $T \cdot \bar{T}=\sum_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}=1}^{N} T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}} \bar{T}_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}}$.

We are interested in studying the asymptotic moments $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})$, which we denote from now on simply $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}$, and the scaling function $r_{T, \bar{T}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$, henceforth denoted $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$. The expectations of trace-invariants are computed using Wick theorem, that is, the classical moment-cumulant formula for a centered Gaussian random variable:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[T_{i_{1}^{1} \ldots i_{1}^{D}} \bar{T}_{j_{1}^{1} \ldots j_{1}^{D}} \cdots T_{i_{n}^{1} \ldots i_{n}^{D}} \bar{T}_{j_{n}^{1} \ldots j_{n}^{D}}\right]=\sum_{\eta \in S_{n}} \prod_{s=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[T_{i_{s}^{1} \ldots i_{s}^{D}} \bar{T}_{j_{q(s)}^{1} \ldots j_{q(s)}^{D}}\right]
$$

where $\eta$ defines the "Wick pairing". Since $\mathbb{E}\left[T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}} \bar{T}_{j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}\right]=N^{1-D} \prod_{c=1}^{D} \delta_{i^{c} \cdot j^{c}}$, we get:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})\right]=\sum_{\eta \in S_{n}} N^{n-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)}, \quad d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=\sum_{c=1}^{D}\left|\sigma_{c} \eta^{-1}\right|
$$

The classical cumulants are given by similar expressions, but with an additional connectivity condition. To be precise, for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}$ a collection of purely connected trace-invariants, $K_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)=1$, denoting $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ their disjoint union, we have:

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=k_{q}\left(\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}}(T, \bar{T}), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}}(T, \bar{T})\right)=\sum_{\substack{\eta \in S_{n}, \text { s.t. } \\ K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1}} N^{n-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)}
$$

where $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$ is the number of pure connected components of the trace-invariant defined by the $D+1$ permutations $\left(\eta, \sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{D}\right)$. This sum is dominated by the terms which minimize $d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$, that is:

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}] \sim N^{n-\min _{\eta \in S_{n}, K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1} d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}
$$

where:

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=\operatorname{Card}\left\{\eta \in S_{n} \mid K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1 \text { and } d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta) \text { is minimal }\right\}
$$

It follows that the scaling function for a complex pure Gaussian tensor is:

$$
r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=n-\min _{\eta \in S_{n}, K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1} d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)
$$

We will review below various known properties of this Gaussian scaling function. However, we emphasize from the beginning that one main question remains open: it is not known whether this scaling function is subadditive or not. We conjecture this to be the case.

Conjecture 5.1. The Gaussian scaling function:

$$
r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=n-\min _{\eta \in S_{n}, K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1} d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)
$$

is strictly subadditive on the pure connected components, that is for any $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with pure connected components $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}$ for $i \in I, r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})<\sum_{i \in I} r\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)$.

# 5.2 Melonic and compatible invariants 

Two classes of trace-invariants will play an important role in the following.
Melonic invariants. Melonic invariants [7] dominate the asymptotic moments in the Gaussian and perturbed Gaussian cases, and more generally, in the case of pure random tensors for which the $\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]$ exhibit Gaussian scaling. The following definitions and results are folklore in the random tensor literature, see [11] and references therein.

Let us fix $D$. Melonic invariants are defined recursively in the graphical representation: the only invariant with two vertices is melonic (represented on the left in Fig. 5) and corresponds to the unique element of $S_{1}^{D}$. If a connected trace-invariant is melonic and has more than two vertices, then it contains a black and a white vertex linked by $D-1$ edges, representing a tensor $T$ and a tensor $\bar{T}$ sharing precisely $D-1$ indices summed together. If the two remaining indices have color $c$, replacing this pair by an edge of color $c$ as in Fig. 5, the resulting invariant is itself melonic. Fig. 6 depicts some example of melonic graph. ${ }^{14}$
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

Figure 5: Left: the only $D$-colored graph (here $D=3$ ) with two vertices is melonic. Right: a pair of vertices linked by $D-1$ edges is replaced by an edge.

This recursive construction induces a pairing of the black and white vertices, corresponding to the list of pairs of vertices recursively removed. The pairing of vertices does not depend on the order in which the removals are performed: for each melonic trace-invariant this pairing is unique and will be called its canonical pairing. Another characterization is given in Thm. 5.3.

An alternating cycle in the colored graph consisting in edges of a color $c$ and canonical pairs is said to be a separating cycle, if cutting any pair of edges of color $c$ in the cycle, the number of pure connected components of the graph is raised by one. An equivalent characterization of melonic invariants is that any cycle alternating edges of a fixed color and canonical pairs either contains a single colored edge, or is separating.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{14}$ Conversely, melonic graphs are constructed by recursive insertions of pairs of vertices connected by $D-1$ edges, respecting the colorings, starting from the graph with two vertices.

![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure 6: Example of melonic graph for $D=3$. The canonical pairs are highlighted in grey.

The following shows that among connected invariants in $S_{n}^{D}$, melonic invariants are those which minimize the sum of distances between all the pairs of permutations $\sum_{1 \leqslant c_{1}<c_{2} \leqslant D}\left|\sigma_{c_{1}} \sigma_{c_{2}}^{-1}\right|$.

Theorem 5.2 (Gurau, Rivasseau [4-6]). Consider a trace-invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$. The degree of the invariant:

$$
\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\sum_{1 \leqslant c_{1}<c_{2} \leqslant D}\left|\sigma_{c_{1}} \sigma_{c_{2}}^{-1}\right|-(D-1)\left(n-K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})\right)
$$

is a non-negative integer $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}) \geqslant 0$. For $D \geqslant 4$, the degree vanishes if and only if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is melonic.
We have the following associated result (see e.g. [8]).
Theorem 5.3. For $D \geqslant 3$, consider a trace-invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ and $\eta \in S_{n}$. Then:

$$
\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)-\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=D K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)-(D-1) K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-n+d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta) \geqslant 0
$$

with equality if and only if the trace-invariant $(\eta, \boldsymbol{\sigma})$ is melonic, which implies that $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is melonic.
If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is melonic, then there exists a unique $\eta \in S_{n}$ such that $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=$ 0 : it corresponds to the canonical pairing of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. This holds in particular if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is melonic and purely connected.

If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is melonic but not purely connected, there are other $\eta \in S_{n}$ (different from the canonical pairing) such that $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=0$ and $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)<K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$.

Compatible invariants. Compatible invariants $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ (see e.g. [47]) are those for which there exists a permutation $\eta$ lying on a geodesic linking every pair of permutations of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. Defining:

$$
\nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=\sum_{1 \leqslant c_{1}<c_{2} \leqslant D}\left(\left|\sigma_{c_{1}} \eta^{-1}\right|+\left|\sigma_{c_{2}} \eta^{-1}\right|-\left|\sigma_{c_{1}} \sigma_{c_{2}}^{-1}\right|\right) \geqslant 0
$$

then $\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta) \geqslant 0$ vanishes if and only if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is compatible and if $\nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=0$, we say that $\eta$ renders $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ compatible.

Lemma 5.4. Melonic invariants are compatible. If $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ is melonic, there is a unique permutation $\eta$ which realizes $\nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=0$, and it corresponds to the canonical pairing of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$.

Proof. Since:

$$
\sum_{1 \leqslant c_{1}<c_{2} \leqslant D}\left(\left|\sigma_{c_{1}} \eta^{-1}\right|+\left|\sigma_{c_{2}} \eta^{-1}\right|\right)=(D-1) \sum_{c=1}^{D}\left|\sigma_{c} \eta^{-1}\right|
$$

we have:

$$
\frac{1}{D-1} \nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)-\frac{\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}{D-1}+D\left[K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)\right]
$$

For a melonic $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$, Thm. 5.2, and Thm. 5.3 imply that first $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=0$, and second there exists a unique $\eta$ corresponding to the canonical pairing such that $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$ and $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=0$.

# 5.3 Order of dominance for the Gaussian scaling 

Rewriting the Gaussian scaling function in $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=n-\min d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$ using Thm. 5.3 we conclude that the finite $N$ cumulants scale like:

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}] \sim N^{1-(D-1)\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-1\right)-\min \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}
$$

where the minimum is taken over the $\eta \in S_{n}$ such that $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1$ and $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}$ is the number of $\eta \in S_{n}$ with $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1$ which minimize $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)$.

First order invariants. The first order contributions are the invariants with maximal scaling.
Theorem 5.5. For $D \geqslant 3$ and $T$ the order $D$ complex pure Gaussian tensor, the invariants $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with maximal scaling $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ are the purely connected, melonic invariants. Furthermore, the corresponding asymptotic moment $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}$ is one, and the first correction is of order $N^{3-D}$ :

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]\left\lvert\, \begin{array}{l}
K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1 \\
\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=0
\end{array}=N+O\left(1 / N^{D-3}\right)\right.
$$

The only point not contained in Thm. 5.3 is the order of the correction, see e.g. [69]. The fact that $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=1$ is to be compared with the $D=2$ case (4.43), for which one obtains the Catalan number $C_{n}$. The melonic invariants can be enumerated and the number of connected melonic invariants is the Fuss-Catalan number [7], which is to be compared with the $D=2$ case for which there is only one such invariant at each $n$.

Purely connected invariants. The order of dominance $1+(D-1)\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-1\right)+\min \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)$ of an invariant captures the amount by which its scaling is suppressed with respect to the first order invariants. The invariants of orders $k \in\{2, \ldots, D-1\}$ are purely connected and such that $\min \bar{\omega}=k-1$ [70]. For order $D$ and above, both $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and $\min \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$ play a role in determining the order. This is new with respect to the $D=2$ case, for which there is no equivalent of $\min \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$. For purely connected trace-invariants, (5.12) simplifies to:

$$
\left.\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]\right|_{K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1} \sim N^{1-\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}
$$

and one can in principle $[16,70]$ identify for any order $k \geqslant 2$ the purely connected trace-invariants with $\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=k-1$. The contributions of order 2 and 3 are for instance given in (19) and (25), (26) and (27) of [70] and are asymptotically enumerated in [71]. In practice, this becomes rapidly quite tedious. Given a purely connected trace-invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$, short of a full computation, it is not obvious how to relate $\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)$ to the properties of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$.
Proposition 5.6. From (5.11) it follows that for $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ purely connected we have:

$$
\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta) \geqslant \frac{\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}{D-1}
$$

with equality if and only if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is compatible.
This gives a lower bound on the order of contribution of an invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. There are compatible and non-compatible invariants at any order, as for every $k \geqslant 2$ it is easy to construct both compatible and non-compatible purely connected invariants satisfying $\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=k-1 .^{15}$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{15}$ This relies on the method of [69]. One can also prove that the probability for an invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ of degree $(k-1)(D-1)$ to be compatible tends to one when $n$ goes to infinity.

Non-connected invariants. The first contribution with $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})>1$ arises at order $D$ and corresponds to $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ consisting of two purely connected melonic graphs. This generalizes to arbitrary number of pure connected components.
Theorem 5.7. For $D \geqslant 3$ and $T$ the order $D$ complex pure Gaussian tensor, the invariants $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with maximal scaling $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ at fixed number of connected components $q=K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ are the disjoint unions of $q$ melonic purely connected components:

$$
\left.\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]\right|_{\substack{K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=q \\ \omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=0}}}=N^{1-(D-1)(q-1)}\left(\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}+O\left(1 / N^{D-2}\right)\right)
$$

where $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}$ is the number of $\eta$ such that $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$ is melonic. ${ }^{16}$
For non-melonic, non purely connected invariants, the situation is worse. The task of computing the Gaussian scaling function for an arbitrary invariant is computationally hard: beyond checking all the Wick pairings, no procedure is known to read off $\min \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$ or to construct the $\eta$ minimizing $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)$ under the constraint $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1$. As general exact results are lacking, the best one can do is to search for convenient bounds on the scaling function. For any invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ an obvious bound on the Gaussian scaling is:

$$
r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1-(D-1)\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-1\right)-\min _{\eta_{\mathrm{E}} S_{n}, K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1} \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta) \leqslant D-\sum_{i=1}^{K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}(D-1)
$$

The bound is saturated by the melonic family and is additive on the pure connected components.
The whole idea is to try to improve this naive additive bound as much as possible. The strategy is to search for bounds consisting in a constant term $D,{ }^{17}$ the scaling of the expectation of 1 , plus a piece which is additive on the pure connected components. The whole point is to find optimal upper bounds: for various families $\mathbb{B}$ of purely connected invariants one searches for some numbers $b\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)$ for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i} \in \mathbb{B}$ such that:

$$
r\left(\bigcup_{i} \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)=D-\sum_{i}(D-1)-\min _{\eta_{\mathrm{E}} S_{n}, K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1} \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta) \leqslant D-\sum_{i} b\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)
$$

and the bound is tight, ${ }^{18}$ in the sense that for any $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{l} \in \mathbb{B}$, there exists some $\bigcup_{j} \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{j}$ with $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{j} \in \mathbb{B}$, such that the bound is saturated for $\bigcup_{j} \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{j} \cup \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{l}$. The naive bound (5.14) would correspond to $b\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)=D-1$, but it is not tight, and the point is to improve this by increasing $b\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)$ as much as possible: while for purely connected melonic invariants $b\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)=D-1$ cannot be improved, it turns out that for other invariants this can be improved to some $b\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)>D-1$, called optimal (due to the tightness) $[12-16,72,73]$.

For $D<6$, the maximal $b\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)$ allowed by the scaling of the purely connected invariants, $b\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}\right)=D-1+\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} \bar{\omega}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i} ; \eta\right)$, works in all the examples treated so far ${ }^{19}$, and (5.15) is always saturated. However, as detailed in the last section of [16] this cannot be true in general. For $D=6$ there exists a connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{0} \in S_{3}^{6}$ such that $r\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{0}\right)=-4$ but $r\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{0} \cup \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{0}\right)=-12$, inconsistent

$$
\frac{k_{2}\left(\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{0}}(T, \bar{T}), \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{0}}(T, \bar{T})\right)}{\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{0}}(T, \bar{T})\right]^{2}} \asymp N^{-4}

However, we stress that the Gaussian scaling function is clearly subadditive in this case, that is, this example does not contradict our conjecture 5.1.

# 5.4 Random tensor models with invariant potentials 

The expectations of a perturbed Gaussian tensor measure are given by:

$$
\mathbb{E}[f(T, \bar{T})]=\int \frac{d T d \bar{T}}{\mathcal{N}} e^{-N^{D-1} T \cdot \bar{T}+V(T, \bar{T})} f(T, \bar{T})
$$

where $\mathcal{N}$ is such that $\mathbb{E}(1)=1$, and the perturbation potential is an invariant:

$$
V(T, \bar{T})\left[\left\{z_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\right\}\right]=\sum_{n \geqslant 2} \sum_{\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}} \frac{N^{\zeta(\boldsymbol{\sigma})} z_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}}{c(\boldsymbol{\sigma})} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})
$$

with $\zeta(\boldsymbol{\sigma}) \geqslant 0$ a choice of scaling, $c(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ suitable combinatorial factors and $z_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}} \in \mathbb{C}$ the coupling constants. The convergence of the integral is ensured for some choices of the couplings. We denote $\mathbb{B}$ the (potentially infinite) set of trace-invariants for which $z_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}} \neq 0$. The Gaussian case is recovered by setting all the couplings to 0 , and will be denoted $T_{0}$ in this subsection.

The characterization of the asymptotic moments of such distributions is usually approached "perturbatively", that is by expanding $\exp V(T, \bar{T})$ in Taylor series and exchanging the Gaussian integral and the sum. The cumulants are then expressed as divergent sums over connected $(D+1)$-colored graphs. The limit $N \rightarrow \infty$ selects sub-series of graphs that optimize some combinatorial constraints and are summable when the coupling constants are sufficiently small. The fact that this procedure provides the true $N \rightarrow \infty$ asymptotic of the cumulants of (5.16) is proved by constructive methods $[8,11,18]$.

The advantage of the perturbative approach is that it reduces the computation of the asymptotic scaling of the cumulants $\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=k_{q}\left(\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}}(T, \bar{T}), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}}(T, \bar{T})\right)$ for $T$ distributed as in (5.16), to the evaluation of the dominant asymptotic contributions of Gaussian cumulants of the form:

$$
k_{q+l}\left(\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}}\left(T_{0}, \bar{T}_{0}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}}\left(T_{0}, \bar{T}_{0}\right), \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}}\left(T_{0}, \bar{T}_{0}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{l}}\left(T_{0}, \bar{T}_{0}\right)\right)
$$

where $T_{0}$ is the order $D$ pure Gaussian tensor of the previous subsections, and the $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{i}$ can be any invariant in $\mathbb{B}$.

Denoting by $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ and $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ the disjoint unions of the $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}$ and $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}$, respectively, and letting $n$ be the total number of tensors $T_{0}$, so that $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cup \boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}$, and $\eta \in S_{n}$ be an arbitrary permutation, the asymptotic scaling $r_{V}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ of $\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]$ is obtained (5.5) by maximizing $n-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cup \boldsymbol{\tau}, \eta)$ over $\eta \in S_{n}$

Theorem 5.8 (Gaussian universality). As a function of the scaling $\zeta(\boldsymbol{\tau})$ of the potential $V$ in the distribution (5.16), we obtain different large $N$ limits:

- If $\zeta(\boldsymbol{\tau})=D-1$ for all the invariants $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in \mathbb{B}$, then the distribution is asymptotically Gaussian with a modified covariance [8]:

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}] \sim_{N} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[T_{0}, \bar{T}_{0}\right] G^{n}, \quad \forall \boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}
$$

where the notation $\sim_{N}$ signifies that the two are identical at first order in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$. Furthermore, denoting $n_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}$ the cardinal of the set on which $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ acts, $G$ is the unique power series solution of the equation:

$$
G=1-\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in \mathbb{B} \\ \text { melonic }}} n_{\boldsymbol{\tau}} z_{\boldsymbol{\tau}} G^{n_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}}
$$

We stress that this holds independently on the existence of a tight additive upper bound. The same holds if $\zeta(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=D-1$ for the melonic graphs and $\zeta(\boldsymbol{\sigma})<D-1$ for the non-melonic ones. ${ }^{22}$

Assuming the existence of a tight additive upper bound on the Gaussian scaling (5.15) involving optimal $b(\boldsymbol{\tau})>D-1$ for the non-melonic $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in \mathbb{B}$ and of the upper bound (5.19), then:

- If for all $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in \mathbb{B}, \zeta(\boldsymbol{\tau})<b(\boldsymbol{\tau}),{ }^{23}$ then the distribution is asymptotically Gaussian identical with the distribution of $T_{0}$, in the sense that for any trace-invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ :

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}] \sim \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[T_{0}, \bar{T}_{0}\right]
$$

- If $\zeta(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=D-1$ for the melonic graphs and $D-1 \leqslant \zeta(\boldsymbol{\tau})<b(\boldsymbol{\tau})$ for the non-melonic ones, the Gaussian behavior of (5.20) and (5.21) is obtained again.
- If for some non-melonic $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in \mathbb{B}, \zeta(\boldsymbol{\tau})=b(\boldsymbol{\tau})$, then the distribution is not necessarily asymptotically Gaussian $[12-16] .{ }^{24}$
- If for some $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in \mathbb{B}, \zeta(\boldsymbol{\tau})>b(\boldsymbol{\tau})$, then the distribution does not admit a large $N$ limit.
