# 5.5 Scaling of the Wishart tensor 

Similar to a Wishart matrix, the Wishart tensor is obtained from the pure complex Gaussian tensor $T, \bar{T}$ by partially tracing over one of its indices:

$$
W_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} \cdot j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}=\sum_{k=1}^{N} T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} k} \bar{T}_{j^{1} \ldots j^{D} k}
$$

A priori, this is just an equivalent perspective on the pure case $T, \bar{T}$ with the difference that there is a fixed labeling of the $T$ and $\bar{T}$ indicating the pairs whose $(D+1)$ th indices are summed together to form a mixed tensor.

Scaling function. As $T$ is a pure complex Gaussian, we have for $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ :

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[W]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(w), \quad r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=n-\min d((\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}), \eta)
$$

where the minimum is taken over $\eta \in S_{n}$ for which $K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=K_{\mathrm{p}}((\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}), \eta)=1$, and $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=$ $\left(\sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{D}, \mathrm{id}\right)$ so that $d((\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}), \eta)=d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)+|\eta|$. As $r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=r(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ with $r$ the Gaussian scaling in (5.7):

$$
r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1-D\left(K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-1\right)-\min \tilde{\omega}((\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}) ; \eta)
$$

First order. The first order corresponds to the $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ which are mixed connected (hence not necessarily purely connected) and for which $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic, that is, they are melonic when including the thick edges corresponding to the permutation id, therefore:

- If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected, then its canonical pairing must be the identity: $\tilde{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \mathrm{id})=0$.
- If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is not purely connected, then each of its pure connected components is melonic, and two situations may occur for the thick edges: either they connect the vertices of a canonical pair in one of the pure connected components, or if they connect different pure connected components, then the cycle in the graph formed alternatively by thick edges and canonical pairs is a separating cycle (Sec. 5.2). In that case, the canonical pairing is not the identity.
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

Figure 7: A pure random tensor with $D$ indices with scaling function $r$ is defined asymptotically at first order by the purely connected melonic invariants. A mixed random tensor with scaling function $r_{W}$ is defined asymptotically at first order by the melonic invariants which are connected when the thick edges play the role of a color $D+1$. The purely connected ones (left) coincide in the two situations (Fig. 6), but the others (right) are considered only in the mixed case.

At this level it is just a partition of the melonic connected graphs with $D+1$ colors into two classes, according to whether the deletion of all the edges of color $D+1$ disconnects the graph or not. In Sec. 6.5, we will treat more generally mixed random tensors that scale like a Wishart tensor (without assuming that they derive from a pure tensor with $D+1$ indices). In that case, there is a difference between the invariants that characterize the asymptotic distributions in the pure and mixed cases, see Fig. 7.

# 6 Free cumulants of unitarily invariant random tensors 

In this section, we define and discuss first order free cumulants in two situations: pure random tensors that scale like a pure complex Gaussian, and mixed random tensors that scale like a Wishart tensor.

### 6.1 Free cumulants for pure Gaussian tensors

We start from the example of a pure complex Gaussian tensor with covariance $\mathbb{E}\left[T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D}} \bar{T}_{\bar{j}^{1} \ldots \bar{j}^{D}}\right]=$ $N^{1-D} C \prod_{i=1}^{D} \delta_{\bar{i}^{c} \cdot \bar{j}^{c}}$. One then has for the two-tensors invariant $T \cdot \bar{T}$ (left of Fig. 5), the only element of $S_{1}^{D}$, which we denote by $\mathbf{i d}_{1}$ :

$$
\Phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}[T, \bar{T}]=\mathbb{E}[T \cdot \bar{T}]=N C
$$

so that the asymptotic covariance is:

$$
\varphi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N} \Phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}[T, \bar{T}]=C
$$

In the case discussed in Thm. 5.8 of an asymptotically Gaussian random tensor model for instance, one would have $C=G$.

Free cumulants. In the Gaussian case, the moment-generating function is simply:

$$
\log Z_{T, \bar{T}}(J, \bar{J})=\log \mathbb{E}_{T, \bar{T}}\left[e^{J \cdot T+\bar{J} \cdot \bar{T}}\right]=C N^{1-D} J \cdot \bar{J}=C N^{1-D} \operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}(J, \bar{J})
$$

hence the only finite $N$ free cumulant is $\mathcal{K}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}[T, \bar{T}]$, and the only non-trivial asymptotic free cumulant is:

$$
\kappa_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{1-D}} \mathcal{K}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}[T, \bar{T}]=C
$$

The corresponding free cumulants can be generally expressed in terms of the asymptotic moments by:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=\varphi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}} \times \delta_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathbf{i d}_{1}}
$$

and (5.6) gives the inverse relation, that is, the asymptotic moments are expressed in terms of the free cumulants through the relation:

$$
\forall \boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}, \quad \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=\operatorname{Card}\left\{\eta \mid K_{\mathrm{p}}(\eta, \boldsymbol{\sigma})=1 \text { and } \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta) \text { minimal }\right\} \times\left(\kappa_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\right)^{n}
$$

In particular for $D \geqslant 3$, the cardinal is just 1 if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected and melonic, see Thm. 5.5, therefore one has:

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma} \mid K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1}=\left(\kappa_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\right)^{n}
$$

Remark 6.1. This is to be compared with the $D=2$ result, for which (6.6) still holds but for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}=\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right)$ with $\#\left(\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2}^{-1}\right)=1$, the number of $\eta$ which minimize $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$ is the Catalan number $(2.4):$

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=C_{n} \times\left(\kappa_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\right)^{n}
$$

The notion of cumulant depends on whether we consider a pure complex tensor $T, \bar{T}$ with $D=2$, or a (mixed) Wishart matrix $W=T T^{\dagger}$ in $D=1$. The cumulants in the two cases are related by:

$$
\kappa_{n}(w)=\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\gamma_{n}, \gamma_{n}\right),\left(\gamma_{n}, \gamma_{n}\right)}(t, \bar{t})
$$

which agree since the pure connected components of $(\sigma, \sigma)$ are a collection of invariants in $S_{1}^{2}$. More generally $\kappa_{\Pi(\sigma), \sigma}(w)=\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\sigma, \sigma),(\sigma, \sigma)}(t, \bar{t})$.

# 6.2 Free cumulants for pure unitarily invariant random tensors 

Our aim is to identify the correct notion of tensorial free-cumulants associated to the first order moments $\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]$ for LU-invariant pure random tensors $T, \bar{T}$ whose classical cumulants scale with the Gaussian scaling function (5.5), that is:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t}), \quad r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=n-\min _{\eta \in S_{n}, K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1} d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)
$$

We do not assume anything regarding the asymptotic moments $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})$ : they are an unspecified list of numbers that characterize the distribution asymptotically. This includes the pure complex Gaussian case and some Gaussian measures perturbed by invariant potentials, but the results derived here are a priori more general.

Our starting point is Thm. 4.10, namely the formula of the finite $N$ free cumulant:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n, \mathrm{p}}^{D}} \sum_{\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n})} \lambda_{\Pi} \prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{[B}}(T, \bar{T})\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c|_{B}} \tau_{c|_{B}}^{-1}\right)
$$

supplemented by the finite $N$ moment cumulant expressions for $\Pi \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau})$ :

$$
\prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{[B}}(T, \bar{T})\right]=\sum_{\substack{\Pi^{\prime} \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n}) \\ \Pi \geqslant \Pi^{\prime} \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau})}} \prod_{G^{\prime}=B^{\prime} \cup \bar{B}^{\prime} \in \Pi^{\prime}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{[B^{\prime}}}[T, \bar{T}]
$$

and the asymptotic of the Weingarten function $W^{(N)}(\nu)=\mathrm{M}(\nu) N^{-n-|\nu|}\left(1+O\left(N^{-2}\right)\right)$ for $\nu \in S_{n}$.
Limit of first order finite size free cumulants. As discussed in Section 5.3, the first order consists of the purely connected melonic trace-invariants.

In order to state the appropriate moment cumulant relation at first order, we recall that $\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}$ means that for all $c \in\{1, \ldots, D\}, \tau_{c} \leq \sigma_{c}$, that is, for each cycle of $\sigma_{c}$, the restriction of $\tau_{c}$ to the support of this cycle is a non-crossing permutation. Also, for $\boldsymbol{\nu} \in S_{n}^{D}$, we define $\mathrm{M}(\boldsymbol{\nu})=\prod_{c=1}^{D} \mathrm{M}\left(\nu_{c}\right)$, where $\mathrm{M}(\nu)$ is the Möbius function on the lattice of non-crossing partitions. Denoting $\mathrm{NC}(n)$ the lattice of non-crossing partitions on $n$ elements, $\mathrm{M}(\boldsymbol{\nu})$ is the Möbius function on the direct product of $\operatorname{lattices}(\mathrm{NC}(n))^{\times D}$, which is itself a lattice.
Theorem 6.2. Let $D \geqslant 3$ and let $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ be a melonic purely connected invariant, $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=0$ and $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1$, and let $\eta \in S_{n}$ be the permutation defined by the canonical pairs of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. Consider a pure random tensor $T, \bar{T}$ whose classical cumulants scale as in (6.10). Then the finite size free cumulant $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]$ scales as $N^{1-n D}$ and:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-1} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D} \\ \boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}(t, \bar{t}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

In particular the $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ s in the sum are melonic but not necessarily purely connected, and $\eta$ is the canonical pairing on $\boldsymbol{\tau}$.

Proof. The proof is presented in Sec. B.1.
In order to gain some intuition on the $\boldsymbol{\tau} \mathrm{s}$ contributing to this sum, we consider a melonic graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with canonical pairing given by the identity (that is, the graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$ in the previous theorem): due to the composition by $\eta^{-1}$, the non-labeled graphs $[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{p}}$ in the sum are the same for any choice of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ in a given class $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{p}}$, so we may make this choice.

For any color $c$, the permutation $\sigma_{c}$ consists in disjoint cycles which correspond to the cycles in the graph formed alternatively of canonical pairs and edges of color $c$, and for each such cycle, one independently considers all the possible non-crossing permutations. If the cycle is a fixed-point, that is, if an edge of color $c$ connects the two vertices of a canonical pair, then this edge remains unchanged in all the $\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}$. Otherwise, one may generate all the $\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}$ by a sequence of flips of edges that belong to cycles of length greater than one, where a flip of two edges consists in exchanging the white vertices to which they are connected. See Fig. 8, where all the $[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{p}} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{\mathrm{p}}$ in the sum are represented for the example of Fig. 6.

The labeling is not indicated, as the same diagrams are obtained regardless of the labeling of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. If the labeling is such that the canonical pairing is the identity, then these diagrams correspond to the $\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}$.

The theorem generalizes trivially for $n$ pure random tensors. We consider some pure random tensors $\left(T_{a}, \vec{T}_{a}\right),\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right)$ and so on, with bipartite joint distribution, and we denote $\vec{X}=$ $\left(X_{1}, \ldots X_{n}\right)$ with $X_{s} \in\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\vec{X}^{\prime}=\left(X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots X_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ with $X_{s}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$. For $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}$ and $\Pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})$, we define:

$$
\Phi_{\Pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}\left[\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}\right]=\prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} k_{K_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\tau_{\mid \bar{B}}\right)}\left(\operatorname{Tr}_{\tau_{\mid \bar{B}}}\left(\left\{X_{s}\right\}_{s \in B},\left\{X_{s}^{\prime}\right\}_{s \in \bar{B}}\right)\right)
$$

where $B$ collects the labels of the white vertices, and $\bar{B}=\tau(B)$ the ones of the black vertices. We denote by $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}\right]$ the appropriate generalization of the pure cumulants in (4.29) to $n$ pairs of tensors, and assuming that the generalized scaling ansatz:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}\right]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)
$$

holds ${ }^{25}$, then Thm. 6.2 goes through, thus defining $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)$. If for all $n \geqslant 1$ and $s \in\{1, \ldots, n\}$, $X_{s}$ and $X_{s}^{\prime}$ are drawn independently from a set of complex pairs (or a bipartite distribution), then $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)$ define the joint distribution of the pairs.

Note that using pure cumulants with pairs $\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right)$, as we do here, or mixed cumulants with substitutions $A_{a}=T_{a} \otimes \bar{T}_{a}$ in these scaling assumptions, leads to different objects and scaling assumptions. Indeed, in the second case, one considers only trace-invariants in which the tensors $X_{s}$ and $X_{s}^{\prime}$ belong to the same pair: if $X_{s}=T_{a}$ for instance, then one must have $X_{s}^{\prime}=\bar{T}_{a}$. As an example, consider the invariant $\boldsymbol{\tau}=\mathbf{i d}_{1} \cup \mathbf{i d}_{1}$ consisting in the disjoint union of two two-vertices invariants, and two pairs $\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right)$ and $\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right)$ then:

- with pure invariants (as we chose to do here), one makes scaling assumptions on the four combinations:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left[T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right], \quad \operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left[T_{a}, \bar{T}_{b}\right], \quad \operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left[T_{b}, \bar{T}_{a}\right], \quad \operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left[T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right]
$$

- with mixed invariants, but substituting $A=T \otimes \bar{T}$, one only obtains the two combinations:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left[T_{a} \otimes \bar{T}_{a}\right]=\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left[T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right], \quad \operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left[T_{b} \otimes \bar{T}_{b}\right]=\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left[T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right]
$$

Properties of first order free cumulants. Free-cumulants for arbitrary melonic invariants are defined as multiplicative extensions. The following theorem (proven in Sec. B.2) is analogous to Prop. 11.4 of [1]. Since $\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}(t, \bar{t})=\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}), \boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}}(t, \bar{t})$, the sum defining $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})$ in Thm. 6.2 is independent on the choice of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ in $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{p}}$, so that for simplicity we fix the labeling to be such that the canonical pairing is the identity: $\eta=\mathrm{id}$.
Theorem 6.3. Let $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{\alpha}^{O}$ be a melonic trace-invariant $(\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=0)$, labeled to set the canonical pairing to be the identity. We denote $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}^{\mathrm{H}}$ its pure connected components and we define:

$$
\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

where $\vec{x}=\left(x_{1}, \ldots x_{n}\right), x_{i} \in\left\{t_{a}, t_{b}, \ldots\right\}, \vec{x}^{\prime}=\left(x_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots x_{n}^{\prime}\right), x_{i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{t}_{a}, \bar{t}_{b}, \ldots\right\}$, and $\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)=$ $\prod_{i=1}^{q} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}^{\mathrm{H}}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)$. Then:

- Each $\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is itself melonic, with canonical pairing the identity.
- The family $\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)$ is the multiplicative extension of the family $\left\{\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right) \mid K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\right.$ $1, \omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=0\}$ defined in Thm. 6.2 :

$$
\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)=\prod_{i=1}^{q} \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}^{\mathrm{H}}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)
$$

- If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected and melonic and if $\left(T_{1}, \bar{T}_{1}\right)$ and $\left(T_{2}, \bar{T}_{2}\right)$ are independent and scale as (6.15), then $\left(T_{1}+T_{2}, \bar{T}_{1}+\bar{T}_{2}\right)$ scales as (6.10), and:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(t_{1}+t_{2}, \bar{t}_{1}+\bar{t}_{2}\right)=\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(t_{1}, \bar{t}_{1}\right)+\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(t_{2}, \bar{t}_{2}\right)
$$

- The defining relation (6.16) can be inverted, so that for any melonic $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with canonical pairing the identity:

$$
\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}} \kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)
$$

so that the data $\left\{\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right) \mid K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1, \omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=0\right\}$ is equivalent to $\left\{\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right) \mid K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\right.$ $1, \omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=0\}$. This together with (6.17) can be taken as an alternative definition of melonic free-cumulants.
that case, the scaling is saturated if among the Wick pairings $\eta$ contributing at first order, there exists some such that for all $s, X_{s}$ and $X_{s(\bar{s})}^{\prime}$ are all of the same type $T_{1}, \bar{T}_{1}$ or $T_{2}, \bar{T}_{2}$, and if not the moment is suppressed in scaling $\left(\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)\right.$ vanishes $)$.

For a Gaussian complex tensor $T, \bar{T}$, we have $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=C \delta_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathbf{i d}_{1}}$ and, with the notations of the theorem, the only non-zero term in the sum (6.19) is $\boldsymbol{\tau}=\mathbf{i d}_{n}=(\mathrm{id}, \ldots, \mathrm{id}) \in S_{n}^{D}$ (the melonic invariant consisting of $n$ disjoint two-vertex graphs whose canonical pairing is the identity), that is:

$$
\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathbf{i d}_{n}\right), \mathbf{i d}_{n}}(t, \bar{t})
$$

and one recovers $(6.8)$.
For $D=1$, the free cumulants of the square Wishart random matrix (3.18) are $\kappa_{n}(w)=1$, and those of the GUE random matrix are $\kappa_{n}(m)=\delta_{n, 2}$. Both lead to similar combinatorics, in the sense that the associated asymptotic moments enumerate graphs embedded on the 2 -sphere in the same combinatorial universality classes. For the pure $D>1$ case treated here this is no longer the case: as explained above, choosing $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=1$ for purely connected melonic invariants leads to richer combinatorics (6.19) in comparison to the choice $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=\delta_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathbf{i d}_{1}}$, which leads to $(6.20)$.

The choice $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=1$ is quite natural and generalizes the square Wishart distribution, albeit in a different sense from what we will discuss below in Sec. 6.5. If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected and melonic, with canonical pairing the identity, and if for each $c$, the partition $\Lambda\left(\sigma_{c}\right) \vdash n$ has parts $\lambda_{c}^{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{c}^{k_{c}}$, with $k_{c}=\#\left(\sigma_{c}\right)$ :

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=\prod_{c=1}^{D} \prod_{i=1}^{k_{c}} C_{\lambda_{c, i}}
$$

to be compared with the Catalan number for $D=1(6.8)$.

# 6.3 A first glimpse at purely connected higher orders 

Non-melonic purely connected invariants are higher-order free cumulants as they are more suppressed than their melonic counterparts in the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$. This is new with respect to matrices, for which the order of dominance is given only by the number of pure connected components.

In the proof of Thm. 6.2 we have obtained (see B. 4 and subsequent) the general formula for a finite $N$ free cumulant associated to a purely connected invariant:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\frac{1}{N^{n D}} \sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}} \sum_{\pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})}\left[\varphi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}(t, \bar{t}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right) N^{r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-\Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})}+o\left(N^{r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-\Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})}\right)\right]
$$

where $\Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau}) \geqslant 0$. Furthermore, we have shown that $\Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})=0$ if and only if:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})+\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}} d(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \eta)=\min _{\eta_{0} \in S_{n}} d\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta_{0}\right) \\
& H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}=\left\{\eta \in S_{n} \mid \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\eta) \leqslant \pi \quad \text { and } \quad \forall B \in \pi, K_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{l B}, \eta_{l B}\right)=1\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

and that $\Delta_{1_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\sigma})=0$, that is the condition is always satisfied at least for $\boldsymbol{\tau}=\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ and $\pi=1_{n}$ (the one-block partition). We denote the set of terms that dominate by:

$$
\mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\left\{(\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}) \mid \pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}) \text { and } \Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})=0\right\}
$$

Proposition 6.4. Let $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}, D \geqslant 1$, be purely connected. Consider a pure random tensor whose cumulants scale as (6.10). Then the finite size free cumulant $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]$ scales as $N^{r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-n D}$, where $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=n-\min _{\eta \in S_{n}} d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$, and:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\sum_{(\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}) \in \mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})} \varphi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}(t, \bar{t}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

We note that if there exists a $\tilde{\eta} \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\tau}}$ for which both $d(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \tilde{\eta})=\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}, \boldsymbol{\tau}} d(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \eta)$ and $d(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \tilde{\eta})=\min _{\eta_{0} \in S_{n}} d\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta_{0}\right)$, that is $d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})+d(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \tilde{\eta})=d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \tilde{\eta})$, then $\boldsymbol{\tau} \tilde{\eta}^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \tilde{\eta}^{-1}$, and in this case the cumulant involves a sum in a lattice and the relation can be inverted using Möbius inversion. However, at this point, it is not clear if such a permutation always exist, or how to organize $\mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ as a lattice in general.

The condition (6.22) can be written in a form adapted to compatible invariants discussed in Section 5.2. We first reformulate the (5.10) as:

$$
d(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \eta)=\frac{1}{D-1}\left(\nabla(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \eta)+\sum_{1 \leqslant c_{1}<c_{2} \leqslant D}\left|\tau_{c_{1}} \tau_{c_{2}}^{-1}\right|\right)
$$

On the other hand, we define:

$$
\nabla^{(2)}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})=\sum_{1 \leqslant c_{1}<c_{2} \leqslant D}\left(\left|\sigma_{c_{1}} \tau_{c_{1}}^{-1}\right|+\left|\tau_{c_{1}} \tau_{c_{2}}^{-1}\right|+\left|\tau_{c_{2}} \sigma_{c_{2}}^{-1}\right|-\left|\sigma_{c_{1}} \sigma_{c_{2}}^{-1}\right|\right) \geqslant 0
$$

and with the help of these two relations we express: ${ }^{26}$

$$
\nabla^{(2)}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})+\nabla(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \eta)=\nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)+(D-1)[d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})+d(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \eta)-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)]
$$

We conclude that the set $\mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ is also the set of pairs $(\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau})$ such that $\pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and:

$$
\nabla^{(2)}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})+\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\tau}}} \nabla(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \eta)=\min _{\eta_{0} \in S_{n}} \nabla\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta_{0}\right)
$$

Assuming that $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is compatible, this condition becomes $\nabla^{(2)}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})=\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}, \boldsymbol{\tau}} \nabla(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \eta)=0$. On the other hand, we also have that if $\nabla^{(2)}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})=0$, then $\eta$ renders $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ compatible if and only if it renders $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ compatible and moreover it is such that $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$.

This allows defining equivalently $\mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ as the set of pairs $(\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau})$ such that $\pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and there exists $\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\tau}}$ which renders $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ compatible and is such that $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$. At this point, in order to proceed, we would need to determine whether it is possible for a $\pi>\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})$ to contribute to the dominant contribution. We posit that this is not the case.
Conjecture 6.5. Consider $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}$. Then any $\eta \in S_{n}$ satisfying $\nabla(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \eta)=0$ is such that $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\eta) \leqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})$, that is, $\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})}$.

It is straightforward to prove that if the Gaussian scaling is subadditive then this conjecture holds, that is Conjecture 5.1 implies the present conjecture.

Assuming this conjecture, ${ }^{27}$ then the cumulants of purely connected invariants in Proposition 6.4 become for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ compatible:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\sum_{\substack{\eta \in S_{n} \\ \nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=0}} \sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D} \\ \boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}(t, \bar{t}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

This is a sum which can be inverted. In particular, if there is a unique $\eta$ such that $\nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=0$ then, choosing the labeling of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ so that this $\eta$ is the identity, we have:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}(t, \bar{t}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

Using the methods of [69] one should be able to build infinite families of compatible traceinvariants $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ of fixed degree $\omega$ and which each have a single $\eta$ for which $\nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=0$. We can conjecturally generalize Thm. 6.3 to this subclass of compatible invariants.

    ${ }^{27}$ And assuming that if several permutations $\eta$ render $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ compatible then the families of invariants such that $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$ are disjoint, which is a weak assumption view that one expects usually at most one such $\eta$ to exist.

Theorem 6.6. If Conj. 6.5 holds, then the finite size free cumulants of a purely connected compatible invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with a unique $\eta \in S_{n}$ satisfying $\nabla(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=0$ scale like $N^{1-\frac{\omega(\sigma)}{D-1}-n D}$ and:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t}):=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-1+\frac{\omega(\sigma)}{D-1}} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\sum_{\substack{\tau \in S_{n}^{D} \\ \tau \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}(t, \bar{t}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

Furthermore, Thm. 6.3 can be generalized immediately to this case.

# 6.4 Mixed perspective on the pure case 

At the end of Sec. 4.2.2, we discussed the difference at the level of finite $N$ free cumulants between pure random tensors $T, \bar{T}$ and the mixed quantity $T \otimes \bar{T}$ : for any $\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(T, \bar{T})\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(T \otimes \bar{T})\right]$ so that for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ purely connected, $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[T \otimes \bar{T}](4.31)$, and if in addition $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is melonic, $N^{n D-1} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[T \otimes \bar{T}]$ converges towards $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(t \otimes \bar{t})=\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})$. For $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ connected $\left(K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1\right)$ but not purely connected $\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})>1\right)$, one generally has $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}] \neq \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[T \otimes \bar{T}]$, as in the mixed case one still has:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[T \otimes \bar{T}]=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(T, \bar{T})\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}\right)
$$

while $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]$ involves an additional sum over partitions (4.29). In fact (the proof is in Sec. B.3):
Lemma 6.7. Let $D \geqslant 3, \boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ be melonic, connected but not purely connected. Let $\eta$ be the canonical pairing of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. Consider $T, \bar{T}$ satisfying (6.10). Then:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(t \otimes \bar{t})=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[T \otimes \bar{T}]=\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})
$$

Considering now $T_{1}, \bar{T}_{1}$ and $T_{2}, \bar{T}_{2}$ two independent LU-invariant pure random tensors, in general $\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}\left(T_{1}+T_{2}, \bar{T}_{1}+\bar{T}_{2}\right)\right] \neq \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}\left(T_{1} \otimes \bar{T}_{1}+\bar{T}_{2} \otimes \bar{T}_{2}\right)\right]$ (see the discussion below (6.15)) and therefore $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[T_{1}+T_{2}, \bar{T}_{1}+\bar{T}_{2}\right] \neq \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[T_{1} \otimes \bar{T}_{1}+T_{2} \otimes \bar{T}_{2}\right]$, even for purely connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. However, from Prop. 4.9 and Thm. 4.10, one has equality for $N$ sufficiently large and purely connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ : $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[T_{1} \otimes \bar{T}_{1}+T_{2} \otimes \bar{T}_{2}\right]=\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[T_{1} \otimes \bar{T}_{1}\right]+\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[T_{2} \otimes \bar{T}_{2}\right]=\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[T_{1}, \bar{T}_{1}\right]+\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[T_{2}, \bar{T}_{2}\right]=\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[T_{1}+T_{2}, \bar{T}_{1}+\bar{T}_{2}\right]$, so that their rescaled limits coincide.
Theorem 6.8. Let $D \geqslant 3, \boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ be melonic $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=0$, purely connected $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1$, and labeled such that its canonical pairing is the identity. Let $T_{1}, \bar{T}_{1}$ and $T_{2}, \bar{T}_{2}$ be two independent LUinvariant pure random tensors satisfying (6.15), and define the mixed tensor $A=T_{1} \otimes \bar{T}_{1}+T_{2} \otimes \bar{T}_{2}$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-1} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D} \\
\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left(a\right) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right) \\
& \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D} \\
\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}}} \kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)
\end{aligned}
$$

where for $\boldsymbol{\nu}$ purely connected and melonic, $\varphi_{\nu}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\lim _{\rightarrow \infty} \Phi_{\nu}^{\mathrm{m}}[A] / N<\infty$. In particular, $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(t_{1}+t_{2}, \bar{t}_{1}+\bar{t}_{2}\right)$ and $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(t_{1}+t_{2}, \bar{t}_{1}+\bar{t}_{2}\right)$. As a consequence,

$$
\sum_{\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime} \text { s.t. } \vec{x}^{\prime} \neq \vec{x}} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)=0
$$

where $\vec{x}=\left(x_{1}, \ldots x_{n}\right), x_{i} \in\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}\right\}, \vec{x}^{\prime}=\left(x_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots x_{n}^{\prime}\right), x_{i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{t}_{1}, \bar{t}_{2}\right\}$, such that not $x_{i}^{\prime} \neq \overline{x_{i}}$ for at least one canonical pair $1 \leqslant i \leqslant n$.

Proof. The theorem is proven in Sec. B.4.
A consequence of (6.36) is that if the quantities in the sum are non-negative they must vanish, so that in that case the corresponding $\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}\right]$ all have a scale lower than $N^{r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}$ in (6.15). This generalizes a known result for the Gaussian case, see Footnote 25. The condition $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}\right)=0$ for $\overrightarrow{x^{\prime}} \neq \vec{x}$ is one of the conditions for tensor freeness, see Thm. 7.6 in Sec. 7.

# 6.5 Mixed random tensors that scale like a Wishart tensor 

In this section, we will discuss the case when our random tensor is mixed rather than pure. As scaling assumption, we will consider mixed random tensors $A$ that scales like the square Wishart random tensor of Section 5.5, that is we assume that for $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ :

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a), \quad r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=n-\min d((\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}), \eta)
$$

where the minimum is taken over $\eta \in S_{n}$ for which $K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)=1$. Note that $d((\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}), \eta)=$ $d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)+|\eta|$ and also $r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=r(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ with $r$ the Gaussian scaling function in (5.7).

For the version of the theorem that involves different tensors, one must make the following stronger assumption for any $\vec{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ :

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[\vec{A}]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a})
$$

This includes the case where there exists a LU-invariant pure random tensor $T, T^{\prime}$ with $D+1$ indices, not necessarily the pure complex Gaussian itself, but displaying Gaussian scaling (6.10), and $A$ is:

$$
A_{i 1 \ldots i^{D} ; j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}=\sum_{k=1}^{N} T_{i 1 \ldots i^{D} k} T_{j^{1} \ldots j^{D} k^{\prime}}^{i}
$$

For this case the results discussed here are to be compared to the pure case with one additional color (see Sec. 5.5), and we review this comparison at the end of this subsection.

For the general case of a mixed tensor $A$ with scaling function $r_{W}$, the thick edges cannot a priori be seen simply as an additional color. In order to understand this, let us first study the free moment-cumulant relations for the first order moments $\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$, corresponding to a melonic connected invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ such that $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic (see Sec. 5.5).
Theorem 6.9. Let $D \geqslant 2, \boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ be connected and such that $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$ (which implies that $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is melonic) and let $\eta \in S_{n}$ be the canonical pairing of $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$. Consider some mixed random tensors $A_{1}, A_{2}, \ldots$ that scale as in (6.37), and satisfy (6.38). Then the limit of the mixed finite size free cumulant associated to $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a}):=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-1} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[\vec{A}]=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}} \varphi_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

and each $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ in the sum is such that $(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic with canonical pairing $\eta$. Furthermore:

- If $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ are independent and scale as in (6.37), then $A=A_{1}+A_{2}$ scales as in (6.37), and $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left(a_{1}\right)+\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left(a_{2}\right)$.
- The relation can be inverted. With the notations above:

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a})=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}} \kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a})
$$

Proof. The proof can be found Section B.5.
In the general mixed case one cannot treat the thick edges (the identity) as an additional color because the inverse relation (6.41) does not include a sum over permutations $\tau_{D+1}$ such that $\tau_{D+1} \eta^{-1} \leq \eta^{-1}$, as one would have in the pure case with one additional color. See the examples in Fig. 9
![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)

Figure 9: A $\sigma$ which is connected but not purely connected and such that $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic (upper left), with canonical pairing given by the blue blobs, and all the $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ such that $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$. The labeling is not indicated, as the same diagrams are obtained regardless of the labeling of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$.

The inverse relation (6.41) simplifies if the connected components of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ are purely connected, as then the canonical pairing on $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is $\eta=\mathrm{id}$, to:

$$
\varphi_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}} \kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)
$$

that is one recovers the formula from the pure case with $D$ indices with canonical pairing $\eta=\mathrm{id}$ (6.19), since for any $\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}, \Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau})$ and $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})$ coincide. Thus for the purely-connected melonic invariants, which are first order in both situations, nothing distinguishes a pure distribution with $D$ indices with Gaussian scaling function $r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ from a mixed distribution with scaling function $r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=r(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$. The difference between the two comes from the fact that there are more first order invariants in the mixed case, namely those which are connected but not purely connected (Fig. 7)

Observe that there are invariants for which $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$ forces $\boldsymbol{\tau}=\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. This is for instance the case for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ melonic with all $\sigma_{c}$ equal. For such invariants the asymptotic moment equals the free cumulant, and it is additive. This phenomenon is specific to the tensor case and does not arise for matrices.

If $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=1$ for the first order $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ (connected and $(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic) and we pick a connected melonic invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{\alpha}^{D}$ with $\eta=\mathrm{id}$ (in which case $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected) then $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)$ is given by the same product of Catalan numbers as in (6.21).

Higher orders. Prop. 6.4 which deals with the higher order in the pure case also generalizes with obvious modifications to the mixed one. In particular, for connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$ scales as:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]_{\mid K_{\mathrm{m}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1}}=N^{r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-\mathrm{n} D}
$$

which is consistent with (3.27) for $D=1$.

The mixed and Wishart point of vue on the pure case. For the genuine Wishart like case, we have the following.
Proposition 6.10. Let $A_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} \ldots j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}=\sum_{k=1}^{N} T_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} k} \bar{T}_{j^{1} \ldots j^{D} k}, D \geqslant 2$, for some pure random tensor $T, \bar{T}$ with $D+1$ indices with Gaussian scaling (6.10). Let $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ be such that ( $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}$ ) is melonic with canonical pairing $\eta$. Then the pure free cumulants of $T, \bar{T}$ and the mixed free cumulants of $A$ are related by:

$$
\kappa_{\Pi_{\rho}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}),(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})}(t, \bar{t})=\sum_{\substack{\nu \in S_{n} \\ \nu \eta^{-1} \leq \eta^{-1}}} \kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \nu^{-1}), \boldsymbol{\sigma} \nu^{-1}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a) \mathrm{M}(\nu)
$$

where the permutation $\nu$ encodes a change of the thick edges representing the tensors $A .{ }^{28}$ Conversely:

$$
\kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\sum_{\substack{\nu \in S_{n} \\ \nu \eta^{-1} \leq \eta^{-1}}} \kappa_{\Pi_{\rho}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \nu),(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \nu)}(t, \bar{t})
$$

If $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected, $\eta=\mathrm{id}$ and $\kappa_{(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})}(t, \bar{t})=\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)$.
Proof. See Section B.6.
![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)

Figure 10: Examples of contributions to the right-hand side of (6.44) for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ as on the upper left of Fig. 9: the new permutation $\nu$ represents a modification of the thick edges (see Footnote 28).

In particular, if $T$ is a pure Gaussian with $D+1$ indices, $D \geqslant 2$, and $A$ is as in (6.39), we have from (6.5) that $\kappa_{\Pi_{\rho}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \nu),(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \nu)}(t, \bar{t})=\delta_{(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \nu),(\eta, \ldots, \eta)}$ where $\eta$ is the canonical pairing of $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$. Inserting this into (6.45) for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ connected with $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic, we see that the right-hand side is zero unless $\boldsymbol{\sigma}=(\eta, \ldots, \eta) \in S_{n}^{D}$ and $\nu=\eta$. For $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ to be connected, $\eta$ must therefore be a cycle of length $n$. We find for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ connected with $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic that:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(w)=\delta_{\boldsymbol{\sigma},(\eta, \ldots, \eta)}
$$

where $\eta$ is a cycle of length $n$, and more generally if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is not necessarily connected that $\kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(w)=\delta_{\boldsymbol{\sigma},(\eta, \ldots, \eta)}$, without condition on $\eta$. This is different from the case of a pure complex Gaussian with two indices (a random matrix) (6.5), but it directly generalize the result for the $D=1$ Wishart matrix (6.9). However, for $D \geqslant 2$, applying (6.41) leads for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ connected with $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic to:

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(w)=1
$$

as expected, since again $\boldsymbol{\tau}=(\eta, \ldots, \eta)$ is the only non-vanishing term in the sum (6.41).

# 7 Asymptotic tensor freeness
### 7.1 Matrix freeness

Let us first review the notion of freeness adapted to unitarily invariant random matrices $A, B \in$ $\mathcal{M}_{N}(\mathbb{C})[60,62]$. If $M=\left(M_{1}, \ldots, M_{n}\right) \in\{A, B\}^{n}$ and defining $\kappa_{n}\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$ where $m_{i} \in\{a, b\}$, $A, B$ are asymptotically free if and only if for all $n \geqslant 2$ :

$$
\kappa_{n}\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)=0
$$

whenever there exist $1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$. For matrices, one can make sense of $a, b$ as being non-commutative random variables, that is, elements of a non-commutative probability space defined as an algebra $\mathcal{A}$ with a unit element 1 , together with a linear functional $\varphi: \mathcal{A} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$, that maps the unit element to 1 . The family $\varphi\left(a^{n}\right), n \geqslant 1$ are the moments of $a$. For a single variable $a$ this relates for $n \geqslant 1$ to $\varphi_{n}$ defined before as $\varphi\left(a^{n}\right)=\varphi_{n}(a)$ where $a^{n} \in \mathcal{A}$. $\varphi$ corresponds asymptotically to " $\frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}[\operatorname{Tr}(\cdot)]$ ". A random matrix $A$ converges in distribution towards $a$ when $N \rightarrow \infty$ if for all $n \in \mathbb{N}^{\star}, \frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{n}\right)\right] \rightarrow \varphi\left(a^{n}\right)$, and the statement above for the asymptotic freeness of $A, B$ directly refers to the freeness of the non-commutative random variables $a$ and $b$.

Freeness is equivalent to the vanishing of mixed centered moments (the original formulation [60]), that is, for any $n \geqslant 2$, for any $\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$ with $m_{i} \in\{a, b\}$ (or some finite fixed set of elements of $\mathcal{A}$ ), and any $g_{i}$ in the subalgebra generated by 1 and $m_{i}$ :

$$
\varphi\left(g_{1} \cdots g_{n}\right)=0
$$

whenever $\varphi\left(g_{i}\right)=0$ for all $g_{i}$, and $g_{1} \cdots g_{n}$ are almost alternating ${ }^{29}$, that is, $g_{i}$ and $g_{i+1}$ belong to two different subalgebras. Since the variables can be centered, for two variables $a, b$, this is equivalent to requiring that for all $k \geqslant 1$ and all $n_{1}, \ldots, n_{k} \geqslant 1, m_{1} \geqslant 1$, if $k \geqslant 2 m_{k} \geqslant 0$, and if $k \geqslant 3 m_{2} \ldots, m_{k-1} \geqslant 1$ :

$$
\varphi\left(\left(a^{n_{1}}-\varphi\left(a^{n_{1}}\right) 1\right)\left(b^{m_{1}}-\varphi\left(b^{m_{1}}\right) 1\right) \cdots\left(a^{n_{k}}-\varphi\left(a^{n_{k}}\right) 1\right)\left(b^{m_{k}}-\varphi\left(b^{m_{k}}\right) 1\right)\right)=0
$$

### 7.2 Asymptotic tensor freeness at the level of free cumulants

Having defined free cumulants of pure and mixed random tensors, we define asymptotic (first order) tensor freeness of a collection of random tensors as the vanishing of $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}$ involving different elements ${ }^{30}$ for any first order $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. More precisely:

- For mixed tensors $A, B, \ldots$ that scale like the Wishart tensor (6.37) and (6.38), $D \geqslant 2$, the first order consists of the connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}, n \geqslant 1$, such that $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$. This constrains the thick edges as follows: in the graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$, any cycle of alternated thick edges and canonical pairs that involves more than one thick edge must be separating (Fig. 7). $A, B, \ldots$ are asymptotically free if for any such $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ and any $\vec{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$ with $m_{i} \in\{a, b, \ldots\}$ :

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0
$$

whenever $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$ for some $i \neq j$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{29}$ The elements $g_{1} \cdots g_{n}$ are strictly alternating if $g_{1}$ and $g_{n}$ belong to different subalgebras.
    ${ }^{30}$ Called mixed cumulants, not to be confused with the term "mixed" for a tensor, which comes from the quantum information interpretation of LU-invariant distributions as distributions over quantum states.

- For pure tensors, $\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right),\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right) \ldots$ that scale like a complex Gaussian (6.10) and (6.15), $D \geqslant 3$, the first order consists of the purely connected and melonic $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}, n \geqslant 1$. We require that $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ be labeled such that its canonical pairing $\eta$ is the identity and consider for $1 \leqslant i \leqslant n, \vec{X}=\left(X_{1}, \ldots X_{n}\right)$ and $\vec{X}^{\prime}=\left(X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots X_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ with $X_{i} \in\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $X_{s}^{\prime} \in$ $\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$. Note that we allow $X_{s}^{\prime} \neq X_{s}$, that is, one could have $X_{s}=T_{a}$ and $X_{s}^{\prime}=\bar{T}_{b}$. In that case, $\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right),\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right) \ldots$ are asymptotically free if:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)=0
$$

whenever $x_{i} \neq x_{j}$ or $x_{i}^{\prime} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$, or $\overline{x_{i}} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$ for some $i, j$.
In the pure case, if there exists $\eta^{-1}$ such that for each $s, X_{\eta^{-1}(s)}^{\prime}=\overline{X_{s}}$, then by changing the labeling of the white vertices one may replace $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ by $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta$, setting $X_{s}^{\prime}=\overline{X_{s}}$ with now $\eta$ defining the canonical pairing. After this change of labeling, the black and white vertices can be seen as representing the inputs and the outputs of the same tensor $X_{s} \otimes \overline{X_{s}}$, and are linked by a thick edge encoded by the permutation id. For $\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}$ satisfying this, the vanishing condition for purely connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with canonical pairing the identity (i.e. with $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \mathrm{id})=0$ ) must be considered in both the pure and mixed cases. On the other hand, the vanishing condition in the pure case for $\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}$ which do not satisfy this condition must be considered only in the pure case, while the vanishing condition for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ such that $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$, connected but not purely, must be considered only in the mixed case.

# 7.3 Paired tensors 

In order to state the definition of matrix freeness at the level of moments (Sec. 7.1), it was necessary to consider elements in the subalgebras $\mathcal{A}[a, 1]$ generated by $a$ and 1 . We let $\mathcal{G}[A]=$ $\left\{A^{n}\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$ : the algebra $\mathcal{A}[A, \mathbb{1}]$ generated by $A$ and $\mathbb{1}$ can also be seen as the set of linear combinations of elements of $\{\mathbb{1}\} \cup \mathcal{G}[A]$. In the tensor case, stating the moments version of tensor freeness will require extending the notions of tensors and trace-invariants. We will introduce here some sets which will generalize the roles of $\mathcal{G}[A]$, of $\mathcal{A}[A, \mathbb{1}]$, and then of $\mathcal{A}[a, 1]$ in Sec. 8 .

Paired tensors. A paired tensor is a tensor with components $P_{\left\{i_{c, r}, j_{c, r}\right\}} \in \mathbb{C}$, where $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$ and $r \in\left\{0, \ldots, k_{c}\right\}, 1 \leqslant i_{c, r}, j_{c, r} \leqslant N$, and where $k_{c} \geqslant 0$ and $\sum_{c=1}^{D} k_{c} \geqslant 1$. There may therefore be no index of color $c$ or there can be several of the same color $c$, in which case the second index $r$ partitions the inputs and outputs of the same color in pairs. We refer to $r$ as the shade: a pair of outputs and inputs $\left(i_{c, r}, j_{c, r}\right)$ has color $c$ and shade $r$. The inputs or outputs of the same color $c$ carrying different shades $r$ are distinguishable. Tensors $A$ or $T \otimes \bar{T}$ considered earlier in the text are paired tensors. If $\mathcal{D}=\sum_{c} k_{c}$, the identity $\mathbb{1}^{\otimes \mathcal{D}}$ of $\mathcal{M}_{N}(\mathbb{C})^{\otimes \mathcal{D}}$ can be viewed as a paired tensor: $\mathbb{1}^{\otimes \mathcal{D}}\left\{i_{c, r}, j_{c, r}\right\}=\prod_{r=1}^{D} \prod_{r=1}^{k_{c}} \delta_{i_{c, r}, j_{c, r}}$.

Trace-invariants of paired tensors. We generalize the notion of trace-invariants for paired tensors. Given $n$ labeled paired tensors $P_{1}, \ldots, P_{n}$, if we represent these tensors by thick edges linking a black and a white vertex, with $k_{c}(i)$ distinguishable half-edges of color $c$ respectively attached to the inputs and the outputs of the tensor $P_{i}$ for each color $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$, then the traceinvariants of these paired tensors are encoded by colored graphs $\mathbf{g}$ with thick edges representing the tensors, and edges of color $c$ representing the index summations. A vertex may now have none or several incident edges for each color $c$. We use the notation $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}}(\vec{P})$. See the example in Fig. 11.

We cannot simply use a single permutation per color as before in order to encode labeled invariants, since here a tensor may now have different pairs of indices of the same color. However,

in the graph there are cycles which go from the output of a tensor which has subscript $\left(c, r_{1}\right)$, through an edge of color $c$, to the intput of a tensor which has subscript $\left(c, r_{2}\right)$, to the output of the same tensor to which it is paired, through an edge of color $c$, etc. If the paired tensors are labeled from 1 to $n$, we thus obtain a set of cycles $\left\{\gamma_{c, b}\right\}$, each of the form $\left(\left[k_{1}, r_{1}\right] \cdots\left[k_{q}, r_{q}\right]\right)$ where $1 \leqslant k_{1}, \ldots, k_{q} \leqslant n$ are the labels of the thick edges (paired tensors) encountered in the cycle (all distinct), and $r_{s}$ is the shade of the pair of output and input of color $c$ of the paired tensor number $k_{s}$ which belongs to the cycle under consideration. The index $b$ labels the different cycles that have the same color $c$. Starting from the collection of labeled paired tensors, one can reconstruct all the colored edges from this data: an output of color $c$ and shade $r$ of a given tensor $k$ appears in only one cycle $\gamma_{c, b_{0}}$ of the $\left\{\gamma_{c, b}\right\}$, and if $\gamma_{c, b_{0}}([k, r])=\left[k^{\prime}, r^{\prime}\right]$, an edge of color $c$ is added between the output of color $c$, shade $r$ of $k$ and the input of color $c$, shade $r^{\prime}$ of $k^{\prime}$.

Melonic invariants of paired tensors. We can generalize for paired tensors the recursive construction that defines melonic graphs and invariants (Sec. 5.2). For our use here, it is enough to define them with thick edges on the canonical pairs (so in the following, "melonic graphs of paired tensors" always have thick edges on the canonical pairs). The definition is the following:

- A melonic invariant with one paired tensor $P$ is always denoted as $\mathbf{i d}_{1}$ (the number of indices is not made explicit unless there is a possible confusion). It corresponds to a graph with two vertices linked by one thick edge and a number of colored edges. One has:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}(P)=\operatorname{Tr}(P)=\sum_{\left\{i_{c, r}\right\}_{c, r}} P_{\left\{i_{c, r}, i_{c, r}\right\}}
$$

- A connected melonic invariant with more than one paired tensor always has a tensor with $\mathcal{D} \geqslant 1$ inputs, of which $\mathcal{D}-1$ are summed with their paired outputs. In the colored graph, it corresponds to a thick edge with a number of edges (possibly zero) with colors in $1, \ldots, D$ linking the same two vertices, with the exception of one pair of an input and output of the same shade. Removing this tensor and reconnecting the two pending half-edges as in Fig. 5, one gets a smaller melonic graph. ${ }^{31}$ An example is shown in Fig. 11.

Consider a connected melonic invariant with graph $\mathbf{g}$ as just defined, but for some regular (labeled) tensors $M_{1}, \ldots M_{n}$ (so the vertices have exactly one incident edge of color $c$ for each $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D)$ with $M_{i} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$ in the mixed case or $M_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{i}^{\prime}$ with $X_{i} \in\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $X_{i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$ in the pure case. Then this invariant is a purely connected melonic invariant $\sigma$

in the usual sense, and the canonical pairing is the identity since by construction, the black and white vertices of the canonical pairs are linked by the thick edges.

To generate all first order invariants in the mixed case, one may consider $q$ paired tensors $P^{\ell}$, $1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q$, of the form:

$$
P_{\left\{i_{c, r}, j_{c, r}\right\}}^{\ell} \underset{1 \leqslant r \leqslant k_{\ell}}{1 \leqslant c \leqslant D}=\left(M_{1}^{\ell}\right)_{i_{1,1}, \ldots i_{D, 1} ; j_{1,2}, \ldots j_{D, 2}}\left(M_{2}^{\ell}\right)_{i_{1,2}, \ldots i_{D, 2} ; j_{1,3}, \ldots j_{D, 3}} \cdots\left(M_{k_{\ell}}^{\ell}\right)_{i_{1, k_{\ell}}, \ldots i_{D, k_{\ell}} ; j_{1,1}, \ldots j_{D, 1}} .
$$

A melonic invariants of $q$ paired tensors $P^{1}, \ldots P^{q}$ of this kind is a trace invariant $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left[\left\{M_{i}^{\ell}\right\}\right]$ for $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ with $n=\sum_{i=1}^{q} k_{\ell}$, connected and such that $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic. The canonical pairing of $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is given by the pairing of inputs and outputs of (7.7). All the invariants of this kind can be generated this way, since inserting a tensor of the form (7.7) reproduces a cycle alternating thick edges and canonical pairs which is separating for $k_{\ell}>1$.

Paired tensors generated by first-order invariants. To a tensor $A$ (mixed or pure $A=$ $\left.T_{a} \otimes \bar{T}_{a}\right)$, we associate a family of paired tensors as follows. Take any first order invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ (in the mixed case, $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is connected and $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic, and in the pure case, with the convention of Sec. 7.2, $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected melonic with canonical pairing the identity), and consider the cycles in the graph which alternate edges of color $c$ and canonical pairs. For each such cycle, choose an edge and split it open. Each edge deletion removes in the corresponding trace-invariant a summation between the output and the input of two (non-necessarily distinct) tensors, and these indices are now free indices in the sense that they are not summed, and are paired (the corresponding half-edges are linked by a path of edges of color $c$ for some $c$ and canonical pairs). If $E$ is the set of edges which have been split open (that is, $E$ is a set of pairs of the form $\left(i, \sigma_{c}(i)\right.$ ) for which the summation is not carried in the definition of the trace-invariant (4.2)), we denote by $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{c E}}(A)$ the resulting "partial trace-invariant". It is a paired tensor with $k_{c}$ paired inputs and outputs for each color $c$, and if there are $n$ regular tensors $A$, the number of inputs of $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{c E}}(A)$ is easily seen to be:

$$
\mathcal{D}=\sum_{c=1}^{D} k_{c}=n(D-1)+K
$$

where $K$ is the number of connected components. If the canonical pairing of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ coincides with the thick edges, the $(D+1)$-colored graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{; E}$ for which the thick edges are represented is connected and it is a tree. The graph is not connected if the canonical pairing of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ differs from the thick edges (a situation which occurs only in the mixed case) ${ }^{32}$, and each connected component is a tree. In the latter case, there are inputs paired with outputs from a different connected component.

The simplest example is the tensor $A$ itself (in the pure case $A=T_{a} \otimes \bar{T}_{a}$ ). In the mixed case, paired tensors of the form (7.7) with all $M_{a}^{\ell}$ equal to $A$ are generated this way. See Fig. 12 for more generic examples.

We denote by $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{m}[A]$ and by $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{n}[T, \bar{T}]$ the sets of paired tensors with $\mathcal{D}$ inputs generated through this procedure by $A$ for the mixed first order invariants or by $T, \bar{T}$ (though the choice $A=T \otimes \bar{T})$ for the pure first order invariants. These sets generalize the set $\mathcal{G}[A]=\mathcal{G}_{1,1}^{m}[A]=$ $\left\{A^{n}\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$ defined above ${ }^{33}$. One may also consider first order trace-invariants of some possibly different tensors: In the mixed case, $\widehat{M}$ then takes value in a fixed set $S=\{A, B \ldots\}$, while in the

# 7.4 Grouping and ungrouping tensors 

Ungrouping tensors. Consider some paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{p}$ with $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S_{\ell}\right]$, where $S_{\ell} \subset$ $\{A, B \ldots\}$, or $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta_{\ell}, \bar{\Theta}_{\ell}\right]$, where $\Theta_{\ell} \subset\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\Theta}_{\ell} \subset\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and a colored graph $\mathbf{g}$ of $\vec{H}$. Assume that $\vec{H}$ involves in total $n$ regular tensors $M_{1}, \ldots M_{n}, M_{i} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$ or $M_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{j}^{\prime}$ with $X_{i} \in\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $X_{j}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$. One can encode the index summations represented by both the edges of $\mathbf{g}$ as well as the internal edges of all the $H_{\ell}$ using a $D$-tuple of permutations $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$, and then:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}}(\vec{H})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{M})
$$

which in the pure case where $M_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{i}^{\prime}$ can also be written with the dedicated notation $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}}(\vec{H})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{M})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}\right)$. See the examples of Fig. 13.
Lemma 7.1. With these notations, $\mathbf{g}$ is a melonic graph of paired tensors if and only if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is first order, i.e. $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is connected and melonic in the mixed case, or $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected with canonical pairing the identity in the pure case.

Proof. It is equivalent to show that every cycle that alternates canonical pairs and at least two edges of color $c$ for any $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$ is separating (where in the case of paired tensors, canonical pairs coincide with the thick edges and the inputs and outputs are of the same shade). This holds because of the fact that the paired inputs and outputs of an element $H_{\ell}$ of $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S_{\ell}\right]$ or $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta_{\ell}, \bar{\Theta}_{\ell}\right]$ are linked inside $H_{\ell}$ by a sequence of edges of color $c$ and canonical pairs.

Assuming $\mathbf{g}$ to be melonic and if now $E$ is a set of edges of $\mathbf{g}$ with colors in $\{1, \ldots D\}$ and with one edge per cycle that alternates edges of color $c$ and paired inputs and outputs, we use the notation $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbb{E}_{c E}}(\vec{H})$ for the partial trace-invariant, which has $|E|$ inputs. From (7.9) and noticing

Grouping tensors. If now we remove the condition on $E$ so that it can be any set of edges of color $1, \ldots D$ of $\mathbf{g}$ (a melonic graph of paired tensors), then the colored graph $\mathbf{g}_{i E}$ might no longer be connected (Fig. 14). Letting $\vec{H}_{i_{j}}$ be the restriction of $\vec{H}$ to the set $R_{j} \subset\{1, \ldots p\}$ of the labels of the thick edges that belong to the connected component number $\jmath$ of $\mathbf{g}_{i E}$, the partial trace of $\vec{H}_{i_{j}}$ associated to the connected component number $\jmath$ is a paired tensor $P_{j}$. Starting from a half-edge in $\mathbf{g}_{i E}$ (created by splitting an edge open), and alternatively following paired tensors and pairs of inputs and outputs of the same shade, one must eventually arrive at another half-edge. Connecting these two half-edges to form an edge (the resulting edge might or might not be an edge of $\mathbf{g}$ ), and repeating the operation for all the half-edges of $\mathbf{g}_{i E}$, one obtains a graph $h$ encoding an invariant of the paired tensors $\vec{H}$ whose connected components $h_{j}$ involve the same $H_{\ell}, \ell \in R_{j}$ as the $P_{j}$. To recover $P_{j}$ from $h_{j}$, one must remove some edges, at most one edge is removed for each cycle alternating paired indices and colored edges.

In addition, since $\mathbf{g}$ is a melonic graph of paired tensors that are elements of $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S_{\ell}\right]$ or $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta_{\ell}, \bar{\Theta}_{\ell}\right]$, there is a $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ first order (Lemma 7.9), and the relevant canonical pairing $\eta$, and a $\vec{M}$, such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}}(\vec{H})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{M})$ (in the pure case, $M_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{i}^{\prime}$ and one can also write $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}}(\vec{H})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{M})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}\right)$ ). There is also a $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}$ with connected components $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}$ satisfying $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{h}_{j}}\left(\vec{H}_{j}\right)=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}}\left(\vec{M}_{j}\right)$ with $\vec{M}_{j}=\vec{M}_{|h_{j}}$ (so in the pure case, $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{h}_{j}}\left(\vec{H}_{j}\right)=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}}\left(\vec{X}_{j}, \vec{X}_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ ), and one has ${ }^{35} \boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$, and therefore in the mixed case $(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic with canonical pairing $\eta$ (Thm. 6.9), and in the pure case $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ is melonic with canonical pairing the identity

Alternating and almost alternating invariants. Given a trace-invariant of paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{p}$ encoded by its colored graph g , with $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{in}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ with $Q_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$, or $H_{\ell} \in$ $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right]$, where $\left(X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right) \in\left\{\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right),\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right) \ldots\right\}$ (that is, here, if $X_{\ell}=T_{a}$, one must have $\bar{X}_{\ell}=\bar{T}_{a}$, etc), we will say that $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H})$ is alternating or strictly alternating if it has more than one paired tensor and all the edges of color $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$ of g that link some $H_{\ell}, H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ with $\ell \neq \ell^{\prime}$ are such that $H_{\ell}$ and $H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ are generated by different tensors $Q_{\ell} \neq Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$ or $\left(X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right) \neq\left(X_{\ell^{\prime}}, \bar{X}_{\ell^{\prime}}\right)$. Note that any number of edges may link the inputs and outputs of a given $H_{\ell}$.

We say that $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H})$ is almost alternating, if at least one edge of some color $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$ links some paired tensors $H_{\ell}, H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ with $\ell \neq \ell^{\prime}$ and generated by different tensors $Q_{\ell} \neq Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$, and at most one edge links two paired tensors $H_{\ell}, H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ with $\ell \neq \ell^{\prime}$ and generated by the same $Q_{\ell}=Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$.

With the same notations, if $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H})$ is not alternating, we may form groups of tensors to form coarser invariants which are alternating, as we now detail. In g, let $E^{\neq}=E^{\neq}(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H})$ be the set of edges of color $c \in\{1, \ldots D\}$ that link paired tensors $H_{\ell}, H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ generated by different tensors

We choose $E^{\text {int }}$ a set of edges of $\mathrm{g}_{i, E^{\neq}}$, such that $E^{\text {int }}$ contains one edge per cycle of $\mathrm{g}_{i, E^{\neq}}$that alternates edges of color $c$ and paired inputs and outputs, and let $E^{\text {tot }}=E^{\neq} \cup E^{\text {int }}$. We let $P_{j}^{\neq}=P_{j}^{\neq}(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H}, E^{\text {int }})$ and $\mathrm{h}_{j}^{\neq}=\mathrm{h}_{j}^{\neq}(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H}, E^{\text {int }})$ be the $P_{j}$ and $\mathrm{h}_{j}$ of $\mathrm{g}_{i, E^{\text {tot }}}$, constructed as above. From the construction, all paired tensors $H_{\ell}$ that belong to the same $P_{j}^{\neq}$are generated by the same tensor $Q_{\ell}=Q(j)$ in $\{A, B \ldots\}$, so that from (7.12), in the mixed case, $P_{j}^{\neq} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}[Q(j)]$, and in the pure case, $Q(j)=X(j) \otimes \bar{X}(j)$ and $P_{j}^{\neq} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{n}}[X(j), \bar{X}(j)]$. The colored graph k built above is in the present situation denoted by $\mathrm{k}^{\neq}=\mathrm{k}^{\neq}\left(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H}, E^{\text {int }}\right)$. From the construction, every edge $e$ of $\mathrm{k}^{\neq}$either links paired tensors $P_{j}^{\neq}, P_{j^{\prime}}^{\neq}$with $j \neq j^{\prime}$ that are generated by different tensors $Q(j) \neq Q\left(j^{\prime}\right)$, or $e$ links and input and output of one paired tensor $P_{j}^{\neq}:\left(\mathrm{k}^{\neq}, \vec{P}^{\neq}\right)$ is strictly alternating.

# 7.5 Asymptotic moments of random paired tensors 

Asymptotics. Consider any paired-tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S_{\ell}\right]$, where $S_{\ell} \subset\{A, B \ldots\}$, or $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{n}}\left[\Theta_{\ell}, \bar{\Theta}_{\ell}\right]$, where $\Theta_{\ell} \subset\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\Theta}_{\ell} \subset\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$, and a trace-invariant of these $q$ paired tensors with colored graph g , that involves a total of $n$ regular tensors $M_{1}, \ldots M_{n}$, $M_{i} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$ or $M_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{i}^{\prime}$ with with $X_{i} \in\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $X_{i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$. Then from (7.9), there is a $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}$ such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{H})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(\vec{M})$. Furthermore, g is a connected melonic graph of paired tensors if and only if $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ is first order (Lemma 7.9). Assume that the regular random tensors $\{A, B \ldots\}$ or $\left\{T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}, T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$ scale as assumed in the previous sections respectively in the mixed (6.37) and (6.38) and pure (6.10) and (6.15) cases. In both cases, the expectations of trace-invariants for first order $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ are of order $N$, and we may set:

$$
\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h}):=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(\vec{M})\right]
$$

In the mixed and pure case, this respectively corresponds to the dedicated notations:

$$
\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m}) \quad \text { or } \quad \phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x})
$$

We say that $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{h})$ is almost or strictly alternating if $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H})$ is.
Considering a set $E$ of edges of g satisfying the condition above (7.12) and splitting open the edges of $E$ defines as in (7.12) some $P_{j} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S_{j}\right]$ or $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{n}}\left[\Theta_{j}, \bar{\Theta}_{j}\right]$, and with the notations of Sec. 7.4, some $\vec{H}_{j}, \boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}$, and k . The $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}$ being first order, we may define as in (7.15) $\phi_{\mathrm{h}_{j}}\left(\vec{h}_{j}\right)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left(\vec{m}_{j}\right)$, or in the pure case $\phi_{\mathrm{h}_{1}}\left(\vec{h}_{j}\right)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}}\left(\vec{x}_{j}, \overrightarrow{x_{j}}\right)$, so that (7.13) becomes:

$$
\phi_{\mathrm{h}_{1}}\left(\vec{h}_{j}\right)=\phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left(p_{j}\right)=\phi\left(p_{j}\right)
$$

Asymptotically, (7.14) implies:

$$
\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=\phi_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p})
$$
