In particular, starting from $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ purely connected with $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \mathrm{id})=0$ and $\vec{Q} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$ (or $Q_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{i}^{\prime}$ with $X_{i} \in\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $X_{i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$ ) instead of $\vec{H}$, with $\boldsymbol{\nu}_{j}$ instead of $\mathrm{h}_{j}$ : $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}_{j}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{q})=\phi\left(p_{j}\right)$ and $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{q})=\phi_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p})$ (or pure equivalent $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}_{j}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x^{\prime}}\right)=\phi\left(p_{j}\right)$ and $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x^{\prime}}\right)=\phi_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p})$ ).

Multilinearity. We now consider the asymptotics of $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{H}^{\prime \prime}\right)$, where $H_{\ell}^{\prime \prime}=H_{\ell}+t_{\ell} H_{\ell}^{\prime}$ with $t_{\ell} \in \mathbb{C}$ and $H_{\ell}, H_{\ell}^{\prime} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}[S]$ with $S=\{A, B \ldots\}$, or $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}[\Theta, \bar{\Theta}]$, where $\Theta=\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\Theta}=\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}, \mathrm{g}$ a connected melonic graph of these paired tensors. By multilinearity:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{H}^{\prime \prime}\right)=\sum_{k=0}^{p} \sum_{1 \leqslant \ell(1)<\ell(2)<\ldots<\ell(k) \leqslant p}\left(\prod_{j=1}^{k} t_{\ell(j)}\right) \operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{H}_{\{\ell(1), \ldots, \ell(k)\}}^{\prime \prime}\right)
$$

where setting $I=\{\ell(1), \ldots, \ell(k)\}$, the $\ell$ th component of $\vec{H}_{[I]}^{\prime \prime}$ is $H_{\ell}$ if $\ell \notin I$ and is $H_{\ell}^{\prime}$ otherwise. Due to (7.9), (6.15) and (6.38), $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{H}_{[I]}^{\prime \prime}\right)$ is of order $N$ and the limit of the rescaled expectation is:

$$
\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{h}^{\prime \prime}\right)=\sum_{k=0}^{p} \sum_{1 \leqslant \ell(1)<\ell(2)<\ldots<\ell(k) \leqslant p}\left(\prod_{j=1}^{k} t_{\ell(j)}\right) \phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{h}_{[I]}^{\prime}\right), \quad h_{\ell}^{\prime \prime}=h_{\ell}+t_{\ell} h_{\ell}^{\prime}
$$

where the $\ell$ th component of $\vec{h}_{[I]}^{\prime \prime}$ is $h_{\ell}$ if $\ell \notin I$ and $h_{\ell}^{\prime}$ otherwise: $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}$ is multilinear by construction.

# 7.6 Asymptotically centering paired tensors 

For any $\mathcal{D} \in \mathbb{N}^{*}$, we let:

$$
\mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}}=\frac{\mathbb{1}^{\otimes \mathcal{D}}}{N^{\mathcal{D}-1}}
$$

If $H \in \mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{m}}[S]$ with $S=\{A, B \ldots\}$ or $H \in \mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{p}}[\Theta, \bar{\Theta}]$, where $\Theta=\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\Theta}=$ $\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$, in order to asymptotically center $H$, we may define at finite $N$ :

$$
G=H-\phi(h) \mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}}
$$

where $\phi(h)=\phi_{\mathrm{id}_{1}}(h)$, so if $H$ involves a total of $n$ regular tensors $M_{1}, \ldots M_{n}, M_{i} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$ or $M_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{i}^{\prime}$ with $X_{i} \in\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $X_{i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$, there exists a first order $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ such that $\phi(h)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})$ in the mixed case and $\phi(h)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x^{\prime}}\right)$ in the pure case.

We need to justify that the rescaling (7.22) is the appropriate one for considering quantities like $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}$, that it will be asymptotically multilinear, and that $G$ thus defined will be asymptotically centered: $\phi(g)=0$. The reason why the identity is rescaled by $N^{\mathcal{D}-1}$ is because for any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ :

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{D}\right)=N^{n-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})}=N^{1-(D-1)\left(K_{p}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-1\right)-\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}) \mathrm{id})}
$$

so if $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is purely connected and $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \mathrm{id})=0$ one has $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{D}\right)=N$.
Lemma 7.2. Any element of $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ which originates from a purely connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is equal to $\mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}}$. Therefore for any $\mathcal{D}$ there exists $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ with $n=(\mathcal{D}-1) /(n-1), \boldsymbol{\sigma}$ purely connected with $\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \mathrm{id})=0$, and a set $E$ consisting of $\mathcal{D}$ edges, one per cycle alternating edges of color $c$ and thick edges, such that:

$$
\mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}}=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{\backslash E}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{D}\right)
$$

Proof. With the notations of the lemma, every path of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ consisting alternatively of thick edges representing and edges of color $c$ and whose extremities are half-edges represents a Kronnecker delta in the corresponding indices. The cycles of this kind contribute as factors of $N$, and the overall exponent of $N$ is $n-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})-\mathcal{D}=1-\mathcal{D}$.

If $\mathbf{g}$ is a connected melonic graph of $\mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}, \ldots \mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}_{p}}$, then from Lemma 7.2, (7.9) and (7.23):

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}, \ldots, \mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}_{p}}\right)=N
$$

leading to the same global rescaling $N$ for melonic invariants as in (7.15). By linearity of $\operatorname{Tr}=\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}$, we do find that $G$ introduced in (7.22) satisfies $\phi(g)=\phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}(g)=0$.

Lemma 7.2 also implies that the following sets both contain $\mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}}$ :

- The set $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta, \bar{\Theta} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ of paired tensors with $\mathcal{D}$ inputs obtained from pure first order invariants (Sec. 7.3, see also Fig. 12), where any thick edge may represent $\mathbb{1}_{D}$, or any of the elements of the form $X_{i} \otimes X_{\hat{i}}^{\prime}$ with $X_{i} \in \Theta$ and $X_{\hat{i}}^{\prime} \in \bar{\Theta}$.
- The set $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ of paired tensors with $\mathcal{D}$ inputs obtained from mixed first order invariants, where any thick edge may represent any element of $S$, but only thick edge that coincide with a canonical pair may be replaced with $\mathbb{1}_{D}$.

Respectively let $\mathcal{A}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ and $\mathcal{A}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta, \bar{\Theta} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ be the sets of complex linear combinations of elements of $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ and $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\theta, \bar{\theta} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$. (7.22) is an element of $\mathcal{A}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ in the mixed case and of $\mathcal{A}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta, \bar{\Theta} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ in the pure case. We let $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}=\cup_{\mathcal{D} \geqslant 1} \mathcal{A}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{m}}$ and $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}=\cup_{\mathcal{D} \geqslant 1} \mathcal{A}_{D, \mathcal{D}}^{\mathrm{p}}$. For $D=1$ and $S=\{A\}, \mathcal{A}_{1}^{\mathrm{m}}[A ; \mathbb{1}]=\mathcal{A}_{1,1}^{\mathrm{m}}[A ; \mathbb{1}]$ is the algebra $\mathcal{A}[A, \mathbb{1}]$ generated by $\mathbb{1}$ and $A$.

Considering $\vec{H}^{\prime}$ where $H_{\ell}^{\prime}=H_{\ell}+\alpha_{\ell} \mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}$ where $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S_{\ell}\right], S_{\ell} \subset\{A, B \ldots\}$, or $H_{\ell} \in$ $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta_{\ell}, \bar{\Theta}_{\ell}\right]$, where $\Theta_{\ell} \subset\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\Theta}_{\ell} \subset\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$, in order to make sense of $\phi_{\mathbf{g}}\left(\vec{h}^{\prime}\right)$, where $\mathbf{g}$ is a connected melonic graph of $p$ paired tensors, we write by multilinearity:

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}}\left(\vec{H}^{\prime}\right)=\sum_{k=0}^{p} \sum_{1 \leqslant \ell(1)<\ell(2)<\ldots<\ell(k) \leqslant p}\left(\prod_{j=1}^{k} \alpha_{\ell(j)}\right) \operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}}\left(\vec{H}_{\{\ell(1), \ldots, \ell(k)\}}\right)
$$

where letting $I=\{\ell(1), \ldots, \ell(k)\}$, the component of index $\ell$ of the vector $\vec{H}_{\{I\}}$ is $H_{\ell}$ if $\ell \notin I$ and is $\mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}$ otherwise. We therefore need to study the asymptotics of the right-hand-side.

Each $M_{i}$ comes from one of the components of $\vec{H}_{\{I\}}$, so it takes value in the set $\left\{\mathbb{1}_{D}, A, B \ldots\right\}$ (in the pure case, each $M_{i}$ different from $\mathbb{1}_{D}$ writes as $M_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{i}^{\prime}$ ). $$
\phi_{\mathbf{g}}\left(1_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}, \ldots, 1_{\mathcal{D}_{p}}\right)=1
$$

We define as above $\mathbf{g}_{\gamma I}$ as the (non-necessarily connected) melonic graph of paired tensors obtained by removing the thick edges with indices in $I=\{\ell(1), \ldots, \ell(k)\}$ from the graph in the same way as in Fig. 16 (the procedure can be adapted here since the inputs and outputs of the same color are paired). We also denote by $\phi_{\Pi\left(\mathbf{g}_{\gamma I}\right), \mathbf{g}_{\gamma I}}\left(\vec{h}_{\gamma I}\right)$ the product of the $\phi_{\mathbf{g}_{\gamma}}$ over the connected components $\mathbf{g}_{\boldsymbol{I}}$ of $\mathbf{g}_{\gamma I}$, where $\vec{h}_{\gamma I}$ gathers the $h_{\ell}$ for $\ell \notin I=\{\ell(1), \ldots, \ell(k)\}$. One has:

$$
\phi_{\mathbf{g}}\left(\vec{h}_{\{I\}}\right)=\phi_{\Pi\left(\mathbf{g}_{, I}\right), \mathbf{g}_{, I}}\left(\vec{h}_{\gamma I}\right)
$$

Since none of the arguments onn the right-hand side is 1 , it can be expressed in terms of asymptotic moments of $\vec{m}$ or $\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}$. Finally coming back to (7.26), we see that all the terms in the sum are of order $N$, so we may rescale and take the limit of the expectation, to obtain:

$$
\phi_{\mathbf{g}}\left(\vec{h}^{\prime}\right)=\sum_{k=0}^{p} \sum_{1 \leqslant \ell(1)<\ell(2)<\ldots<\ell(k) \leqslant p}\left(\prod_{j=1}^{k} \alpha_{\ell(j)}\right) \phi_{\mathbf{g}}\left(\vec{h}_{\{I\}}\right), \quad h_{\ell}^{\prime}=h_{\ell}+\alpha_{\ell} 1_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}
$$

The notation $h_{\ell}^{\prime}=h_{\ell}+\alpha_{\ell} 1_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}$ is consistent with multilinearity, since the component of index $\ell$ of $\vec{h}_{\{I\}}$ is $h_{\ell}$ if $\ell \notin\{\ell(1), \ldots, \ell(k)\}$ and $1_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}$ otherwise.

# 7.7 Free cumulants of paired tensors 

We are now able to introduce free cumulants associated to connected melonic graphs of paired tensors. In Sec. 7.3, we detailed how trace-invariants of paired tensors can be encoded by graphs $\mathbf{g}$ or cycles $\left\{\gamma_{c, b}\right\}$, each of the form $\left(\left(k_{1}, r_{1}\right) \cdots\left(k_{q_{c, b}}, r_{q_{c, b}}\right)\right)$ where $1 \leqslant k_{1}, \ldots k_{q} \leqslant n$ are the labels

of the thick edges encountered in the cycle, and $r_{s}$ is the shade of the pair of output and input of color $c$ of the paired tensor number $k_{s}$ which is in the cycle.

Consider any paired-tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S_{\ell}\right]$, where $S_{\ell} \subset\{A, B \ldots\}$, or $H_{\ell} \in$ $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta_{\ell}, \bar{\Theta}_{\ell}\right]$, where $\Theta_{\ell} \subset\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\Theta}_{\ell} \subset\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$, and a trace-invariant of these $q$ paired tensors with colored graph $\mathfrak{g}$, encoded by some such cycles $\left\{\gamma_{c, b}\right\}$. We may independently consider some non-crossing permutations $\left\{\tau_{c, b}\right\}$ with $\tau_{c, b} \leq \gamma_{c, b}$ in $S_{\mathrm{NC}}\left(\gamma_{c, b}\right)$, which is isomorphic to $\mathrm{NC}\left(q_{c, b}\right)$, where $q_{c, b}$ is the number of elements in the cycle $\gamma_{c, b}$. We use the notation $\{\mathrm{h} \mid \mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{g}\}$ to refer to the set of $h$ built from all the $\tau_{c, b} \leq \gamma_{c, b}$, and the notation $\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{h}, \mathrm{g})=\prod_{c, b} \mathrm{M}\left(\tau_{c, b} \gamma_{c, b}^{-1}\right)$.

We may therefore define free cumulants for connected melonic graphs $\mathfrak{g}$ of $q$ paired tensors for any $\vec{h}=\left(h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}\right)$ as:

$$
\varkappa_{\mathfrak{g}}(\vec{h})=\sum_{\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{g}} \phi_{\Pi(\mathrm{h}), \mathrm{h}}(\vec{h}) \mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~h}, \mathrm{~g})
$$

where as above, $\phi_{\Pi(\mathrm{h}), \mathrm{h}}(\vec{h})$ is the product of the $\phi_{\mathrm{h}_{j}}$ over the connected components $\mathrm{h}_{j}$ of $h$. By multilinearity of the $\phi$, the $\varkappa$ are multilinear.

To understand this formula better, one can use (7.16) and Lemma 7.1: we may gather the colored edges of $\mathfrak{g}$ together with the colored edges of each $H_{\ell}$, to form a colored graph of $M_{1}, \ldots M_{n}$, namely, a first order invariant $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$, such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathfrak{g}}(\vec{H})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{M})$. In the mixed case, $M_{i} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$, while in the pure case, $M_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{i}^{\prime}$ with $X_{i} \in\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $X_{i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}\left(\operatorname{so} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{M})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}\right)\right)$. To each $\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{g}$ corresponds a $\boldsymbol{\rho} \in S_{n}^{D}$ which satisfies $\boldsymbol{\rho} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$, where $\eta \in S_{n}$ is the canonical pairing of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ (pure) or ( $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}$ ) (mixed), but not any such $\boldsymbol{\rho}$ may occur in the sum, as the edges internal to the $H_{\ell}$ must be the same in $\boldsymbol{\rho}$ and $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$, as will be detailed in the proof of Prop. 7.4, see (7.36). One has:

$$
\phi_{\Pi(\mathrm{h}), \mathrm{h}}(\vec{h})=\varphi_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\rho}), \boldsymbol{\rho}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m}) \quad(\text { mixed }), \quad \text { and } \quad \phi_{\Pi(\mathrm{h}), \mathrm{h}}(\vec{h})=\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\rho}), \boldsymbol{\rho}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right) \quad \text { (pure) }
$$

where in the pure case $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\rho})=\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\rho})$ due to the fact that the connected components of $\boldsymbol{\rho}$ are purely connected (since in that case the canonical pairing is the identity).

If $\mathfrak{g}$ is not necessarily connected, we set $\varkappa_{\Pi(\mathrm{g}), \mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})$ to be the product of the $\varkappa_{\mathfrak{g}_{i}}$ over the connected components $\mathfrak{g}_{i}$. We can invert the formula in the lattice $\times_{c, b} S_{\mathrm{NC}}\left(\gamma_{c, b}\right) \cong \times_{c, b} \mathrm{NC}\left(q_{c, b}\right)$, to obtain:

$$
\phi_{\mathfrak{g}}(\vec{h})=\sum_{\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{g}} \varkappa_{\Pi(\mathrm{h}), \mathrm{h}}(\vec{h})
$$

The relation between $\varkappa$ and $\kappa$ is more complicated than the relation between $\phi$ and $\varphi(7.32)$ : see (7.34) later in this section. With the same notations as above, the following proposition, analogous to Prop. 11.15 of [1]. is proved in Sec. C.1.
Proposition 7.3. Let $\mathfrak{g}$ be a connected melonic graph of $q \geqslant 2$ paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}$ be the number of inputs of $H_{\ell}$, then one has $\varkappa_{\mathfrak{g}}(\vec{h})=0$ if one of the $h_{\ell}$ is $\mathfrak{l}_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}$ (i.e. if $H_{\ell}=\mathfrak{1}_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}$ ).

This of course applies as well to $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x}^{\prime}\right)$ and $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})$. The second result we will need relates free cumulants of paired tensors $\vec{H}$ and those obtained by grouping them to obtain bigger paired tensors $\vec{P}$ as in Sec. 7.4. See the proof in Sec. C.1. It generalizes Thm. 11.12 of [1].
Proposition 7.4. Let $\mathfrak{g}$ be a connected melonic graph of $q$ paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S_{\ell}\right]$, where $S_{\ell} \subset\{A, B \ldots\}$, or $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta_{\ell}, \bar{\Theta}_{\ell}\right]$, where $\Theta_{\ell} \subset\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\Theta}_{\ell} \subset\left\{\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots\right\}$, $E$ a set of edges of $\mathfrak{g}$, the $P_{j}$ obtained as connected components of $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathfrak{g}, \mathcal{E}}(\vec{H})$, the $\mathrm{h}_{j}$ such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{h}_{j}}\left(\vec{H}_{j}\right)=\operatorname{Tr}\left(P_{j}\right)(7.13)$, and which constitute the connected components of $\mathrm{h}$, which is a melonic invariant of $\vec{H}$, and finally, k such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathfrak{g}}(\vec{H})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{P})(7.14)$. Then:

$$
\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p})=\sum_{\substack{h^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{g} \\ \Pi\left(\mathrm{~h}^{\prime}\right) \vee \Pi(\mathrm{h})=1_{q}}} \varkappa_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime}}(\vec{h})
$$

where $\Pi(\mathrm{g}), \Pi(\mathrm{h})$ are the partitions of $\{1, \ldots, q\}$ induced by the connected components of $\mathrm{g}, \mathrm{h}$.
We may apply the proposition to a first order $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ instead of the more general g : in the mixed case, if $\eta \in S_{n}$ is the canonical pairing of $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}), \mathrm{k}$ is a connected melonic graph of $q$ paired tensors $P_{1}, \ldots P_{q}$ generated by $A, B \ldots, \vec{M}$ is such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{P})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{M})(7.9), \boldsymbol{\tau}_{\ell}$ with support $R_{\ell} \subset\{1, \ldots n\}$ is such that $\operatorname{Tr}\left(P_{\ell}\right)=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{\ell}}\left(\vec{M}_{\mid B_{\ell}}\right)$, and $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}$ has connected components $\left\{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{\ell}\right\}$ :

$$
\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p})=\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\rho} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1} \\ \Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\rho} \eta^{-1}\right) \vee \Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}\right)=1_{n}}} \kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\rho}), \boldsymbol{\rho}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})
$$

In the pure case, the $P_{1}, \ldots P_{q}$ are generated by $T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots$ and $\bar{T}_{a}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots$, one has $M_{i}=X_{i} \otimes X_{i}^{\prime}$ and $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{P})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{X}, \vec{X}^{\prime}\right), \boldsymbol{\tau}_{\ell}$ is such that $\operatorname{Tr}\left(P_{\ell}\right)=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{\ell}}\left(\bar{X} \otimes \bar{X}^{\dagger}{ }_{\mid B_{\ell}}\right)$, and:

$$
\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p})=\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\rho} \in \boldsymbol{\sigma} \\ \Pi(\boldsymbol{\rho}) \vee \Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau})=1_{n}}} \kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\rho}), \boldsymbol{\rho}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x^{\prime}})
$$

The proof of Prop. 7.4 in Sec. C. 1 relies on the useful relation (C.2), which here simplifies to:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p}) & =\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\rho} \in S_{n}^{D} \\
\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\rho} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}}} \varphi_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\rho}), \boldsymbol{\rho}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m}) \\
\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p}) & =\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\rho} \in S_{n}^{D} \\
\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\rho} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}}} \varphi_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\rho}), \boldsymbol{\rho}}\left(\vec{x}, \vec{x^{\prime}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider now the situation where, in the mixed case, k is a connected melonic graph of $P_{1}, \ldots P_{q}$ with $P_{\ell}$ of the form (7.7), and $\vec{M}$ such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{P})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{M})$, so that $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ is connected and $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic. Then $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ coincides with $(\eta, \eta, \ldots, \eta)$, so that in this particular situation:

$$
\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p})=\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})
$$

# 7.8 Asymptotic tensor freeness at the level of moments
### 7.8.1 Mixed case

We consider some mixed random tensors $A, B \ldots$ with $D \geqslant 2$ inputs which scale as (6.37), and we consider the corresponding asymptotic moments and first order free cumulants $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{m}), \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{m})$, where $\vec{m} \in\{a, b, \ldots\}^{n}$, as well as the asymptotic moments $\phi$ and cumulants $\varkappa$ associated to connected melonic invariants of paired tensors. The following is proved in Sec. C.2.1.
Theorem 7.5 (Asymptotic mixed tensor freeness). The following statements are equivalent:

1. For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected and with $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$, and any $\vec{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right) \in$ $\{a, b, \ldots\}^{n}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0$ whenever there exists $1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$.
2. The two following conditions are satisfied:

- For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected such that $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic with canonical pairing $\eta \neq \mathrm{id}$, and any $\vec{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right) \in\{a, b, \ldots\}^{n}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0$ whenever there exists $i \in\{1, \ldots n\}$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{\eta(i)}$.
- For any $q \geqslant 2$, any paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$ such that $\forall 1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{m}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ with $Q_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$, and any connected melonic graph g of the paired tensors $\vec{H}$, $\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=0$ whenever there exists $1 \leqslant \ell<\ell^{\prime} \leqslant q$ such that $Q_{\ell} \neq Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$.

3. The two following conditions are satisfied:

- For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected and such that $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic with canonical pairing $\eta \neq \mathrm{id}$, and any $\vec{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right) \in\{a, b, \ldots\}^{n}, \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0$ whenever there exists $i \in\{1, \ldots n\}$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{\eta(i)}$.
- For any $q \geqslant 2$, any $\mathcal{D}_{1}, \ldots \mathcal{D}_{q} \geqslant 1$, any paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$ such that for $1 \leqslant$ $\ell \leqslant q, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{\mathrm{n}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ with $Q_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$, and any connected melonic graph g of $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$, letting for each $\ell: h_{\ell}^{\prime}=h_{\ell}-\phi\left(h_{\ell}\right) 1_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}$, then $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{h}^{\prime}\right)=0$ whenever $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{h})$ is almost alternating.

Notice the dissymmetry: the first statements of point 2 and 3 do not require the notion of paired tensors nor introducing $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$. These notions are needed for the second statements of 2 and 3 , because of the necessity to center the $h_{\ell}$. For point 3 , for $A, B, C$ asymptotically free, the example on the right of Fig. 13 with $H_{1}, \ldots H_{4}$ respectively generated by $A, B, C$ and $C$ is almost alternating (Fig. 15) and therefore vanishes when the $H_{i}$ are asymptotically centered.

For points 2 and 3 , one can replace $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{m}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ by $\mathcal{A}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ etc, see Rk. C. 2 and Rk. C.6.

# 7.8.2 Pure case 

We now consider some pure random tensors $T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}, T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots$ for $D \geqslant 3$, which scale as (6.10) and (6.15), and we consider the corresponding asymptotic moments and first order free cumulants $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}\right), \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}\right)$, where for each $i, x_{i} \in\left\{t_{a}, t_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $x_{i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{t}_{a}, \bar{t}_{b} \ldots\right\}$, as well as the $\phi$ and $\varkappa$.
Theorem 7.6 (Asymptotic pure tensor freeness). The following statements are equivalent:

1. For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ purely connected and melonic with canonical pairing the identity, and any $\vec{x} \in\left\{t_{a}, t_{b} \ldots\right\}^{n}$ and $\overrightarrow{x^{\prime}} \in\left\{\bar{t}_{a}, \bar{t}_{b} \ldots\right\}^{n}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}\right)=0$ whenever $x_{i} \neq x_{j}$ or $x_{i}^{\prime} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$, or $\overline{x_{i}} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$ for some $i, j$.
2. The two following conditions are satisfied:

- For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ purely connected and melonic with canonical pairing the identity, and any $\vec{x} \in\left\{t_{a}, t_{b} \ldots\right\}^{n}$ and $\overrightarrow{x^{\prime}} \in\left\{\bar{t}_{a}, \bar{t}_{b} \ldots\right\}^{n}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}\right)=0$ whenever there exists $i \in\{1, \ldots n\}$ such that $\overline{x_{i}} \neq x_{i}^{\prime}$.
- For any $q \geqslant 2$, any paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$ such that $\forall 1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right]$ where $\left(X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right) \in\left\{\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right),\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right) \ldots\right\}$, and any connected melonic graph g of the paired tensors $\vec{H}, \varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=0$ whenever $\exists 1 \leqslant \ell<\ell^{\prime} \leqslant q$ such that $\left(X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right) \neq\left(X_{\ell^{\prime}}, \bar{X}_{\ell^{\prime}}\right)$.

3. The two following conditions are satisfied:

- For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ purely connected and melonic with canonical pairing the identity, and any $\vec{x} \in\left\{t_{a}, t_{b} \ldots\right\}^{n}$ and $\overrightarrow{x^{\prime}} \in\left\{\bar{t}_{a}, \bar{t}_{b} \ldots\right\}^{n}, \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}\right)=0$ whenever there exists $i \in\{1, \ldots n\}$ such that $\overline{x_{i}} \neq x_{i}^{\prime}$.
- For any $q \geqslant 2$, any $\mathcal{D}_{1}, \ldots \mathcal{D}_{q} \geqslant 1$, any $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$ such that $\forall 1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q, H_{\ell} \in$ $\mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right]$ where $\left(X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right) \in\left\{\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right),\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right) \ldots\right\}$, and any connected melonic graph g of $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$, letting for each $\ell: h_{\ell}^{\prime}=h_{\ell}-\phi\left(h_{\ell}\right) 1_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}$, then $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{h}^{\prime}\right)=0$ whenever $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{h})$ is almost alternating.

The proof can be found in Sec. C.2.2. For points 2 and 3, one can replace $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right]$ by $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$, see Rk. C. 2 and Rk. C. 6 and Thm. 8.2.

For the second statement of point 3 , for $T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}, T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}, T_{c}, \bar{T}_{c}$ asymptotically free, the example on the left of Fig. 13, with $H_{1}, H_{2}, H_{3}, H_{4}$ respectively generated by $T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}, T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}, T_{c}, \bar{T}_{c}$ and $T_{c}, \bar{T}_{c}$, vanishes when the $H_{i}$ are asymptotically centered.

# 8 Limiting spaces and tensor freeness 

Here we provide an answer to the question: can we give a more precise meaning to the letters $a, b, h, t, \bar{t}$ used in the asymptotic moments and free cumulants $\varphi_{\sigma}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a}), \varphi_{\sigma}(t, \bar{t}), \phi_{\mathbf{S}}(\vec{h})$, etc, in the same was as for matrices they can be seen as non-commutative random variables (Sec. 7.1). Our approach is to introduce spaces whose elements are constructed algebraically from a set of generators in the same way as the paired tensors that are centered in the formulation of asymptotic tensor freeness (Sec. 7.8), so that asymptotic tensor freeness of the generators $A, B, C \ldots$ can be reformulated as tensor freeness of the algebraic spaces generated by $a, b, c \ldots$ The trace of these elements - which define the moments - correspond to melonic graphs in the generators, and therefore the random tensors considered converge in distribution to such elements.

### 8.1 Tensorial probability spaces

General idea. Elements $x, y$ of a non-commutative algebra can be multiplied on the left or right: $x y$ and $y x$ are a priori different. In this sense they have one input (right) and one output (left), and if the input of $x$ is multiplied with the output of $y$, then $x$ has no more available input, and $x y$ still has an input (that of $y$, by associativity) and an output (that of $x$ ).

The main objects in the present case are elements $x, y$, which can be multiplied on the left and right in a number of ways. They have a number of inputs and outputs of different kinds, and $x$ and $y$ can be multiplied on the left or right if they have an input and output of the same kind. After multiplication, it may still be possible to multiply $x$ on the right in $x y$ by some $z$, by using other inputs of $x$, different from the one used to multiply $x$ with $y$.

Starting from a set of generators, we will build by multiplication some elements with more inputs and outputs. The space is organized in sets of elements with the same number of inputs and outputs of the same kind. Some special elements generalize the role of the identity. A unital linear functional plays the same role as for non-commutative probability spaces.

Elements. For $D \geqslant 1$ and $\vec{k}=\left(k_{1}, \ldots k_{D}\right)$ where $k_{c} \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\sum_{c} k_{c}>0$, we consider complex vector spaces $\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}$ (for the addition) of elements which have $k_{c}$ inputs of color $c$ on the right $k_{c}$ outputs of color $c$ on the left, which are distinguishable and paired: if $x \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}$ and $k_{c} \geqslant 1$, we respectively label the different inputs and outputs of color $c$ of $x$ from 1 to $k_{c}$. Inputs and outputs with the same label have the same shade. We define the graded space $\mathcal{A}_{D}=\bigcup_{\vec{k}} \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}$.

Multiplication. If $c \in\{1, \ldots D\}, x \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}^{(1)}}$ and $y \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}^{(2)}}$, and $s^{(1)}, s^{(2)} \in \mathbb{N}^{\bullet}$ with $k_{c}^{(1)} \geqslant$ $s^{(1)}$ and $k_{c}^{(2)} \geqslant s^{(2)}$, we may consider the product:

$$
x_{\cdot(c ; s^{(1)}, s^{(2)})} y \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}} \quad \text { where } \begin{cases}k_{c}=k_{c}^{(1)}+k_{c}^{(2)}-1 \\ k_{c^{\prime}}=k_{c^{\prime}}^{(1)}+k_{c^{\prime}}^{(2)} & \text { if } c^{\prime} \neq c\end{cases}
$$

obtained by multiplying the input of $x$ of color $c$ and shade $s^{(1)}$, with the output of $y$ of color $c$ and shade $s^{(2)}$. Inputs and outputs of different colors cannot be multiplied, and any inputs and outputs of the same color may be multiplied. If $k_{c}>0$ in (8.1), the result $x_{\cdot(c ; s^{(1)}, s^{(2)})} y$ itself has distinguishable inputs and outputs of color $c$, which are labeled from 1 to $k_{c}$. The output $\left(c, s^{(1)}\right)$ of $x$ and the input $\left(c, s^{(2)}\right)$ of $y$ are paired in $x_{\cdot\left(c ; s^{(1)}, s^{(2)}\right)} y$, and the input and outputs of $x, y$ that are not involved in the multiplication remain paired after the multiplication. A difference with non-commutative algebras is that if $x_{\cdot\left(c ; s^{(1)}, s^{(2)}\right)} y$ is multiplied on the right by another element $z \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}^{(3)}}$, then the input of $x_{\cdot\left(c ; s^{(1)}, s^{(2)}\right)} y$ multiplied with the output of $z$ may correspond (by associativity) either to an input of $y$ or to an input of $x$, and similarly for multiplication from the left.

Graphical representation. An expression representing the multiplication of a number $n$ of elements $x, y, z \ldots$ gets rapidly messy when $n$ grows whereas it is easily represented graphically. We use the same representation as for paired tensors: an element $x \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}$ is represented by a thick edge linking a white vertex (left) and a black vertex (right). We represent the inputs and outputs by some half-edges, respectively connected to the black vertex and the white vertices, and which are labeled by a pair $(c, s)$, where $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$ is the color and $1 \leqslant s \leqslant k_{c}$ is the shade (if $k_{c}=0$ no half-edge is represented). For each color, around the white and black vertices incident to a given thick edge, the shade is represented as growing from top to bottom (Fig. 17). Connecting the half-edge representing the input $\left(c, s^{(1)}\right)$ of $x$ with the half-edge representing the output $\left(c, s^{(2)}\right)$ of $y$ to form an edge labeled $\left(c ; s^{(1)}, s^{(2)}\right)$ represents the multiplication $x \cdot{ }^{\cdot}\left(c ; s^{(1)}, s^{(2)}\right) y$, see Fig. 17.
![img-16.jpeg](img-16.jpeg)

Figure 17: Here $x \in \mathcal{A}_{3, \vec{k}^{(1)}}$ and $y \in \mathcal{A}_{3, \vec{k}(2)}$ with $\vec{k}^{(1)}=(2,1,0)$ and $\vec{k}^{(2)}=(2,1,1)$. Performing the multiplication $x \cdot{ }_{(1 ; 1,2)} y$, we obtain a new element $z \in \mathcal{A}_{3, \vec{k}}$ with $\vec{k}=(3,2,1)$. The labels of the edges and half-edges involved in the multiplication are in blue. For a given color, the shade grows from top to bottom around each vertex. The half-edges are relabeled on the right, but the vertical ordering of the half-edges is coherent for the three graphs (so for instance the half-edges $(1,2)$ of $y$ are relabeled $(1,3)$ in $z)$.

The result of multiplying a number of elements is a tree, see Fig. 18. In such a tree $\mathcal{T}$ that represents an element $z$, consider an half-edge $e$ corresponding to an output $\left(c, s_{1}\right)$ of an element $x_{1}$ involved in the multiplication. It is the extremity of a path in $\mathcal{T}$ which follows the thick-edge $x_{1}$ attached to $e$, then either an half-edge $\left(c, s_{1}\right)$, or an edge labeled $\left(c ; s_{1}, s_{2}\right)$, then a thick edge $x_{2}$, and so on, until finally an half-edge labeled $\left(c, s_{r}\right)$ is met for some $r \geqslant 1$. If now instead of seing these two half-edges as an output of $x_{1}$ and an input of $x_{r}$ respectively, we see them as an input and output of $z$, then they are paired and will carry the same shade. In Fig. 18, the labels are those of the half-edges of $z$ and not of the elements $x, y, w, u, v$ (the shades of these elements is encoded in the top to bottom ordering of half-edges around the thick edges).

Associativity in this context is the fact that the result of multiplying several elements does not depend on the order in which the elements are multiplied, as long as it leads to the same tree (Fig. 18).

Generated spaces. Consider a set $\mathrm{s}=\{a, b, c \ldots\}$ of elements (called generators), which may be infinite (see the mixed case in Sec. 8.3). We let $\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}[\mathrm{~s}]$ be the set of elements constructed by multiplication of a finite number of elements of $\mathbf{s}$ and which have $k_{c}$ inputs of color $c$. We then let $\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}[\mathrm{~s}]$ be the set of linear combinations of elements of $\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}[\mathrm{~s}]$ with complex coefficients, and $\mathcal{A}_{D}[\mathrm{~s}]=\bigcup_{\vec{k}} \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}[\mathrm{~s}]$ (many $\vec{k}$ correspond to an empty set). The generators will differ in the pure (Sec. 8.2) and mixed (Sec. 8.3) cases.

The case $D=1$. For $D=1, \mathcal{A}_{1,1}$ (i.e. the vector $\vec{k}$ only has a single component which is equal to one) is a non-commutative algebra. The graph representing the multiplication $x y z \ldots$ of a

![img-17.jpeg](img-17.jpeg)

Figure 18: Example of multiplication of some elements $x, y, w, u, v$. We keep the convention of Fig. 17: for each thick edge, the shade of half-edges of the same color grows from top to bottom, allowing the identification of the shade locally for each thick edge. The labels represented are those of the element $z$ resulting from the multiplication (and not those of the elements $x, y, w, u, v$ themselves): the indices which are paired are the extremities of paths that alternate colored edges and paired inputs and outputs.
number of some elements $x, y, z \cdots$ is a line starting from an half-edge of color 1 representing the output of $x$, a white vertex, a thick edge, a black vertex representing the input of $x$, an edge of color 1 representing the multiplication of $x$ and $y$, a white vertex representing the output of $y$, and so on. Then $\mathcal{G}_{1,1}[\mathrm{~s}]$ corresponds to the set of words in the generators, and $\mathcal{A}_{1,1}[\mathrm{~s}]$ is the algebra generated by s.

Identities. For any $D \geqslant 1$ and any $\vec{k}$, one can define a particular element $1_{\vec{k}} \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}$ such that for any $x \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}^{\prime}}$ :

$$
1_{\vec{k}} \cdot\left(c_{1} ; s_{1}, s_{1}^{\prime}\right) x=x \cdot\left(c_{2} ; s_{2}, s_{2}^{\prime}\right) 1_{\vec{k}}
$$

gives the same result regardless of the values of $c_{1}, s_{1}, s_{1}^{\prime}, c_{2}, s_{2}, s_{2}^{\prime}$, whenever the products are well defined ${ }^{38}$. Any multiplication of a number of elements $1_{\vec{k}(1)}, \ldots 1_{\vec{k}(n)}$ gives the same elements $1_{\vec{k}}$ in the destination space. Choosing $\mathrm{s}=\left\{1_{\vec{k}_{0}}\right\}$, then for any $\vec{k}$ which corresponds to a tree representing a multiplication of copies of $1_{\vec{k}_{0}}$ (Fig. 18), $\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}\left[1_{\vec{k}_{0}}\right]=\left\{1_{\vec{k}}\right\}$ and $\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}\left[1_{D}\right]=\mathbb{C} 1_{\vec{k}}$, and so on.

Trace. The trace $\phi$ is a linear functional from $\mathcal{A}_{D}$ to $\mathbb{C}$, which satisfies the following property for $x \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}^{(1)}}$ and $y \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}^{(2)}}$ :

$$
\phi\left(x \cdot{ }_{(c ; s^{(1)}, s^{(2)})} y\right)=\phi\left(y \cdot{ }_{(c ; s^{(2)}, s^{(1)})} x\right)
$$

whenever the parameters $\vec{k}^{(1)}, \vec{k}^{(2)}, c, s^{(1)}, s^{(2)}$ are such that one of the products is well defined.
The trace acts as follows with respect to the elements $1_{\vec{k}}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi\left(1_{\vec{k}} \cdot\left(c^{L} ; l J^{\prime}\right) x_{1} \cdot\left(c_{1}^{L} ; l_{1}, l_{1}^{\prime}\right) x_{2} \cdots \cdot\left(c_{p}^{L} ; l_{p}, l_{p}^{\prime}\right) x_{p}\right) & =\phi\left(x_{1} \cdot\left(c_{1}^{R} ; r_{1}, r_{1}^{\prime}\right) x_{2} \cdots \cdot\left(c_{p}^{R} ; l_{p}, l_{p}^{\prime}\right) x_{p} \cdot\left(c^{R} ; r, r^{\prime}\right) 1_{\vec{k}}\right) \\
& =\phi\left(x_{1}\right) \phi\left(x_{2}\right) \cdots \phi\left(x_{p}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

whenever the values of the colors and shades involved in the multiplication are such that all elements $x_{1}, \ldots x_{p}$ are multiplied with $1_{\vec{k}}$. Graphically, it means that the thick edge $e$ corresponding to $1_{\vec{k}}$ is connected to the rest of the graph only through its inputs (left of (8.4)) or only through its outputs (upper right in (8.4)), and every $x_{i}$ is connected to $e$ via an edge, see Fig. 19.

Similarly, one may then argue that for any $\vec{k}, 1_{\vec{k}}=1^{\otimes \sum k_{c}}$, where 1 is the usual identity of an algebra.

Figure 19: Graphical representation of the property (8.4).

In particular, for any $x \in \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}$ :

$$
\phi\left(1_{\vec{k}} \cdot\left(c_{1} ; s_{1}, s_{1}^{\prime}\right) x\right)=\phi\left(x \cdot\left(c_{2} ; s_{2}, s_{2}^{\prime}\right) 1_{\vec{k}}\right)=\phi(x)
$$

regardless of the values of $c_{1}, s_{1}, s_{1}^{\prime}, c_{2}, s_{2}, s_{2}^{\prime}$, whenever it is well defined, and for any $\vec{k}$ :

$$
\phi\left(1_{\vec{k}}\right)=1
$$

The trace and melonic graphs. For non-commutative probability spaces, (8.3) corresponds to the property $\phi(x y)=\phi(y x)$ :

1. For any word of elements, one can take the rightmost one and multiply it on the left instead of the right and this will give the same result: the trace is cyclic.
2. Equivalently, one can see $\phi$ as adding the missing multiplication between the input and output of the word (the missing edge in the line graph representing the word), and $\phi$ applied to any word obtained by removing an edge from this graph gives the same value.

These two points of view generalize in the present case as follows: consider a tree $\mathcal{T}$ as in Fig. 18, which represents an element $z$ obtained multiplying $q$ other elements $h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}$.

1. Take any element $x$ formed multiplying some of the $h_{i}$ and which in $z$ has a single multiplied input (in $\mathcal{T}$, the corresponding subtree is incident to a single edge $e$ labeled $\left(c ; s_{1}, s_{2}\right)$, the rest being half-edges). Consider the half-edge which is paired in $z$ with the output $\left(c ; s_{1}\right)$ of $x$ : it corresponds to the input $\left(c, s_{3}\right)$ of some element $y$ involved in the multiplication. The element $z^{\prime}$ obtained by splitting $e$ open an reconnecting $x$ to the graph by joining its output $\left(c ; s_{1}\right)$ with the input $\left(c, s_{3}\right)$ of $y$ is such that $\phi(z)=\phi\left(z^{\prime}\right)$. See Fig. 20.
![img-19.jpeg](img-19.jpeg)

Figure 20: On the left, an element $z^{\prime}$ obtained from $z$ of Fig. 18 performing the operation (8.3) for $w$ versus the rest, and on the right $z^{\prime \prime}$ obtained from $z$ through this operation, this time for the subtree containing $u, w$ versus the subtree containing $x, y, v$. From (8.3), $\phi(z)=\phi\left(z^{\prime}\right)=\phi\left(z^{\prime \prime}\right)$.
2. Equivalently, one can see $\phi$ as adding the missing multiplications between the paired inputs and outputs of $z$. Graphically, each pair of half-edges (the extremities of paths that alternate colored edges and paired inputs and outputs) is replaced by an edge. The result does

not have any pending half-edges and it is a melonic graph g of paired tensors (Sec. 7.3), see Fig. 21. One may therefore express $\phi(z)$ as a quantity of $h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}$, labeled by g:

$$
\phi(z)=\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})
$$

Reciprocally, starting from a melonic graph g of elements $h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}$ and removing a set of edges $E$ containing precisely one edge per cycle alternating colored edges and paired inputs and outputs, one obtains a tree $\mathrm{g}_{: E}$ corresponding to an element $z_{\mathrm{g}_{: E}}$ obtained by multiplication of $h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}$. Doing this for all sets $E$ satisfying this condition, one generates all the different trees obtained by doing the procedure of point 1 above in all possible ways. Applying $\phi$ to any of these elements $z_{\mathrm{g}_{: E}}$ gives the same value $\phi\left(z_{\mathrm{g}_{: E}}\right)=\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})$. The element $z_{\mathrm{g}_{: E}}$ plays a role analogous to "the asymptotics of $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{g}_{: E}}(\vec{H})$ ", see below.

Properties for melonic graphs. Due to the properties of the trace $\phi$ and definition of multiplication between elements, the properties found asymptotically for the moments of paired tensors in Sec. 7.5, Sec. 7.6 and Sec. 7.7 are satisfied here. The quantities $\phi(z)=\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})$ of (8.7) are linear in each $h_{i}$ because $z$ is, and $\phi$ is linear. The property below (8.2) should be compared with Lemma 7.2. (7.28) should then be compared here with (8.6). (7.29) is satisfied here due to (8.3) and (8.4). (7.18) is also satisfied here due to the definition of multiplication of elements. Free cumulants $\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})$ associated to the quantities $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})$ can be defined through the formula (7.31), and the inverse formula (7.33) holds. Prop. 7.3 and Prop. 7.4 are also satisfied for the quantities of this section.

Tensorial probability space. The generalization of a non-commutative probability space called tensorial probability space - is then defined as the data $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}, \phi\right)$ of a space and trace as defined above, where if $\mathcal{A}_{D}=\bigcup_{\vec{k}} \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}$, each non-empty $\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}$ is required to contain $1_{\vec{k}}$. Elements of $\mathcal{A}_{D}$ generalize non-commutative random variables, and the moments of $x \in \mathcal{A}_{D}$ are the $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(x)$ for all melonic ${ }^{39}$ graphs g in copies of $x$. From (8.7) they correspond to the $\phi(z)$ for $z \in \mathcal{G}_{D}[x]$ : $\phi(z)=\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(x)$, but there are in general different elements $z \in \mathcal{G}_{D}[x]$ which correspond to the same moment $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(x)$. Similarly, the joint moments of a set of random variables $\mathrm{s} \subset \mathcal{A}_{D}$ are given by melonic graphs in copies of the random variables in s, namely the $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})$ for all $q \geqslant 1$, all $\vec{h} \in \mathrm{~s}^{q}$, and all melonic graphs g of $\vec{h}$ (non-labeled). They correspond to the $\phi(z)$ for $z \in \mathcal{G}_{D}[\mathrm{~s}]$, again with repetition ${ }^{40}$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{39}$ In the sense of melonic graphs of paired tensors, Sec. 7.3.
    ${ }^{40}$ For non-commutative probability spaces, this repetition occurs when considering more than one random variable: different words in the random variables $h_{1} h_{2} h_{3} \ldots h_{r}$ or $h_{r} h_{1} h_{2} \ldots h_{r-1}$ or $h_{r-1} h_{r} h_{1} \ldots h_{r-2}$ etc correspond with this convention to the same moment. This convention is different from that of [1], where joint moments are defined as the $\phi(z)$ for words $z$ in the random variables.

As for non-commutative random variables, we define convergence in distribution as follows: let $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{(N)}, \phi^{(N)}\right)$ for $N \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}, \phi\right)$ be as introduced above. Consider $x \in \mathcal{A}_{D}$ and for each $N, x_{N} \in \mathcal{A}_{D}^{(N)}$. Then $x_{N}$ is said to converge in distribution to $x$ (written $x_{N} \xrightarrow{\text { dist }} x$ ) if all moments converge:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(x_{N}\right)=\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(x)
$$

for any melonic graph g of any number of copies of $x$. In the same way, $x_{N}^{(1)}, \ldots x_{N}^{(p)} \in \mathcal{A}_{D}^{(N)}$ converge in distribution to $x^{(1)}, \ldots x^{(p)} \in \mathcal{A}_{D}$ if all the joint moments of the former converge towards the joint moments of the latter, that is:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{h}_{N}\right)=\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})
$$

for all $q \geqslant 1$, all $\vec{h}_{N} \in \mathrm{~s}_{N}^{q}$ where $\mathrm{s}_{N}=\left\{x_{N}^{(1)}, \ldots x_{N}^{(p)}\right\}$, and all melonic graph g of $\vec{h}_{N}$. Furthermore, in the equation above, $\vec{h} \in \mathrm{~s}^{q}$ where $\mathrm{s}=\left\{x^{(1)}, \ldots x^{(p)}\right\}$ is such that if $\vec{h}_{N}=\left(x_{N}^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, \ldots, x_{N}^{\left(i_{q}\right)}\right)$, where $i_{1}, \ldots i_{q} \in\{1, \ldots p\}$, then $\vec{h}=\left(x^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, \ldots, x^{\left(i_{q}\right)}\right)$.

# 8.2 Generators in the pure case 

We now specify the generators in the pure case. We assume the existence of some sets of elements $\theta=\left\{t_{a}, t_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\theta}=\left\{\bar{t}_{a}, \bar{t}_{b} \ldots\right\}$. Elements of $\theta$ (resp. $\bar{\theta}$ ) can only be multiplied on the left (resp. right): they have $D$ distinguishable outputs (resp. inputs) labeled by their color $1, \ldots D$. We define the set of tensor products $\mathrm{s}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]=\left\{x \otimes x^{\prime}\right\}_{x \in \theta, x^{\prime} \in \bar{\theta}}$, whose elements have a pair of inputs and outputs of color $c$ for each $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$. We represent graphically an element $x \otimes x^{\prime}$ of $\mathrm{s}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]$ as a thick edge with $x$ labeling the white vertex and $x^{\prime}$ labeling the black vertex.

We consider the set $\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{p}}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]=\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}[\mathrm{~s}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]]$ generated using this set. Its elements correspond to trees as in Fig. 22, but for which the black and white vertices have exactly one incident edge or half-edge of each color $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$ (so the shade can be omitted): see Fig. 22. We also let $\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{p}}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]=\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}[\mathrm{~s}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]]$ and $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]=\mathcal{A}_{D}[\mathrm{~s}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]]$.
![img-21.jpeg](img-21.jpeg)

Figure 22: Example of element of $\mathcal{G}_{3, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{p}}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]$, with $\vec{k}=(4,4,3), \theta=\left\{t_{a}, t_{b}, t_{c}\right\}$, and $\bar{\theta}=\left\{\bar{t}_{a}, \bar{t}_{b}, \bar{t}_{c}\right\}$.
An element of $\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{p}}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]$ built from $n$ generators has $k_{c} \geqslant 1$ for $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$, and a total of $\mathcal{D}=\sum_{c=1}^{D} k_{c}=n(D-1)+1$ inputs and the same number of outputs (see (7.8)). All the elements in $\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{p}}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]$ and in $\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{p}}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]$ for $\vec{k}$ satisfying $\sum k_{c}=\mathcal{D}$ with $\mathcal{D}$ fixed involve the same number $n=(\mathcal{D}-1) /(D-1)$ of generators. In particular, letting $\vec{h}=(1,1,1, \ldots 1)$, one has $\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{h}}^{\mathrm{p}}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]=\mathrm{s}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]$

Generators of identities. Let $1_{D}$ be the particular element $1_{1, \ldots, 1}$ satisfying the properties listed in the previous section (so $1_{D}$ has a single input and output of color $c$ for each $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$ ). Choosing as only generator $\mathrm{s}=\left\{1_{D}\right\}$, then for any $\vec{k}$ which correspond to a tree representing a multiplication of pure generators (Fig. 22), one has $\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}\left[1_{D}\right]=\left\{1_{\vec{k}}\right\}, \mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}\left[1_{D}\right]=\mathbb{C} 1_{\vec{k}}$, etc.

Now considering the generating set $\mathrm{s}=\mathrm{s}[\theta, \bar{\theta}] \cup\left\{1_{D}\right\}$, each $\mathcal{G}_{D, \bar{k}}^{\mathrm{p}}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]$ is in particular supplemented with the element $1_{\bar{k}}$ (but also all elements generated by some copies of $1_{D}$ and some elements of $\mathrm{s}[\theta, \bar{\theta}]$ ). We let $\mathcal{G}_{D, \bar{k}}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\theta, \bar{\theta} ; 1_{D}\right]=\mathcal{G}_{D, \bar{k}}[\mathrm{~s}]$ and similarly for $\mathcal{A}_{D, \bar{k}}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\theta, \bar{\theta} ; 1_{D}\right]$ and $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\theta, \bar{\theta} ; 1_{D}\right]$.

Remark 8.1. In this construction the $t$ and $\bar{t}$ are not the generators themselves, as they do not belong to the generated space: they can be seen as "pre-generators". One could instead add a color 0 which would play a special role, and consider directly the space generated by multiplication of the $t$ and $\bar{t}$ themselves, but then the trace would only be defined on the subspace for which each cycle alternating colored edges and thick edges has the same number of black and white vertices. The advantage of our approach is that one can treat the identity on the same level as the generators, and the constructions for the mixed and pure cases only differ by the choice of generators.

The trace and melonic graphs. With this choice of generating set, the points 1 and 2 of the homonymous paragraph of Sec. 8.1 are modified as follows:

1. The shade is now trivial and one can simply follow the paths which alternate thick edges and edges of color $c$.
2. Here, replacing the paired half-edges by full edges, one obtains a melonic graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ in the usual sense ${ }^{41}$, whose canonical pairing is given by the thick edges, and one may express $\phi(z)$ in terms of the $\vec{x}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}$ which compose the generators $x_{1} \otimes x_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, x_{n} \otimes x_{n}^{\prime}$ multiplied to form $z$, as:

$$
\phi(z)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}\right)
$$

Reciprocally, starting from a melonic graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with canonical pairing given by the thick edges, and removing a set of edges $E$ containing precisely one edge per cycle alternating colored edges and canonical pairs, one obtains a tree $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{\backslash E}$ of the kind of Fig. 22.

Pure random tensors and convergence. Consider the trace $\phi^{(N)}=\frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}[\operatorname{Tr}(\cdot)]$, where $\operatorname{Tr}=$ $\operatorname{Tr}_{\text {id }_{j}}$ has been defined in (7.6). A pure tensor $(T, \bar{T})$, together with the rescaled identity $\mathbb{1}_{D}=$ $\frac{1}{\bar{N}^{D-1}}$, generates a tensorial probability space:

$$
\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[T, \bar{T} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right], \phi^{(N)}\right)
$$

The moments of the generator $T \otimes \bar{T}$ correspond to the $\phi^{(N)}(z)$ for $z \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}[T, \bar{T}]$, that is, the $\frac{1}{N} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})=\frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})\right]$ for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ purely connected and melonic, and the family of moments converges ${ }^{42}$ :

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})\right]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})
$$

for all $n \geqslant 1$ and all $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ purely connected and melonic. The $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})$ can be seen as the moments of the generator $t \otimes \bar{t}$ of a tensorial probability space $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[t, \bar{t} ; 1_{D}\right], \phi\right)$ : for $z \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}[t, \bar{t}]$, we set $\phi(z)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})$ if joining the paired half-edges of the tree corresponding to $z$, one obtains the graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. We conclude that $(T, \bar{T})$ converges in distribution to $(t, \bar{t})$ (in the sense that $T \otimes \bar{T}$ converges in distribution to $t \otimes \bar{t}$ ). This generalizes for a collection of pure random tensors and their joint convergence to a collection of pregenerators of a tensorial probability space. As an example, a complex pure Gaussian tensor converges in distribution in this sense, to a $(t, \bar{t})$ with moments $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(t, \bar{t})=1$ (Thm. 5.5).

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{41}$ That is, a purely connected melonic graph as in Sec. 5.2 whose canonical pairing is the identity, and not a more general melonic graph of paired tensors as in Sec. 7.3.
    ${ }^{42}$ Both for finite $N$ and at the limit, only one representative per equivalence classe under $\sim_{p}$ must be considered in the family of moments.

Tensor freeness in the pure case. As specified in Sec. 8.1, given some sets $\theta=\left\{t_{a}, t_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\theta}=\left\{\bar{t}_{a}, \bar{t}_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and the tensorial probability space $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\theta, \bar{\theta} ; 1_{D}\right], \phi\right)$ that they generate together with $1_{D}$, all the quantities $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}, \phi, \phi_{\mathbf{g}}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}, \varkappa_{\mathbf{g}}$ obtained considering tensor asymptotics of pure tensors $T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}, T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots$ are now understood in terms of traces of elements of $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\theta, \bar{\theta} ; 1_{D}\right], \phi\right)$, and they satisfy the same properties as those derived in Sec. 7.5, Sec. 7.6 and Sec. 7.7. As a consequence, Thm. 7.6 can be reformulated as an equivalence of conditions regarding the quantities $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}, \phi, \phi_{\mathbf{g}}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}, \varkappa_{\mathbf{g}}$ defined for elements of $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\theta, \bar{\theta} ; 1_{D}\right], \phi\right)$. Asymptotic tensor freeness of pure tensors $T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}, T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b} \ldots$ can then be understood as tensor freeness of the limiting random variables (or the subspaces they generate).

We do not state again the equivalence for the case where there exists $1 \leqslant i \leqslant n$ such that $\bar{x}_{i} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$, as for this case things remain unchanged.
Theorem 8.2 (Pure tensor freeness). The following statements are equivalent:

1. For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ purely connected and melonic with canonical pairing the identity, and any $\vec{x} \in\left\{t_{a}, t_{b} \ldots\right\}^{n}$ and $\overrightarrow{x^{\prime}} \in\left\{\bar{t}_{a}, \bar{t}_{b} \ldots\right\}^{n}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(\vec{x}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}\right)=0$ whenever $x_{i} \neq x_{j}$ or $x_{i}^{\prime} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$, or $\bar{x}_{i} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$ for some $i \neq j$.
2. For any $q \geqslant 2$, any $h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}$ such that $\forall 1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q, h_{\ell} \in \mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[x_{\ell}, \bar{x}_{\ell} ; 1_{D}\right]$ where $\left(x_{\ell}, \bar{x}_{\ell}\right) \in$ $\left\{\left(t_{a}, \bar{t}_{a}\right),\left(t_{b}, \bar{t}_{b}\right) \ldots\right\}$, and any connected melonic graph $\mathbf{g}$ of $\vec{h}, \varkappa_{\mathbf{g}}(\vec{h})=0$ whenever there exists $1 \leqslant \ell<\ell^{\prime} \leqslant q$ such that $\left(x_{\ell}, \bar{x}_{\ell}\right) \neq\left(x_{\ell^{\prime}}, \bar{x}_{\ell^{\prime}}\right)$.
3. For any $q \geqslant 2$, any $h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}$ such that for $1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q, h_{\ell} \in \mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[x_{\ell}, \bar{x}_{\ell} ; 1_{D}\right]$ where $\left(x_{\ell}, \bar{x}_{\ell}\right) \in$ $\left\{\left(t_{a}, \bar{t}_{a}\right),\left(t_{b}, \bar{t}_{b}\right) \ldots\right\}$, and any connected melonic graph $\mathbf{g}$ of $h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}, \phi_{\mathbf{g}}(\vec{h})=0$ whenever $(\mathbf{g}, \vec{h})$ is almost alternating and for all $\ell, \phi\left(h_{\ell}\right)=0$.

In analogy with usual freeness, by definition, the $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[t_{a}, \bar{t}_{a} ; 1_{D}\right], \mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[t_{b}, \bar{t}_{b} ; 1_{D}\right] \ldots$ are said to be tensorially free if 2 and 3 are satisfied. The equivalence between 2 and 3 of this theorem should then be compared to Thm. 11.16 of [1], and that between 1 and 2 with Thm. 11.20 of [1].

The proof of Thm. 8.2 is similar to that of Thm. 7.6, with the modifications pointed out in Rk. C. 2 and Rk. C.6. There is a formulation analogous to Thm. 7.6, which involves the $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[x_{\ell}, \bar{x}_{\ell}\right]$ instead of the $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[x_{\ell}, \bar{x}_{\ell} ; 1_{D}\right]$, but we do not state it here.

# 8.3 Generators in the mixed case 

We assume the existence of some set $\mathrm{s}_{0}=\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{p}\right\}$ of elements (which we may also call "pregenerators") with $D$ distinguishable outputs (resp. inputs) labeled by their color $1, \ldots D$. We define the set of ordered tensor products $\mathbf{s}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0}\right]=\left\{a_{i_{1}} \otimes a_{i_{2}} \otimes \cdots a_{i_{r}}\right\}_{r \geqslant 1, i_{s} \in\{1, \ldots p\}}$, whose elements have by convention a pairing of the inputs and outputs of color $c$ for each $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$, defined in the same way as (7.7): the output of $a_{i_{1}} \otimes a_{i_{2}} \otimes \cdots a_{i_{r}}$ labeled $(c, s)$ corresponds to the output of color $c$ of $a_{i_{s}}$, and the paired input labeled $(c, s)$ corresponds to the input of color $c$ of $a_{i_{s-1}}$. We represent graphically such an element $a_{i_{1}} \otimes a_{i_{2}} \otimes \cdots a_{i_{r}}$ of $\mathrm{s}\left[a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{p}\right]$ as a cycle consisting alternatively of thick edges labeled cyclically from 1 to $r$ and blue blobs (Fig. 23) and with $a_{i_{k}}$ labeling the thick edge number $k$, for $1 \leqslant k \leqslant r$.
![img-22.jpeg](img-22.jpeg)

Figure 23: Graphical representation of the generators in the mixed case.

We let $\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0}\right]=\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}\left[\mathrm{~s}\left[\mathrm{~s}_{0}\right]\right]$ generated from the set $\mathrm{s}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0}\right]$. Its elements correspond to trees as in Fig. 18, but for which the black and white vertices incident to a given thick edge have the same number of incident edges or half-edges of each color $1 \leqslant c \leqslant D$ : see Fig. 24. Each thick edge may be replaced by a cycle as in Fig. 23. We define $\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0}\right]$ and $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0}\right]$ in the same way.
![img-23.jpeg](img-23.jpeg)

Figure 24: Multiplication of generators in the mixed case: Example of element of $\mathcal{G}_{3, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0}\right]$, with $\vec{k}=(5,6,5)$ and obtained multiplying some generators $x, y, z$ for $\mathrm{s}_{0}=\{a, b\}$. The generators are $x=a, y=b \otimes a$ and $z=a \otimes b \otimes b$. For the top diagram, around every vertex, the shade of each color grows from top to bottom. The pregenerators $a, b$ are shown explicitly on the bottom diagram, using the representation of Fig. 23.

Identities. We define $\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0} ; 1_{D}\right]=\mathcal{G}_{D, \vec{k}}\left[\mathrm{~s}\left[\mathrm{~s}_{0}\right] \cup\left\{1_{D}\right\}\right]$ and similarly for $\mathcal{A}_{D, \vec{k}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0} ; 1_{D}\right]$ and $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0} ; 1_{D}\right]$. Note that for every $r \geqslant 1, \mathcal{G}_{D}\left[1_{D}\right]$ contains $1_{r, r, \ldots r}$, which has the same number of inputs of each color as an element $a_{i_{1}} \otimes a_{i_{2}} \otimes \cdots a_{i_{r}} \in \mathrm{~s}\left[\mathrm{~s}_{0}\right]$. Note also that due to the convention for the pairing of indices, an element of $\mathrm{s}\left[1_{D}\right]$ formed of $r$ copies of $1_{D}$ differs from $1_{r, r, \ldots r}$.
Remark 8.3. In this construction, the set of generators is $\mathrm{s}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0}\right]$ and not $\mathrm{s}_{0}$ (which is only a strict subset of $\mathrm{s}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0}\right]$ ). It is not entirely satisfying to use an infinite family of generators for a finite set of pregenerators (leading also to issues for instance when considering moments, see below). As for the pure case, one could instead add a color 0 which plays the role of the blue blobs. This allows generating the elements in $\mathrm{s}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0}\right]$ by multiplication of elements of $\mathrm{s}_{0}$ themselves, using the new color 0, but then the same issue as for the pure case (Rk. 8.1) occurs regarding the trace, and there is an additional issue due to the identities.

The trace and melonic graphs. With this choice of generating set, point 2 of the homonymous paragraph of Sec. 8.1 is modified as follows:
2. Here, if one replaces paired half-edges by full edges and replaces the thick edges by the cycles alternating thick edges and blue blobs (Figs. 23 and 24), one obtains ${ }^{43}$ a connected graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$, and the canonical pairing of $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is given by the blue blobs, see Fig. 25. One may then express $\phi(z)$ in terms of the $n \geqslant q$ elements of $\mathrm{s}_{0}=\left\{a_{1}, \ldots, a_{p}\right\}$ which compose the $q$ generators involved in the multiplication leading to $z$. There is a $\vec{m} \in \mathrm{~s}_{0}^{\mathrm{n}}$ such that:

$$
\phi(z)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})
$$

Reciprocally, starting from $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ connected with $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic with canonical pairing represented by blue blobs and removing a set of edges $E$ containing precisely one edge per cycle alternating colored edges and canonical pairs, one obtains a tree $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{\backslash E}$ of the kind of Fig. 24.

Figure 25: In the mixed case, when the graphical representation of the generators is made explicit (bottom of Fig. 24), the trace can be seen as connecting the paired half-edges (extremities of paths alternating canonical pairs and edges of a given color) to obtain a connected graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ such that $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic, with canonical pairing given by the blue blobs.

Mixed random tensors and convergence. Consider the trace $\phi^{(N)}=\frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}[\operatorname{Tr}(\cdot)]$, where $\operatorname{Tr}=\operatorname{Tr}_{\text {id }}$, has been defined in (7.6). A mixed tensor $A$, together with the rescaled identity $\mathbb{1}_{D}=\frac{1^{\otimes D}}{N^{D-1}}$, generates a tensorial probability space:

$$
\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[A ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right], \phi^{(N)}\right)
$$

In the mixed case, we modify slightly the notion of moments: we define the moments of $A$ as a pregenerator to be the family of joint moments of the elements of $\mathrm{s}[A]$, whose elements are of the form (7.7). They consist in the $\phi^{(N)}(z)$ for $z \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\mathcal{G}_{D}[\mathrm{~s}[A]]$, that is, the $\frac{1}{N} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(A)=\frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)\right]$ for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ connected satisfying $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$, and the family of joint moments converges ${ }^{44}$ :

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)\right]=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)
$$

for all $n \geqslant 1$ and all $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected satisfying $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$. The $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)$ can be seen as the moments of the pregenerator $a$ of a tensorial probability space $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[a ; 1_{D}\right], \phi\right)$ : for $z \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}[a]$, we set $\phi(z)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)$ if joining the paired half-edges of the tree corresponding to $z$ and making the cyclic structure of the generators explicit, one obtains the graph $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. We conclude that $\mathrm{s}[A]$ converges in distribution to $\mathrm{s}[a]$, which we call convergence in distribution of $A$ to $a$, as pregenerators. This generalizes for a collection of mixed random tensors and their joint convergence to a collection of pregenerators of a tensorial probability space. As an example, the mixed Wishart tensor $W$ of Sec. 5.5 converges in distribution in this sense, to a pregenerator $w$ with moments $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(w)=1(6.47)$.

Another point of view on non-commutative probability spaces. For $D=1$, the trace of an element $z \in \mathcal{G}_{1}^{\mathrm{m}}[a]$ is of the form $\phi(z)=\varphi_{w}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)$, where $\sigma$ is a connected cycle alternating $n$ thick edges representing copies of $a$ and $n$ edges of color 1 . If $z$ is obtained by multiplying only copies of the generator $a, z \in \mathcal{G}_{1}[a]$, the blue blobs coincide with the thick edges:

$$
\phi\left(a^{n}\right)=\varphi_{\gamma}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)
$$

where $\gamma=(12 \ldots n) \in S_{n}$. They correspond to the moments of $a$ as an element of $\left(\mathcal{A}_{1}^{\mathrm{m}}[a ; 1], \phi\right)$. On the other hand, if $z$ involves other generators $a^{\otimes r}$, one still gets a connected cycle alternating thick edges and edges of color 1 , but with blue blobs representing a non-crossing pairing of the black and white vertices. Since one retains only one representative per graph (i.e. per equivalence class under $\sim_{m}$ ), any multiplication of generators involving a total of $n$ copies of $a$ corresponds to the same moment $\phi\left(a^{n}\right)=\varphi_{\gamma}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)(8.16)$. This additional degeneracy is not present for $D>1$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{44}$ Both for finite $N$ and at the limit, only one representative per equivalence classe under $\sim_{m}$ must be considered in the family of moments.

as then the canonical pairing of $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is unique and introducing tensor products of copies of $a$ is required because the canonical pairs can differ from the thick edges. Therefore, the moments of $a$ (both as a generator and as a pregenerator) in the tensorial probability space $\left(\mathcal{A}_{1}^{\mathrm{m}}[a ; 1], \phi\right)$ are the same as those of the random variable $a$ in the non-commutative probability space $(\mathcal{A}[a, 1], \phi)$.

Tensor freeness in the mixed case. As specified in Sec. 8.1, given some set $\mathrm{s}_{0}=\{a, b \ldots\}$ and the tensorial probability space $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0} ; 1_{D}\right], \phi\right)$, all the quantities $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}} ; \phi, \phi_{\mathrm{g}}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}, \varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}$ obtained considering tensor asymptotics of mixed tensors $A, B \ldots$ are now understood in terms of traces of elements of $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0} ; 1_{D}\right], \phi\right)$, and they satisfy the same properties as those derived in Sec. 7.5, Sec. 7.6 and Sec. 7.7. Thm. 7.5 can therefore be reformulated as an equivalence of conditions regarding the quantities $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}} ; \phi, \phi_{\mathrm{g}}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}, \varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}$ for elements of $\left(\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[\mathrm{s}_{0} ; 1_{D}\right], \phi\right)$. Asymptotic tensor freeness of mixed tensors $A, B \ldots$ can then be understood as tensor freeness of the limiting random variables (or the subspaces they generate).

We do not state again the equivalence for the case where there exists $1 \leqslant i \leqslant n$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{\eta(i)}, \eta$ being the canonical pairing of $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ in the first statement, as for this case things remain unchanged.

Theorem 8.4 (Mixed tensor freeness). The following statements are equivalent:

1. For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected and with $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$, and any $\tilde{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right) \in$ $\{a, b \ldots\}^{n}$ such that for all $i, m_{i}=m_{\eta(i)}$, where $\eta$ is the canonical pairing of $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$, $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\tilde{m})=0$ whenever there exists $1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$.
2. For any $q \geqslant 2$, any $h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}$ such that $\forall 1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q, h_{\ell} \in \mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[q_{\ell} ; 1_{D}\right]$ with $q_{\ell} \in\{a, b \ldots\}$, and any connected melonic graph $\mathbf{g}$ of $\tilde{h}, \varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\tilde{h})=0$ whenever $\exists \ell<\ell^{\prime}$ such that $q_{\ell} \neq q_{\ell^{\prime}}$.
3. For any $q \geqslant 2$, any $h_{1}, \ldots h_{q}$ such that for $1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q, h_{\ell} \in \mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[q_{\ell} ; 1_{D}\right]$ with $q_{\ell} \in\{a, b \ldots\}$, and any connected melonic graph $\mathbf{g}$ of $\tilde{h}, \phi_{\mathbf{g}}(\tilde{h})=0$ whenever $(\mathbf{g}, \tilde{h})$ is almost alternating and for every $\ell, \phi\left(h_{\ell}\right)=0$.

See the comments below Thm. 8.2.

# 8.3.1 Composition and graph operad 

One may alternatively describe the limiting spaces using composition of diagrams instead of multiplication. The properties of composition at the limit are the same as those for the finite $N$ quantities $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}, \operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}}, \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{, \mathrm{E}}}, \operatorname{Tr}_{\mathbf{g}, \mathrm{g}}$, described in Sec. 7.5 and Sec. 7.6. The construction should be analogous to the operad of graph operations described by Male in [75], with differences such as: only the thick edges are replaces by elements from the space, the colored edges represent multiplication and instead of one input and output (a source and a sink in [75]), there are now a certain number of inputs and outputs of the same shade. We do not expect these differences to affect the mathematical properties described in [75].

# A Proofs of Sec. 4 

We gather here the proofs of statements in Sec. 4.

## A. 1 Proofs of Sec. 4.1.2

Proof of Thm. 4.5: We start by proving the linear independence in the mixed case. We consider $n_{\max }$ and the family $\operatorname{Tr}_{[\sigma]_{m}}$ of trace-invariants for $[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m} \in S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{m}$ with $n \leqslant n_{\max }$, a set of corresponding complex numbers $\lambda_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}$, and the linear combination:

$$
\sum_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m} \in \bigcup_{n \leqslant N} S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{m}} \lambda_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}} \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}(A)=0, \quad \forall A \in M_{N}(\mathbb{C})^{\otimes D}
$$

But then trivially, if $A$ is a complex random tensor with finite moments, this implies:

$$
\sum_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m} \in \bigcup_{n \leqslant N} S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{m}} \lambda_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}(A) \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}(\bar{A})\right]=0
$$

and in order to conclude it is enough to exhibit a particular random tensor such that the covariance matrix:

$$
G=\left\{\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}(A) \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}(\bar{A})\right]\right\}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m} \in \bigcup_{n \leqslant N} S_{n}^{D} / \sim_{m}}
$$

is invertible for $N$ large enough. Let us take $A \in M_{N}(\mathbb{C})^{\otimes D}$ distributed according to the Ginibre ensemble, that is the $N^{2 D}$ components $A_{i^{1} \ldots i^{D} \ldots j^{1} \ldots j^{D}}$ are independent complex Gaussians with covariance $\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{A}_{\bar{i} \bar{j}} A_{\bar{k} \bar{j}}\right]=\prod_{i=1}^{D} \delta_{i^{i}}, k^{i} \delta_{j^{i}}, l^{i} / N^{D}$. The only non zero elements of the covariance matrix $G$ are obtained from the Wick theorem as:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}(A) \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}(\bar{A})\right]=\sum_{\eta \in S_{n}} N^{\sum_{c=1}^{D} \#\left(\sigma_{c} \eta \tau_{c}^{-1} \eta^{-1}\right)-n D}
$$

where the permutation $\eta$ encodes the Wick pairings between $A$ s and $\bar{A}$ s. In terms of the distance function $d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right)(4.10)$. It becomes:

$$
G_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}=\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}(A) \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}(\bar{A})\right]=C_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}} N^{-d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}\right)}\left(1+O\left(N^{-1}\right)\right)
$$

where $C_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{m}}>0$ is the number of $\eta \in S_{n}$ for which the distance is attained. Since $d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right)=0$, the diagonal terms are strictly positive $C_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m},[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{m}}>0$ and of order 1 , while the off-diagonal terms are all suppressed in $1 / N$, as $d_{\mathrm{m}}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{\mathrm{m}},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{\mathrm{m}}\right) \geqslant 1$ for any two different classes. The following lemma completes the proof, as for $N$ larger enough, $G$ satisfies the inequality in the lemma.

Lemma A.1. Let $A=\left\{a_{i j}\right\}$ be a $N \times N$ Hermitian matrix with positive diagonal entries $a_{i i}>0$. If all off-diagonal entries satisfy $\left|a_{i j}\right| \leqslant \sqrt{a_{i i} a_{j j}} / N$, then $A$ is positive definite and invertible
Proof. Without loss of generality, we may assume that $A$ has diagonal entries equal to one (otherwise we multiply $A$ on the left and right by the matrix $\left\{a_{i i}^{-1 / 2} \delta_{i j}\right\}$ ) and off-diagonal entries bounded as $\left|a_{i j}\right| \leqslant 1 / N, i \neq j$. We split $A=\mathbb{1}+\bar{A}$, where $\bar{A}$ has null diagonal and operator-norm less than 1 , as it is bounded by the Frobenius norm, $\|\bar{A}\|_{\mathrm{op}}^{2} \leqslant \operatorname{Tr}\left(\bar{A}^{2}\right)<1$. Therefore, $\mathbb{1}+\bar{A}$ is positive-definite and $(\mathbb{1}+\bar{A})^{-1}=\sum_{k \geqslant 0} A^{k}$, where the series converges in operator norm.

The proof is similar in the pure case, choosing $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$ to be independent, distributed complex Gaussians with covariances $\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{T}_{\bar{i}} T_{\bar{k}}\right]=\prod_{c=1}^{D} \delta_{i^{c}, k^{c}} / N^{D / 2}$ and evaluating the covariance matrix:

$$
H_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{p},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}}=\mathbb{E}_{T_{1}, T_{2}}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{p}}\left(T_{2}, T_{1}\right) \operatorname{Tr}_{[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}}\left(\bar{T}_{1}, \bar{T}_{2}\right)\right]=D_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{p},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}} N^{-d_{p}\left([\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{p},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}\right)}\left(1+O\left(N^{-1}\right)\right)
$$

where $D_{[\boldsymbol{\sigma}]_{p},[\boldsymbol{\tau}]_{p}}>0$ is the number of $\eta, \nu \in S_{n}$ for which the distance is attained.

# A. 2 Proof of Thm. 4.10
