In the mixed case, due to the LU-invariance of $B$, we can write $Z_{A}(B)$ in terms of the tensor HCIZ integral [33,34]. Denoting with $U=U^{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes U^{D}$ and $d U=d U^{1} \ldots d U^{D}$, where $d U^{c}$ denotes the Haar measure on $U(N)$, from the moment-cumulant relation (2.8) we have:

$$
\left.\frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial z^{n}} \log \mathbb{E}_{A} \mathbb{E}_{U}\left[e^{z \operatorname{Tr}\left(B^{T} U A U^{1}\right)}\right]\right|_{z=0}=\sum_{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n)} \lambda_{\pi} \prod_{G \in \pi} \mathbb{E}_{A}\left[\int d U\left[\sum_{\vec{i}, \vec{j}, \vec{k}, \vec{b}} B_{\vec{i}, \vec{j}} U_{\vec{i}, \vec{d}} A_{\vec{k}, \vec{b}} \overline{U_{\vec{j}, \vec{b}}}\right]^{[G]}\right]
$$

The integral over the unitary group is computed from (2.11):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial z^{n}} \log Z_{A}(z B)\right|_{z=0} \\
& =\sum_{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n)} \lambda_{\pi} \prod_{G \in \pi} \sum_{\sigma_{|G|}, \tau_{|G|} \in S_{|G|}^{D}} \sum_{i, j, a, b}\left(\prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c \mid G} \tau_{c \mid G}^{-1}\right) \delta_{i \bar{\zeta}_{J_{c}}^{c} c_{c G}(s)} \delta_{a \bar{\zeta}_{k} k_{c} c_{c G}(s)}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{s \geqslant 1}^{|G|} A_{\vec{a}_{s}, \vec{b}_{s}} B_{\vec{i}_{s}, \vec{j}_{s}}\right] \\
& =\sum_{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n)} \lambda_{\pi} \prod_{G \in \pi} \sum_{\sigma_{|G|}, \tau_{|G|} \in S_{|G|}^{D}}\left(\prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c \mid G} \tau_{c \mid G}^{-1}\right)\right) \operatorname{Tr}_{\sigma_{|G|}}(B) \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\tau_{|G|}}(A)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(B)$ factors over the mixed connected components in $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and the summand is invariant under relabelings, we can exchange the sum over partitions with the ones over permutations to obtain:

$$
\left.\frac{\partial^{n}}{\partial z^{n}} \log Z_{A}(z B)\right|_{z=0}=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{C}^{D}} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(B) \sum_{\substack{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})}} \lambda_{\pi} \prod_{G \in \pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{|G}}(A)\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c \mid G} \tau_{c \mid G}^{-1}\right)
$$

In the pure case, similar manipulations lead to the similar formulae, but with the "mixed" replaced by "pure". In detail, we start from:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\partial_{z}^{n} \partial_{\bar{z}}^{n} \log \mathbb{E}_{T, \bar{T}}\left[e^{z J \cdot T+\bar{z} \bar{J} \cdot \bar{T}}\right]\right|_{z=\bar{z}=0} \\
& \quad=\sum_{\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n})} \lambda_{\Pi} \prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \mathbb{E}_{T, \bar{T}}\left[\int d U\left[\sum_{\overrightarrow{i d}} J_{\vec{i}} U_{\vec{i}, \vec{d}} T_{\vec{d}}\right]^{[B]}\left[\sum_{\overrightarrow{j b}} \overrightarrow{J_{\vec{j}} U_{\vec{j}, \vec{b}} \bar{T}_{\vec{b}}}\right]^{[\bar{B}]}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and we integrate over the unitary group. In this context, it is convenient to regard the permutations in (2.11) as bijective mappings from the white elements to the black ones, that is $s \rightarrow \overline{\sigma_{c}}(s)$. Denoting $S_{B, \bar{B}}$ the set of bijections from the elements of $B$ to the ones of $\bar{B}$, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\partial_{z}^{n} \partial_{\bar{z}}^{n} \log \mathbb{E}_{T, \bar{T}}\left[e^{z J \cdot T+\bar{z} \bar{J} \cdot \bar{T}}\right]\right|_{z=\bar{z}=0}=\sum_{\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n})} \lambda_{\Pi} \prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \sum_{\sigma_{|B|}, \tau_{|B|} \in S_{B, \bar{B}}^{D}} \\
& \sum_{i, j, a, b}\left(\prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c \mid B} \tau_{c \mid B}^{-1}\right) \delta_{i \bar{\zeta}_{J_{c}^{c}} c_{c \mid B}(s)} \delta_{a \bar{\zeta}_{k} k_{c} c_{c \mid B}(s)}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{s \geqslant 1}^{|B|} T_{\vec{a}_{s}} \bar{T}_{\vec{b}_{s}} J_{\vec{i}_{s}} \bar{J}_{\vec{j}_{s}}\right] \\
& =\sum_{\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n})} \lambda_{\Pi} \prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \sum_{\sigma_{|B|}, \tau_{|B|} \in S_{B, \bar{B}}^{D}}\left(\prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c \mid B} \tau_{c \mid B}^{-1}\right) \operatorname{Tr}_{\sigma_{|B|}}(J, \bar{J}) \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\tau_{|B|}}(T, \bar{T})\right]\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

and we observe that $\sigma_{c \mid B} \tau_{c \mid B}^{-1}$ is a permutation of the black elements having the same cycle-type as the permutation $\tau_{c \mid B}^{-1} \sigma_{c \mid B}$ of the white ones. The invariants now factor over the pure connected

components, and when commuting the sum over $\Pi$ with the ones over $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ and $\boldsymbol{\tau}$, the compatibility condition that $\left.\boldsymbol{\sigma}\right|_{B},\left.\boldsymbol{\tau}\right|_{B}$ correspond to the parts of $\Pi$ implies that $\Pi$ must be coarser that the partitions in pure connected components $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})$, leading to:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \partial_{z}^{n} \partial_{z}^{0} \log \mathbb{E}_{T, \bar{T}}\left[\left.e^{z J \cdot T+\bar{z} \cdot \bar{T}}\right]\right|_{z=\bar{z}=0} \\
& \quad=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{c, n}^{D}} \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(J, \bar{J}) \sum_{\substack{\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n}) \\
\Pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}) \vee \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})}} \lambda_{\Pi} \prod_{G=B \cup \bar{B} \in \Pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{| B}}(T, \bar{T})\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c|_{B}} \tau_{c|_{B}}^{-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In order to invert the relations we start by averaging the expectations over the unitary group:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)\right]=\mathbb{E}_{A}\left[\int d U \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(U A U^{\dagger}\right)\right], \quad \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)\right]=\mathbb{E}_{T, \bar{T}}\left[\int d U \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(U T, \bar{T} U^{\dagger}\right)\right]
$$

which is, using the definition (4.2) of the trace-invariants and (2.11):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)\right] & =\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\nu} \in S_{c}^{D}} \sum_{i, j, a, b} \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{s=1}^{n} A_{\vec{a}_{s} \mid \vec{b}_{s}}\right] \prod_{c, s} \delta_{\vec{c}_{s} \mid \vec{b}_{c}(s)} \delta_{\vec{c}_{s} \mid \vec{b}_{c}(s)} \delta_{a_{s}^{c} \mid b_{c}^{c}(s)} W^{(N)}\left(\tau_{c} \nu_{c}^{-1}\right) \\
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(T, \bar{T})\right] & =\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\nu} \in S_{c}^{D}} \sum_{i, j, a, b} \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{s=1}^{n} T_{\vec{a}_{s}} \bar{T}_{\vec{b}_{s}}\right] \prod_{c, s} \delta_{\vec{c}_{s} \mid \vec{b}_{c}(s)} \delta_{\vec{c}_{c} \mid \vec{b}_{c}(s)} \delta_{a_{s}^{c} \mid b_{c}^{c}(s)} W^{(N)}\left(\tau_{c} \nu_{c}^{-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where again, in the pure case, the sum should be considered as a sum over bijections between the white and the black vertices. Recalling that $\sum_{c=1}^{D} \#\left(\sigma_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}\right)=n D-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})$, this is:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(A)\right]=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}} N^{n D-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})} \mathcal{G}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}[A], \quad \mathcal{G}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}[A]=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\nu} \in S_{n}^{D}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}(A)\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\nu_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}\right)
$$

and similarly for the pure case. We define the multiplicative extension in the mixed case:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\prod_{G \in \pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{| G}}(A)\right] & =\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D} \\
\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}) \leqslant \pi}} N^{n D-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})} \mathcal{G}_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}[A] \\
\mathcal{G}_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}[A] & =\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\nu} \in S_{c}^{D} \\
\pi \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\nu})}} \prod_{G \in \pi} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\nu}_{| G}}(A)\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\nu_{c|_{G}} \tau_{c|_{G}}^{-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

while in the pure case we have $\Pi \in \mathcal{P}(n, \bar{n})$ and $\Pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$. Comapring with (4.27) leads to:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{m}[A]=\sum_{\substack{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \lambda_{\pi} \mathcal{G}_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\sigma}}[A], \quad \mathcal{G}_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\sigma}}[A]=\sum_{\substack{\pi^{\prime} \in \mathcal{P}(n) \\ \pi \geqslant \pi^{\prime} \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}} \mathcal{K}_{\pi^{\prime}, \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{m}[A]
$$

where the last equality follows by Möebius inversion. The pure case is similar.

# B Proofs of Sec. 6
## B. 1 Proof of Thm. 6.2

General asymptotic. The finite $N$ free cumulants in Thm. 6.2 simplify for a purely connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$, as the sum over partitions reduces to one term corresponding to the one set partition.

Expressing it in terms of classical cumulants we have:

$$
\left.\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]\right|_{K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1}=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n, n}^{D}} \sum_{\pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})} \Phi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}[T, \bar{T}] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}\right)
$$

where all the partitions encountered in this proof are bipartite, and all the permutations should be seen as mapping white to black vertices.

The Gaussian scaling hypothesis (6.10) yields:

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{n-\sum_{B \in \pi} \min d\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{[B}, \eta_{B}\right)}} \Phi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}[T, \bar{T}]=\varphi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}(t, \bar{t})
$$

where each minimum is taken over the $\eta_{B} \in S_{|B|}$ with $K_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{]_{B}}, \eta_{B}\right)=1$. We let:

$$
H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}=\left\{\eta \in S_{n} \mid \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\eta) \leqslant \pi \quad \text { and } \quad \forall B \cup \bar{B} \in \pi, K_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{]_{B}}, \eta_{]_{B}}\right)=1\right\}
$$

the sets of permutations over which the minimum in the Gaussian scaling is taken, that is:

$$
\sum_{B \in \pi} \min _{\eta_{B} \in S_{|B|}, K_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{]_{B}}, \eta_{B}\right)=1} d\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{]_{B}}, \eta_{B}\right)=\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}} \sum_{B \in \pi} d\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{]_{B}}, \eta_{]_{B}}\right)=\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}} d(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \eta)
$$

Taking into account that asymptotically the Weingarten functions behave as:

$$
\prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}\right)=N^{-n D-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})} \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)\left(1+O\left(N^{-2}\right)\right)
$$

we obtain the $N \rightarrow \infty$ asymptotic behaviour of the finite $N$ free cumulant:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}[T, \bar{T}]=\frac{1}{N^{n D}} \sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}} \sum_{\pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})}\left[\varphi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}(t, \bar{t}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right) N^{r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-\Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})}+o\left(N^{r(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-\Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})}\right)\right]
$$

where $\Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})=d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})+\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}} d(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \eta)-\min _{\eta_{0} \in S_{n}} d\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta_{0}\right)$. Now, for any $\eta \in S_{n}$, one has the $D$-fold triangular inequality:

$$
d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})+d(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \eta) \geqslant d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)
$$

with equality if and only if $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$. It follows that $\Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau}) \geqslant 0$ and at large $N$, the dominant contribution is given by $\Delta_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})=0$, and only the couples $(\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau})$ belonging to the set:

$$
\mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=\left\{(\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}) \mid \pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}) \text { and } d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})+\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}} d(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \eta)=\min _{\eta_{0} \in S_{n}} d\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta_{0}\right)\right\}
$$

contribute to the cumulant. Note that this set is nonempty, $\left(\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}\right) \in \mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$, as for $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=1$ we have $H_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})}=S_{n}$.

Expressions in terms of degrees. In order to use our results on the degree of graphs, it is convenient to parametrize the set $\mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ using the degree $\bar{\omega}$ (Thm. 5.3). For $\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}, \pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$ and $\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}$, as the restriction of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta$ to each block of $\pi$ is connected, we have $\#(\pi)=K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)$ and:

$$
\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)=D \#(\pi)-(D-1) K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-n+d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)
$$

At the same time, we also have the following.

Lemma B.1. For any $\sigma, \tau \in S_{n}^{D}$ we have:

$$
\mathcal{C}(\sigma ; \tau)=K_{\mathrm{p}}(\sigma, \tau)-K_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)+d(\sigma, \tau) \geqslant 0, \quad \mathcal{C}(\sigma ; \sigma)=0
$$

Proof. Consider the $2 D$ colored graph $(\sigma, \tau)$. Deleting an edge corresponding to $\sigma_{c}$ in each cycle of $\sigma_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}$ does not disconnect the graph. Deleting the remaining $d(\sigma, \tau)$ edges in $\sigma$ leads to the graph $\tau$, and the number of connected components cannot increase by more than 1 for each of these edges.

The $D$-fold triangular inequality (B.5) is expressed equivalently for any $\sigma, \tau \in S_{n}^{D}, K_{\mathrm{p}}(\sigma)=$ $1, \pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)$ and $\eta \in H_{\tau, \pi}$ as:

$$
\mathcal{C}(\sigma ; \tau)+D\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)-\#(\pi)\right)+\bar{\omega}(\tau ; \eta) \geqslant \bar{\omega}(\sigma ; \eta)
$$

hence the condition defining the set $\mathbf{S}(\sigma)$ becomes in terms of the degree:

$$
\mathcal{C}(\sigma ; \tau)+D\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)-\#(\pi)\right)+\min _{\eta \in H_{\tau, \pi}} \bar{\omega}(\tau ; \eta)=\min _{\eta_{0} \in S_{n}} \bar{\omega}\left(\sigma ; \eta_{0}\right)
$$

The melonic case. If $\sigma$ is purely connected and melonic, $\omega(\sigma)=0$ and $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\sigma)=1$, then from Thm. 5.3, for $D \geqslant 3$ there exists a unique $\eta_{0} \in S_{n}$ such that $\bar{\omega}\left(\sigma ; \eta_{0}\right)=0$, and (B.10) simplifies to:

$$
\mathcal{C}(\sigma ; \tau)+D\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)-\#(\pi)\right)+\min _{\eta \in H_{\tau, \pi}} \bar{\omega}(\tau ; \eta)=0
$$

and since all the three terms are non-negative, this implies $\mathcal{C}(\sigma ; \tau)=0, \pi=\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)$, and $\min _{\eta \in H_{\tau, \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)}} \bar{\omega}(\tau ; \eta)=0$. The last condition tells us that $\tau$ must be melonic, but not necessarily purely connected.

From (B.9), for any $\tau$ with $\mathcal{C}(\sigma ; \tau)=0$ we have that for any $\eta \in H_{\tau, \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)}$ :

$$
\bar{\omega}(\tau ; \eta) \geqslant \bar{\omega}(\sigma ; \eta)
$$

with equality if and only if $\tau \eta^{-1} \leq \sigma \eta^{-1}$. Let $\eta \in H_{\tau, \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)}$ be such that $\bar{\omega}(\tau ; \eta)=0$ : then $\bar{\omega}(\sigma ; \eta)=0$, and as $\sigma$ is purely connected, $\eta$ is the canonical pairing of $\sigma$, and $\tau \eta^{-1} \leq \sigma \eta^{-1}$.

Reciprocally, if $\sigma$ is melonic purely connected and $\eta$ is its canonical pairing, and if $\tau$ is such that $\tau \eta^{-1} \leq \sigma \eta^{-1}$, then for $\pi=\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau) \vee \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\eta)$ one has $\eta \in H_{\tau, \pi}$ and from (B.9):

$$
\mathcal{C}(\sigma ; \tau)+D\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)-\#(\pi)\right)+\bar{\omega}(\tau ; \eta)=\bar{\omega}(\sigma ; \eta)=0
$$

It follows that $\pi=\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)$, that is, $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau) \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\eta)$ or said otherwise, $\eta \in H_{\tau, \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)}$, and on the other hand $\mathcal{C}(\sigma ; \tau)=\bar{\omega}(\tau ; \eta)=0$, hence $\min _{\eta \in H_{\tau, \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau)}} \bar{\omega}(\tau ; \eta)=0$ and in particular $\tau$ is melonic.

If $\omega(\sigma)=0$ and $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\sigma)=1$, and if $\eta$ corresponds to the canonical pairing of $\sigma$, then the asymptotics of (B.4) is:

$$
\kappa_{\sigma}(t, \bar{t}):=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-r(\sigma)} \mathcal{K}_{\sigma}[T, \bar{T}]=\sum_{\substack{\tau \in S_{n}^{D} \\ \tau \eta^{-1} \leq \sigma \eta^{-1}}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\tau), \tau}(t, \bar{t}) \mathrm{M}\left(\sigma \tau^{-1}\right)
$$

where, as $\sigma$ is melonic $r(\sigma)=1$ (see Thm. 5.5).

# B. 2 Proof of Thm. 6.3 

The first assertion has been proven in Thm. 6.2. The asymptotic additivity derives from (4.25) as well as the fact that $\left(T_{1}+T_{2}, \bar{T}_{1}+\bar{T}_{2}\right)$ scales as (6.10), which is itself a consequence of the multilinearity of the classical cumulants and of (6.15).

Multiplicativity. (6.17) is the analogue of Prop. 10.21 in [1]: the mapping $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n} \rightarrow$ $\mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)$ is multiplicative because $\sigma, \tau \in S_{n} \rightarrow \mathrm{M}\left(\sigma \tau^{-1}\right)$ is. For $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ with pure connected components $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{1}^{\mathrm{p}}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{q}^{\mathrm{p}}$, since $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\eta) \leqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$, letting $G_{i}=B_{i} \cup \bar{B}_{i}$ be the support of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}^{\mathrm{p}}$ :

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=\sum_{\substack{\tau \in S_{n}^{D} \\ \tau_{[B_{i} \leq \bar{\sigma}]_{B_{i}}}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}} \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)=\sum_{\left\{\tau_{[B_{i}} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}^{\mathrm{p}}\right\}} \prod_{i=1}^{q} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\tau_{[B_{i}}\right), \tau_{[B_{i}}}} \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}^{\mathrm{p}} \boldsymbol{\tau}_{[B_{i}}^{-1}\right)=\prod_{i=1}^{q} \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{i}^{\mathrm{p}}}
$$

Inversion. If all the tensors are identical, the inversion is an example of Möbius inversion. The direct product of $D$ copies of the lattice of non crossing partitions $\mathrm{NC}(n)$ is the lattice $(\mathrm{NC}(n))^{\times D}$ whose Möbius function is $\mathrm{M}(\boldsymbol{\nu})=\prod_{c=1}^{D} \mathrm{M}\left(\nu_{c}\right)$ (Prop. 10.14 of [1]), and we recall that $\mathrm{NC}(n)$ is isomorphic to the lattice of non crossing permutations on $\mu, S_{\mathrm{NC}}(\mu)$, for any cycle $\mu$ with $n$ elements.

Here for each $c$ we fix some $\mu_{c}$ with $n$ elements for which $\sigma_{c} \leq \mu_{c}$, and we work in the lattice product $\times{ }_{c=1}^{D} S_{\mathrm{NC}}\left(\mu_{c}\right)$, which contains $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$. Any interval $[\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\sigma}]$ where $\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}$ is itself a lattice (Remark 9.26 in [1]). In particular, letting $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ be melonic and with canonical pairing the identity, and $\mathbf{i d}_{n} \in S_{n}^{D}$ be the $D$-tuple of permutations (id, $\ldots$, id), that is, the melonic invariant consisting in $n$ disjoint two-vertex graphs with canonical pairing the identity, the Möbius inversion (Proposition 10.6 in [1]) ensures that (6.16) can be inverted on the interval $\left[\mathbf{i d}_{n}, \boldsymbol{\sigma}\right]$, hence for any $\boldsymbol{\nu} \in\left[\mathbf{i d}_{n}, \boldsymbol{\sigma}\right]$ :

$$
\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\nu}), \boldsymbol{\nu}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x})=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\nu}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\nu} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right), \quad \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\nu}), \boldsymbol{\nu}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x})=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\nu}} \kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x})
$$

and in particular this holds for $\boldsymbol{\nu}=\boldsymbol{\sigma}$.

# B. 3 Proof of Lemma. 6.7 

The only difference with the proof of Thm. 6.2 is that the exponent of $N$ for the terms in he sum is now expressed as

$$
-n D+K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-\left[\mathcal{C}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})+D\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})-\#(\pi)\right)+\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}} \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \eta)+\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})\right)\right]
$$

where the quantity between bracket is still non-negative. For it to vanish, one has the additional condition $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})=K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})$, that is, $\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}) \leqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})$. The $D$-fold triangular inequality (B.5) is in this case seen to be equivalent to:
$\mathcal{C}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})+D\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})-\#(\pi)\right)+\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})\right)+\bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \eta) \geqslant \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \eta)+D\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \eta)\right)$.
One then proceedes as in Sec. B. 1 to show that the set of $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ such that $\mathcal{C}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})+D\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})-\right.$ $\#(\pi))+\min _{\eta \in H_{\boldsymbol{\tau}, \pi}} \bar{\omega}(\boldsymbol{\tau} ; \eta)+\left(K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})\right)=0$ coincides with the set of $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ such that $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$, where $\eta$ is the canonical pairing of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ (and $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ ). One obtains the same limit as in Thm. 6.2, and it factorizes over the pure connected components.

## B. 4 Proof of Thm. 6.8

Even though $A=T_{1} \otimes \bar{T}_{1}+T_{2} \otimes \bar{T}_{2}$ is mixed, we express $\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$ in terms of pure quantities by multilinearity:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}} \sum_{\left\{A_{i} \in\left\{T_{1} \otimes T_{1}, T_{2} \otimes T_{2}\right\}\right\}} \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)\right] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}\right)
$$

For each assignment of the $A_{i} \mathrm{~s}, \operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ is the same as a pure invariant $\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\tau}}(\vec{X}, \vec{X})$, where $\vec{X}$ (resp. $\vec{X}$ ) assigns some tensors $T_{1}$ or $T_{2}$ to the white (resp. black) vertices of $\boldsymbol{\tau}$, with the condition that the components $\bar{X}_{i}$ of $\vec{X}$ and the components $X_{i}$ of $\vec{X}$ satisfy $\bar{X}_{i}=\overline{\left(X_{i}\right)}$. We may therefore use the classical moment cumulant formula over the pure connected components of $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ :

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{c}^{D}} \sum_{\{\vec{X}\}} \sum_{\pi \geqslant \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})} \Phi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}[\vec{X}, \vec{X}] \prod_{c=1}^{D} W^{(N)}\left(\sigma_{c} \tau_{c}^{-1}\right)
$$

Since by assumption the tensors satisfy (6.15), the proof of Thm. 6.2 goes through and one obtains:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} N^{n D-1} \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\sum_{\{\vec{x}\}} \sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{c}^{D}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

In particular, since the labeling is such that the canonical pairing is the identity, for all the terms in the sum the connected and purely connected components of $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ coincide. For any $\boldsymbol{\nu}$ satisfying this property, one has:

$$
\Phi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\sum_{\left\{A_{i} \in\left\{T_{1} \otimes T_{1}, T_{2} \otimes T_{2}\right\}\right\}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right]=\sum_{\{\vec{X}\}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}[\vec{X}, \vec{X}]=N^{r(\boldsymbol{\nu})} \sum_{\vec{x}} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x})+o\left(N^{r(\boldsymbol{\nu})}\right)
$$

where the assumption is necessary for the second equality and he third uses (6.15). For such $\boldsymbol{\nu}$ :

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r(\boldsymbol{\nu})}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\sum_{\vec{x}} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x})
$$

so that (6.34) is proven. The inversion (6.35) has already been proven (Sec. B.2). The fact that $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(t_{1}+t_{2}, \bar{t}_{1}+\bar{t}_{2}\right)$ comes from (6.33), and $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}\left(t_{1}+t_{2}, \bar{t}_{1}+\bar{t}_{2}\right)$ from the inverse relations. However:

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}\left(t_{1}+t_{2}, \bar{t}_{1}+\bar{t}_{2}\right)=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N^{r(\boldsymbol{\nu})}} \Phi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}\left[T_{1}+T_{2}, \bar{T}_{1}+\bar{T}_{2}\right]=\sum_{\vec{x}, \vec{\nu}} \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\nu}}(\vec{x}, \vec{x})
$$

where $\vec{x}=\left(x_{1}, \ldots x_{n}\right), x_{i} \in\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}\right\}, \overrightarrow{x^{\prime}}=\left(x_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots x_{n}^{\prime}\right), x_{i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\bar{t}_{1}, \bar{t}_{2}\right\}$. For (B.18) and (B.19) to be equal, (6.36) must hold.

# B. 5 Proof of Thm. 6.9. 

The proof follows the one in the pure case presented in Section B. 1 by replacing $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ with $(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id})$ and observing that the pure connected components of $(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id})$ are one to one with the mixed connected components of $\boldsymbol{\tau}$, thus:

$$
\mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]=\frac{1}{N^{n D}} \sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D}} \sum_{\pi \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau})}\left(\varphi_{\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right) N^{n-d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})-\min _{\eta \in H(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}), \pi} d((\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}), \eta)}+\ldots\right)
$$

where for $\pi \geqslant \Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}), H_{(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}), \pi}=\left\{\eta \in S_{n} \mid \Pi(\eta) \leqslant \pi \quad\right.$ and $\left.\forall B \in \pi, K_{\mathrm{m}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{|B}, \eta_{|B}\right)=1\right\}$.
General asymptotics. The $D$-fold triangular inequality (B.5) is now replaced with:

$$
d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})+d((\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}), \eta) \geqslant d((\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}), \eta)
$$

with equality if and only if $(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}) \eta^{-1} \leq(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}) \eta^{-1}$, that is $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$, and the dominant contributions satisfy:

$$
d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})+\min _{\eta \in H_{(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}), \pi}} d((\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}), \eta)=\min _{\eta_{0} \in S_{n}} d\left((\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}), \eta_{0}\right)
$$

which is saturated at least for $\boldsymbol{\tau}=\boldsymbol{\sigma}$, hence for a connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathcal{K}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}[A]$ scales as $N^{r_{W}(\boldsymbol{\sigma})-n D}$.
First order. Using the degree, $\bar{\omega}((\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}), \eta)$, (B.7) gives rise to a term $K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})$ instead of $K_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})$, and applying Lemma B. 1 to $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ and $(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id})$ we get:

$$
\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})=d(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})-K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})+K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau}) \geqslant 0
$$

where for $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ connected $K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \boldsymbol{\tau})=1$, and (B.20) is equivalent to:

$$
\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma} ; \boldsymbol{\tau})+(D+1)\left(K_{\mathrm{m}}(\boldsymbol{\tau})-\#(\pi)\right)+\bar{\omega}((\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}) ; \eta) \geqslant \bar{\omega}((\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}) ; \eta)
$$

The rest follows as in Sec. B.1, identifying for connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ such that $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ is melonic, the set of $(\pi, \boldsymbol{\tau})$ satisfying (B.21) as $\pi=\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau})$ and $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$, where $\eta$ is the canonical pairing of $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$. The additivity follows from the additivity of the finite $N$ free cumulants.

Inversion. The inversion is slightly more involved. We start from the multiplicative extension to any non-necessarily connected $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic with canonical pairing $\eta$ :

$$
\kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a})=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}} \varphi_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)=\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D} \\(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}) \eta^{-1} \leq(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}) \eta^{-1}}} \varphi_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{a}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

where $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau})=\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id})$. Changing variables to $\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}=\boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$ and $\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime}=\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}$, we rewrite this as:

$$
\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right), \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \eta}^{\mathrm{m}}\left(\vec{a}_{\eta}\right)=\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime} \in S_{n}^{D} \\\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right) \leq\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right)}} \varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right), \boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime} \eta}^{\mathrm{m}}\left(\vec{a}_{\eta}\right) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime-1}\right)
$$

where the notation $\vec{a}_{\eta}$ indicates that after the change of variable, the variable $a_{s}$ is now associated to the thick edge going from the white vertex $s$ to the black vertex $\overline{\eta^{-1}(s)}$. After this change of variable, which corresponds to a relabeling of the white vertices to set the canonical pairing to the identity, one has $\bar{\omega}\left(\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right) ; \mathrm{id}\right)=0, \Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \eta, \mathrm{id}\right)=\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right)$, and similarly for $\boldsymbol{\tau}$. For $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \sigma_{D+1}^{\prime}\right) \in S_{n}^{D+1}$ we denote:

$$
g(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}})=\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \sigma_{D+1}^{\prime}\right), \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \sigma_{D+1}^{\prime-1}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left(\vec{a}_{\sigma_{D+1}^{\prime}}\right), \quad f(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}})=\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \sigma_{D+1}^{\prime}\right), \boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \sigma_{D+1}^{\prime-1}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left(\vec{a}_{\sigma_{D+1}^{\prime}}\right)
$$

We fix a connected $\boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime}$ with $\bar{\omega}\left(\left(\boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right) ; \mathrm{id}\right)=0$ and consider the relations above for all the $\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}$ such that $\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime} \leq \boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime}$ : the $\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}$ are not necessarily connected and satisfy $\bar{\omega}\left(\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right) ; \mathrm{id}\right)=0$. We rewrite (B.25) for any $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \sigma_{D+1}^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{L}=\left[\left(\mathbf{i d}_{n}, \eta^{-1}\right),\left(\boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right)\right]$ as:

$$
g(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}})=\sum_{\substack{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}} \in \mathcal{L} \\ \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}} \leq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}}} f(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}) \mathrm{M}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}^{-1}\right)
$$

which holds as in the lattice interval $\mathcal{L}$ we have $\sigma_{D+1}^{\prime}=\eta^{-1}$ and $\tau_{D+1}^{\prime}=\eta^{-1}$. Note that $\mathcal{L}$ is a sublattice of $\times_{c=1}^{D} S_{\mathrm{NC}}\left(\nu_{c}^{\prime}\right) \times S_{\mathrm{NC}}\left(\eta^{-1}\right)$, and we can invert this formula (Proposition 10.6 in [1]) to obtain for all $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}=\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}^{\prime}, \sigma_{D+1}^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{L}=\left[\left(\mathbf{i d}_{n}, \eta^{-1}\right),\left(\boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime}, \eta^{-1}\right)\right]$ :

$$
f(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}})=\sum_{\substack{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}} \in \mathcal{L} \\ \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}} \leq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}}} g(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}})
$$

and again $\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime}, \tau_{D+1}^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{L}$ forces $\tau_{D+1}^{\prime}=\eta^{-1}$. Retracing our steps we conclude.

# B. 6 Proof of Prop. 6.10 

Starting from the free moment-cumulant formula for the pure case:

$$
\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}),(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})}(t, \bar{t})=\sum_{\substack{\left.\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \tau_{D+1}\right) \in S_{n}^{D+1}\right.}}\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \tau_{D+1}\right),\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \tau_{D+1}\right)}(t, \bar{t}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right) \mathrm{M}\left(\tau_{D+1}\right)
$$

we use the invariance $\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \tau_{D+1}\right),\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \tau_{D+1}\right)}(t, \bar{t})=\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}, \mathrm{id}\right),\left(\boldsymbol{\tau} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}, \mathrm{id}\right)}(t, \bar{t})$ and observe that:

$$
\varphi_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}, \mathrm{id}\right),\left(\boldsymbol{\tau} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}, \mathrm{id}\right)}(t, \bar{t})=\varphi_{\Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\tau} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}\right), \boldsymbol{\tau} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}}^{-1}(a)
$$

The invariant $\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime}=\boldsymbol{\tau} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}$ is such that $\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime}\right.$, id $)$ is melonic, with canonical pairing $\eta \tau_{D+1}^{-1}$, so that:

$$
\varphi_{\Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime}\right), \boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime}}^{-1}(a)=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime} \tau_{D+1} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime} \tau_{D+1} \eta^{-1}} \kappa_{\Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime}\right), \boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)
$$

Changing back to $\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime} \tau_{D+1}=\boldsymbol{\tau}$ and $\boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime} \tau_{D+1}=\boldsymbol{\nu}$ and putting the two relations together, we have:

$$
\kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}),(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})}(t, \bar{t})=\sum_{\substack{\left.\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \tau_{D+1}\right) \in S_{n}^{D+1}\right) \\\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \tau_{D+1}\right) \eta^{-1} \leq(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}) \eta^{-1}}} \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right) \mathrm{M}\left(\tau_{D+1}\right) \sum_{\boldsymbol{\nu} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}} \kappa_{\Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\nu} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}\right), \boldsymbol{\nu} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}}^{-1}(a)
$$

One has to be careful that for $\boldsymbol{\tau}^{\prime}$ and $\boldsymbol{\nu}^{\prime}$, the identity is the permutation encoding the thick edges and the canonical pairing is $\eta \tau_{D+1}^{-1}$, but after the change of labeling the permutation encoding the thick edges is $\tau_{D+1}$, and the canonical pairing is $\eta$. As $\kappa_{\Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\nu} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}\right), \boldsymbol{\nu} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}}^{-1}(a)$, factors over the connected components of $\Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\nu} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}\right)=\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\nu} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}\right.$, id $)=\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\nu}, \tau_{D+1}\right)$, exchanging the sums over $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ and $\boldsymbol{\nu}$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id}),(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})}(t, \bar{t})=\sum_{\substack{\tau_{D+1} \eta^{-1} \leq \eta^{-1} \\
\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \tau_{D+1}\right) \leq \eta^{-1}}} \mathrm{M}\left(\tau_{D+1}\right) \sum_{\boldsymbol{\nu} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}} \kappa_{\Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\nu} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}\right), \boldsymbol{\nu} \tau_{D+1}^{-1}}^{-1}(a) \\
& \times \sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D} \\
\boldsymbol{\nu} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}}} \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right) \\
& \text { and the last sum is } \delta(\boldsymbol{\nu}, \boldsymbol{\sigma}) \text {, so that setting } \nu=\tau_{D+1} \text {, we get: }
\end{aligned}
$$

Reciprocally, starting from the mixed moments in terms of the pure ones which we express in terms of pure cumulants, and substituting into the mixed cumulant moment formula, we get:

$$
\kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\tau} \in S_{n}^{D} \\ \boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}}} \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right) \sum_{\substack{\left.\left(\boldsymbol{\nu}, \nu_{D+1}\right) \in S_{n}^{D+1}\right) \\\left(\boldsymbol{\nu}, \nu_{D+1}\right) \eta^{-1} \leq(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id}) \eta^{-1}}} \kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\nu}, \nu_{D+1}\right),\left(\boldsymbol{\nu}, \nu_{D+1}\right)}(t, \bar{t})
$$

and exchanging the summations and summing the Möebius functions we find:

$$
\kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\sigma}), \boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(a)=\sum_{\substack{\nu \in S_{n} \\ \nu \eta^{-1} \leq \eta^{-1}}} \kappa_{\Pi_{\mathrm{p}}(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \nu),(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \nu)}(t, \bar{t})
$$

# C Proofs of Sec. 7
## C. 1 Proofs of Sec. 7.7

Proof of Prop. 7.3. We directly generalize the proof by induction of [1]. If $q=2$, the connected melonic graphs of two paired tensors are such that the two thick edges form a square with e.g. the edges of color 1 , while each one of the other colored edges links the same two vertices as one of the thick edges. For such a graph, one has if one of the tensors is the identity on the appropriate space: $\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}, 1_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\right)=\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}, 1_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}\right)-\phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left(h_{1}\right) \phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left(1_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}\right)$, since $\mathrm{M}((1)(2))=1$ and $\mathrm{M}((12))=-1$. Using (7.28) as well as (7.29) and since after removing any of the thick edges (Fig. 16), the invariant is $\mathbf{i d}_{1}$, we have $\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}, 1_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}\right)=\phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left(h_{1}\right)-\phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left(h_{1}\right)=0$.

We now assume $q>2$. Up to a relabeling, we may assume that $h_{q}=1_{\mathcal{D}_{q}}$. From (7.33):

$$
\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}, \ldots, h_{q-1}, 1_{\mathcal{D}_{q}}\right)=\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}, \ldots, h_{q-1}, 1_{\mathcal{D}_{q}}\right)+\sum_{\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{g} \mid \mathrm{h} \neq \mathrm{g}} \varkappa_{\Pi(\mathrm{h}), \mathrm{h}}(\vec{h})
$$

From (7.29), the left-hand-side is $\phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{g}_{: q}\right) \mathrm{g}_{: q}}\left(h_{1}, \ldots, h_{q-1}\right)$. For the rightmost term, the condition $\mathrm{h} \neq \mathrm{g}$ forces h to have more than one connected component, and from the induction hypothesis, $h_{q}$ must be alone in a component $\mathbf{i d}_{1}$, whose contribution is $\varkappa_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left(1_{\mathcal{D}_{q}}\right)=\phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left(1_{\mathcal{D}_{q}}\right)=1$. This means that this sum can be rewritten as a sum over $\mathrm{h}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{g}_{: q}$ of $\varkappa_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime}}(\vec{p})$, that is, $\phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{g}_{: q}\right) \mathrm{g}_{: q}}$ (since $\mathrm{g}_{: q}$ might not be connected, we obtain the multiplicative extension of (7.33)). To summarize:

$$
\phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{g}_{: q}\right) \mathrm{g}_{: q}}\left(h_{1}, \ldots, h_{q-1}\right)=\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}, \ldots, h_{q-1}, 1_{\mathcal{D}_{q}}\right)+\phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{g}_{: q}\right) \mathrm{g}_{: q}}\left(h_{1}, \ldots, h_{q-1}\right)
$$

so that $\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}, \ldots, h_{q-1}, 1\right)=0$.
Proof of Prop. 7.4. Let us recall the notations of the proposition: g is a connected melonic graph of $q$ paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{f j}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[S_{\ell}\right]$, where $S_{\ell} \subset\left\{A, B \ldots\right\}$, or $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{f j}^{\mathrm{p}}\left[\Theta_{\ell}, \bar{\Theta}_{\ell}\right]$, where $\Theta_{\ell} \subset\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}$ and $\bar{\Theta}_{\ell} \subset\left\{T_{a}, T_{b} \ldots\right\}, E$ is a set of edges of g , the $P_{j}$ are obtained as connected components of $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{g}, E}(\vec{H})$, the $\mathrm{h}_{j}$ with support $R_{j} \subset\{1, \ldots q\}$ such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{h}_{j}}\left(\vec{H}_{j}\right)=$ $\operatorname{Tr}\left(P_{j}\right)(7.13)$, and which constitute the connected components of h , which is a melonic invariant of $\vec{H}$, and finally, k is such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{H})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{P})(7.14)$. One develops using (7.31):

$$
\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p})=\sum_{\mathrm{k}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{k}} \phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{k}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{k}^{\prime}}(\vec{p}) \mathrm{M}\left(\mathrm{k}^{\prime}, \mathrm{k}\right)
$$

For each $\mathrm{k}^{\prime}$, from (7.9) we may gather the colored edges of $\mathrm{k}^{\prime}$ together with the colored edges that link the $H_{\ell}$ inside each $P_{j}$, to form a colored graph $\mathrm{h}^{\prime}$ of $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$. From (7.18), one has $\phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{k}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{k}^{\prime}}(\vec{p})=\phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime}}(\vec{h})$.

The summation over $\mathrm{k}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{k}$ can be exchanged for a summation over $\mathrm{h}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{g}$, but with the condition that the edges of color in $1, \ldots D$ that are internal to the $P_{j}$ are the same in $\mathrm{h}^{\prime}$ and g , or said otherwise, $\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{h}^{\prime}$, where we have recalled the definition of h at the beginning of the proof. This is because h is the smallest of the $\mathrm{h}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{g}$ leaving these edges unchanged. We will have shown that:

$$
\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{p})=\sum_{\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{h}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{g}} \phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime}}(\vec{h}) \mathrm{M}\left(\mathrm{~h}^{\prime}, \mathrm{g}\right)
$$

if we justify that $\mathrm{M}\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}, \mathrm{g}\right)=\mathrm{M}\left(\mathrm{k}^{\prime}, \mathrm{k}\right)$. We let $\left\{\gamma_{c, b}\right\}$ be the cycles encoding $\mathrm{k},\left\{\eta_{c, b}\right\}$ be the non-crossing permutations of the $\left\{\gamma_{c, b}\right\}$ whose cycles encode $\mathrm{k}^{\prime}$, and similarly, $\left\{\epsilon_{c, b}\right\}$ the cycles encoding g , and $\left\{\zeta_{c, b}\right\}$ the non-crossing permutations of the $\left\{\epsilon_{c, b}\right\}$ whose cycles encode $\mathrm{h}^{\prime}$. We need to show that

$$
\prod_{c, b} \mathrm{M}\left(\eta_{c, b} \gamma_{c, b}^{-1}\right)=\prod_{c, b} \mathrm{M}\left(\zeta_{c, b} \epsilon_{c, b}^{-1}\right)
$$

Each cycle $\epsilon_{c, b}$ entirely included in one of the $P_{j}$ is left unchanged: $\epsilon_{c, b}=\zeta_{c, b}$, contributing with a factor 1 to the right-hand side, so for these cycles there is nothing to prove. We now consider a cycle of $\gamma_{c, b}$ which is completed into a cycle of $\epsilon_{c, b}$ by the portions that are internal to some of the $\left\{P_{j}\right\}$ and alternate edges of color $c$ and thick edges. For each thick edge labeled $i$ for which the edge of color $c$ of $\mathbf{g}$ which is connected to its white vertex (the input of the corresponding paired tensor) is internal to one of the $\left\{P_{j}\right\}$, since this edge of color $c$ is in both $\mathbf{g}$ and $\mathrm{h}^{\prime}$, applying $\epsilon_{c, b}^{-1}$ and then $\zeta_{c, b}$, one returns to $i$, so the contribution to $\zeta_{c, b} \epsilon_{c, b}^{-1}$ is the singlet (i). For the thick edges for which the edge of color $c$ connected to its white vertex is an edge of k (not internal to one of the $\left\{P_{j}\right\}$ ), then the cycles $\left\{\zeta_{c, b} \epsilon_{c, b}^{-1}\right\}_{b}$ coincide exactly with the cycles of $\left\{\eta_{c, b} \gamma_{c, b}^{-1}\right\}_{b}$. Since the singlets contribute as factors 1 to the $\mathbf{M}$ (see the definition (2.5)), (C.3) indeed holds.

If we also denote $\left\{\theta_{c, b}\right\}$ the non-crossing permutations of the $\left\{\epsilon_{c, b}\right\}$ whose cycles encode $\mathbf{h}$, the condition in the sum (C.2) can be expressed as summations for all $c, b$ over $\zeta_{c, b}$ satisfying $\theta_{c, b} \leq \zeta_{c, b} \leq \epsilon_{c, b}$. Recalling that each $\epsilon_{c, b}$ is a single cycle, the direct product $\times_{c, b} S_{\mathrm{NC}}\left(\epsilon_{c, b}\right)$ is a lattice. We therefore want to apply the partial inversion formula which can be found in e.g. Prop. 10.11 of [1]. Indeed, for any $\left\{\vartheta_{c, b}\right\}_{c, b}$ in $\times_{c, b} S_{\mathrm{NC}}\left(\epsilon_{c, b}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\#}$ encoded by the cycles of $\vartheta_{c, b}$ is a (not necessarily connected) melonic graph of paired tensors $\vec{h}$ and so taking the product of (7.33) for the connected components of $\mathrm{h}^{\#}$, one has that $\phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime \prime}}(\vec{h})=\sum_{\mathrm{h}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{h}^{\prime \prime}} \varkappa_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime}}(\vec{h})$, where by definition the sum is to be understood as a sum over $\zeta_{c, b}$ whose cycles encode $\mathrm{h}^{\prime}$. One can therefore apply the aforementioned proposition, obtaining:

$$
\sum_{\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{h}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{g}} \phi_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime}}(\vec{h}) \mathrm{M}\left(\mathrm{~h}^{\prime}, \mathrm{g}\right)=\sum_{\substack{\mathrm{h}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{g} \\ \Pi\left(\mathrm{~h}^{\prime}\right) \vee \Pi(\mathrm{h})=1_{q}}} \varkappa_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime}}(\vec{h})
$$

This concludes the proof.

# C. 2 Proofs of Sec. 7.8
## C.2.1 Proof of Thm. 7.5

We first show that points 1 and 2 are equivalent:
Lemma C.1. The two following conditions are equivalent:
(a) For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected and with $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$, and any $\vec{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right) \in$ $\{a, b \ldots\}^{n}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0$ whenever there exists $1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$.
(b) The two following conditions are satisfied:

- For any $n \geqslant 2$, any $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected such that $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic with canonical pairing $\eta \neq \mathrm{id}$, and any $\vec{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right) \in\{a, b \ldots\}^{n}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0$ whenever there exists $i \in\{1, \ldots n\}$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{\eta(i)}$.
- For any $q \geqslant 2$, any paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$ such that $\forall 1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{m}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ with $Q_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$, and any connected melonic graph $\mathbf{g}$ of $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}, \varkappa_{\mathbf{g}}(\vec{h})=0$ whenever there exists $1 \leqslant \ell<\ell^{\prime} \leqslant q$ such that $Q_{\ell} \neq Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$.

Proof. - From (b) to (a): By the first statement of (b), we only need to prove (a) for $\vec{m}$ such that for every $1 \leqslant i \leqslant n, m_{i}=m_{\eta(i)}$. Consider $\vec{m}$ satisfying this property, and $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected and with $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$. In the colored graph of $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$, all the cycles alternating canonical pairs and thick edges correspond to the same element of $\{a, b \ldots\}$. Label each one of these cycles with $\ell \in\{1, \ldots q\}$ and for each cycle form the paired tensor (7.7) with $k_{\ell}$ the number of thick edges in the cycle number $\ell$, and $M_{1}^{\ell}=\ldots=M_{k_{\ell}}^{\ell}$ all equal to the element of $\{A, B \ldots\}$ represented by

each thick edge in the cycle. Applying (b) to the connected melonic graph k obtained grouping the tensors to form $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$, we have by (7.38):

$$
0=\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}}(\vec{h})=\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})
$$

From (a) to (b): Again, we only need to prove that the property (a) for $\vec{m}$ satisfying $m_{i}=m_{\eta(i)}$ for every $1 \leqslant i \leqslant n$ implies the second statement of (b). Assuming (a) and with $\mathrm{g}, \vec{H}, \vec{Q}$ as in the statement (b), we prove that $\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=0$. There exist $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ connected and with $\omega(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})=0$ and $\vec{m}$ with at least $i, j \in\{1, \ldots n\}$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$ and such that $\operatorname{Tr}_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{H})=\operatorname{Tr}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}(\vec{m})$. By (7.34):

$$
\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=\sum_{\substack{\boldsymbol{\rho} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1} \\ \Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\rho} \eta^{-1}\right) \vee \Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}\right)=1_{n}}} \kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\rho}), \boldsymbol{\rho}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ is defined above (7.34). We know that there exist $i, j \in\{1, \ldots n\}$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$. By construction, $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ has no connected component containing some $i, j$ for which $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$. In order for the condition $\Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\rho} \eta^{-1}\right) \vee \Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}\right)=1_{n}$ to be satisfied, $\boldsymbol{\rho}$ must therefore have a connected component containing some $i, j$ for which $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$. Therefore, by (a), every $\boldsymbol{\rho}$ in the sum (C.5) must be such that $\kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\rho}), \boldsymbol{\rho}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0$, and so $\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=0$.

Remark C.2. In Lemma C.1, one may replace $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ by $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell}, \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ in the second statement of (b): then in order for the condition $\Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\rho} \eta^{-1}\right) \vee \Pi\left(\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1}\right)=1_{n}$ to be satisfied, $\boldsymbol{\rho}$ must have a connected component containing either $1_{D}$, or some $i, j$ for which $m_{i} \neq m_{j}$, and the same conclusions hold. By multilinearity, one may also replace $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ by $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ or $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$.

We then show the equivalence between point 2 and point 3 . We start with the easiest part.
Lemma C.3. The two following assertions are equivalent:
(a-i) For any $n \geqslant 2, \boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected and with $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic with canonical pairing $\eta \neq \mathrm{id}$, and any $\vec{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right) \in\left\{a, b \ldots\right\}^{n}, \kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0$ whenever there exists $i \in\{1, \ldots n\}$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{\eta(i)}$.
(a-ii) For any $n \geqslant 2, \boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}$ connected and $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic with canonical pairing $\eta \neq \mathrm{id}$, and any $\vec{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right) \in\left\{a, b \ldots\right\}^{n}, \varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0$ whenever there exists $i \in\{1, \ldots n\}$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{\eta(i)}$.

Proof. We fix $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \in S_{n}^{D}, \eta \in S_{n}, \vec{m}=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$ as in the lemma and $i$ such that $m_{i} \neq m_{\eta(i)}$.
From (a-ii) to (a-i): From Thm. 6.9:

$$
\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}} \varphi_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m}) \mathrm{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma} \boldsymbol{\tau}^{-1}\right)
$$

Since $m_{i} \neq m_{\eta(i)}$, then the cycle in the graph which alternates thick edges and canonical pairs and contains the thick edge labeled $i$ is a separating cycle. Since any $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ satisfying $\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}$ is such that $(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathrm{id})$ has the same canonical pairing $\eta$, and since the permutation defining the thick edges of $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ is still the identity, there is for every $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ in the sum a connected component $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}$ with support $B_{j}$ with the same separating cycle, which satisfies $\omega\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}, \mathrm{id}_{\left|B_{j}\right)}\right)=0$, has canonical pairing $\eta_{i B_{j}}$, and contains the same thick edge $i$ for which $m_{i} \neq m_{\eta_{i} B_{j}}(i)$, for which $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\tau}_{j}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left(\vec{m}_{\left|B_{j}\right)}\right)=0$. From (a-ii) every term in the sum vanishes, and so does $\kappa_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})$.

From (a-i) to (a-ii): Reciprocally, one has from Thm. 6.9:

$$
\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=\sum_{\boldsymbol{\tau} \eta^{-1} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma} \eta^{-1}} \kappa_{\Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau}), \boldsymbol{\tau}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})
$$

The discussion is exactly the same as above, and assuming (a-i) we find that $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})=0$ for any $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ connected with $(\boldsymbol{\sigma}, \mathrm{id})$ melonic, and therefore the same holds for $\varphi_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}^{\mathrm{m}}(\vec{m})$.

We recall that for $\mathfrak{g}$ a melonic graph of paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{p}$ with $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[R_{\ell}\right]$ with $R_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\},(\mathrm{~g}, \vec{H})$ is almost alternating if it has at least one edge linking paired tensors $H_{\ell}$, $H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ generated by different tensors $R_{\ell} \neq R_{\ell^{\prime}}$, and at most one edge of $\mathfrak{g}$ which links two paired tensors $H_{\ell}, H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ generated by the same $R_{\ell}=R_{\ell^{\prime}}$. It is strictly alternating if different any two paired tensors linked by an edge are generated by different elements of $\{A, B \ldots\}$. In order to prove the equivalence of the remaining statements, we will need the following key lemma.

Lemma C.4. Let $\mathfrak{g}$ be a connected melonic graph of the paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ with $Q_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$, or $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{n}}\left[X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right]$ with $\left(X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right) \in\left\{\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right),\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right) \ldots\right\}$, such that $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H})$ is almost alternating, and consider $\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{g}$. Then either $(\mathrm{h}, \vec{H})$ has an almost alternating connected component, or it has a connected component consisting of a single paired tensor.

Proof. We consider a system of cycles $\left\{\gamma_{c, b}\right\}$ encoding $\mathfrak{g}$ and the non-crossing permutations $\left\{\tau_{c, b}\right\}$ with $\tau_{c, b} \leq \gamma_{c, b}$, whose cycles encode $\mathrm{h}$.

The statement of the lemma holds if $\mathrm{h}=\mathrm{g}$, because $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{H})$ is almost alternating. Otherwise, $\tau_{c, b} \neq \gamma_{c, b}$ for some $c, b$. We can go from $\left\{\gamma_{c, b}\right\}$ to $\left\{\tau_{c, b}\right\}$ by a sequence $\left\{\rho_{c, b}(i)\right\}, i=1, \ldots, k$, where $\rho_{c, b}(1)=\gamma_{c, b}, \rho_{c, b}(k)=\tau_{c, b}$, and there is a single $c, b$ for which $\rho_{c, b}(i) \neq \rho_{c, b}(i+1)$ (all the others are equal), and for this $c, b$ one has: $\rho_{c, b}(i+1) \leq \rho_{c, b}(i)$ and $\#\left(\rho_{c, b}(i+1)\right)=\#\left(\rho_{c, b}(i)\right)+1$. At this step, a pair of edges of color $c$ that both belong to the same cycle $\rho_{c, b}(i)$ has been flipped: they remain connected to the same white vertices, but the black vertices to which they are connected have been exchanged, dividing the cycle of $\rho_{c, b}(i)$ to which they belonged in two. Note that this corresponds to a multiplication of $\rho_{c, b}(i)$ by an appropriate transposition.

We want to show that at each step $i$ from 2 to $k$, the following property is true: there exist two connected components of $\left\{\rho_{c, b}^{(i)}\right\}$ whose colored edges are all the same as in $\mathfrak{g}$, with the exception of a single edge. We call this property $P(i)$. We will update a pair $\left(\mathcal{C}_{1}(i), \mathcal{C}_{2}(i)\right)$ of connected components of this kind (which "validate" $P(i)$ ).
$P(2)$ holds because a single pair of edges has been flipped to go from $\left\{\gamma_{c, b}\right\}$ to $\left\{\rho_{c, b}^{(2)}\right\}$, creating two connected components $\left(\mathcal{C}_{1}(2), \mathcal{C}_{2}(2)\right)$ which validate $P(2)$.

At the next step, the pair of edges to be flipped belong to the same connected component of $\left\{\rho_{c, b}^{(2)}\right\}$, say, $\mathcal{C}_{1}(2)$. Flipping these edges creates two connected components: one of them has two edges that were not in $\mathfrak{g}$, while the other, which we call $\mathcal{C}_{1}(3)$, has a single edge that is not in $\mathfrak{g}$. Setting $\mathcal{C}_{2}(3)=\mathcal{C}_{2}(2)$, we have a pair which validates $P(3)$. At every step that follows, either the two edges are flipped in a connected component which is neither $\mathcal{C}_{1}(i)$ nor $\mathcal{C}_{2}(i))$, in which case $\mathcal{C}_{1}(i+1):=\mathcal{C}_{1}(i)$ and $\mathcal{C}_{2}(i+1):=\mathcal{C}_{2}(i)$, or it is performed in say $\mathcal{C}_{1}(i)$, in which case as for step 2 to 3 a component $\mathcal{C}_{1}(i+1)$ is created with a single edge not in $\mathfrak{g}$, and we update $\mathcal{C}_{2}(i+1):=\mathcal{C}_{2}(i)$. This proves that $P(i)$ holds at every step.

Having proven that $P(k)$ is true, we consider the following situations.

- If there is no edge of $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ or $\mathcal{C}_{2}(k)$ that is also in $\mathfrak{g}$, or if all the edges of $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ or $\mathcal{C}_{2}(k)$ that are also in $\mathfrak{g}$ link the inputs and outputs of a paired tensor, then this connected component of $h$ consists of a single paired tensor with a number of edges linking its inputs and outputs, that is, a melonic graph of a single paired tensor, and the statement of the lemma holds.

Otherwise both $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ and $\mathcal{C}_{2}(k)$ contain edges that also belong to g or link paired tensors $H_{\ell}$, $H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ with $\ell \neq \ell^{\prime}$. Since g is almost alternating, it has at most one edge $e$ which links two paired tensors generated by the same $Q_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$ (or the pure equivalent, by $\left(X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right) \in$ $\left\{\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right),\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right) \ldots\right\}$ ).

- If g is strictly alternating, or if $e$ exists but has been flipped at some step and is therefore not as in g , or if $e$ remains in h as it was in g but does not belong to $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ or $\mathcal{C}_{2}(k)$, then there is at least one edge in $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ and one in $\mathcal{C}_{2}(k)$ that are also in g and the edges of $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ and $\mathcal{C}_{2}(k)$ that are also in g still all link in h paired tensors generated by different elements of $\{A, B \ldots\}$. There is only one edge of $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ which is not in g , so it might link two paired tensors $H_{\ell}, H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ of $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ with $\ell \neq \ell^{\prime}$ and which are generated by the same element of $\{A, B \ldots\}$, but no other edge of $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ can have this property, so $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$ is almost alternating (and $\mathcal{C}_{2}(k)$ as well).

Otherwise, $e$ exists in g and remains in h , and it belongs to say $\mathcal{C}_{1}(k)$.

- We then consider $\mathcal{C}_{2}(k)$ (this is why we needed two connected components to validate $P(i))$ : it has at most one edge linking paired tensors generated by the same element of $\{A, B \ldots\}$, and it has at least one edge linking paired tensors generated by different elements of $\{A, B \ldots\}$ : it is almost alternating.

Lemma C.5. The two following assertions are equivalent:
(b-i) For any $q \geqslant 2$, any paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$ such that $\forall 1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q, H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D}^{m}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ with $Q_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$, and any connected melonic graph g of $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}, \varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=0$ whenever there exists $1 \leqslant \ell<\ell^{\prime} \leqslant q$ such that $Q_{\ell} \neq Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$.
(b-ii) For any $q \geqslant 2$, any $\mathcal{D}_{1}, \ldots \mathcal{D}_{q} \geqslant 1$, any paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$ such that for $1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q$, $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{m}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ with $Q_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$, and any connected melonic graph g of $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$, letting for each $\ell: h_{\ell}^{\prime}=h_{\ell}-\phi\left(h_{\ell}\right) 1_{\mathcal{D}_{\ell}}$, then $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{h}^{\prime}\right)=0$ whenever $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{h})$ is almost alternating.
Proof. We generalize the proof of Thm. 11.16 of [1]. We fix some paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots H_{q}$, $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{\ell}}^{m}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ with $Q_{\ell} \in\{A, B \ldots\}$, and a connected melonic graph g of these paired tensors.

From (b-i) to (b-ii): We assume that (b-i) holds and that $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{h})$ is almost alternating. Recalling the free moment-cumulant relation for melonic invariants of paired tensors (7.33):

$$
\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{h}^{\prime}\right)=\sum_{\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{g}} \varkappa_{\Pi(h), \mathrm{h}}\left(\vec{h}^{\prime}\right)
$$

From Lemma C.4, since $(\mathrm{g}, \vec{h})$ is almost alternating, every $\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{g}$ is such that:

- Either $(\mathrm{h}, \vec{h})$ has an almost alternating connected component with support $B \subset\{1, \ldots, q\}$, which in particular has at least two paired tensors $H_{\ell}, H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ with $\ell \neq \ell^{\prime} \in B$ and generated by different elements $Q_{\ell} \neq Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$. We focus on the contribution to the right-hand-side of (C.8) for such a $h$, and using the multilinearity of $\varkappa$, we expand all the entries of the factor $\varkappa_{h_{i B}}\left(\vec{h}_{i B}^{\prime}\right)$. From Prop. 7.3, the terms involving $1_{D}$ vanish, and by (b-i), the term involving $\vec{H}_{i B}$ also vanishes.
- Or $(\mathrm{h}, \vec{h})$ has a connected component which is a melonic graph of a single paired tensor, contributing to a factor $\varkappa_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left(h_{\ell}^{\prime}\right)=\phi_{\mathbf{i d}_{1}}\left(h_{\ell}^{\prime}\right)=\phi\left(h_{\ell}^{\prime}\right)=0$ by linearity of $\phi$.

From (b-ii) to (b-i): We assume that (b-ii) holds and that there exists $1 \leqslant \ell<\ell^{\prime} \leqslant q$ such that $Q_{\ell} \neq Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$. We recall the free cumulant-moment relation for melonic invariants of paired tensors $(7.31):$

$$
\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=\sum_{\mathrm{h} \leq \mathrm{g}} \phi_{\Pi(\mathrm{h}), \mathrm{h}}(\vec{h}) \mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~h}, \mathrm{~g})
$$

In order to prove (b-i), we proceed by induction on the number $q$ of paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots, H_{q}$ considered. If $q=2$, as in the proof of Prop. 7.3 in Sec. C.1, the connected melonic graphs of two paired tensors are such that the two thick edges form a square with e.g. the edges of color 1 , while each one of the other colored edges links the same two vertices as one of the thick edges. From (C.9) and Prop. 7.3, letting $h_{\ell}^{\prime}=h_{\ell}-\phi\left(h_{\ell}\right) 1_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}$, we have for any such invariant $\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}, h_{2}\right)=\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}^{\prime}, h_{2}^{\prime}\right)=\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}^{\prime}, h_{2}^{\prime}\right)$, due to the fact that $\mathrm{M}((1)(2))=1$ and $\mathrm{M}((12))=-1$. Since by assumption $Q_{1} \neq Q_{2},(\mathrm{~g}, \vec{h})$ is alternating, so by (b-ii) one has $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(h_{1}^{\prime}, h_{2}^{\prime}\right)=0$.

We now assume that $q>2$, that (b-ii) holds, and that (b-i) holds for any $q^{\prime}<q$, and we prove that (b-i) holds for $q$ paired tensors. In order to apply (b-ii), we need to group the paired tensors $H_{1}, \ldots, H_{q}$ so that the invariant of paired tensors for the different groups is alternating. This is described at the end of Sec. 7.4: removing $E^{\text {tot }}=E^{\neq} \cup E^{\text {int }}$, where $E^{\neq}$is the set of edges linking paired tensors generated by different $Q_{\ell}$ and $E^{\text {int }}$ contains one edge per cycle of $\mathrm{g}_{i, E \neq}$ that alternates edges of color $c$ and paired inputs and outputs, we consider the paired tensors $P_{j}^{\neq}$corresponding to the connected components of $\mathrm{g}_{i, E^{\text {tot }}}$ and the colored graph $\mathrm{k}^{\neq}$whose colored edges are the edges of $E^{\text {tot }}$ and whose thick edges represent the paired tensors $\vec{P}^{\neq}$. The invariant encoded by $\mathrm{k}^{\neq}$is melonic for the paired tensors $\vec{P}^{\neq}$, and $\left(\mathrm{k}^{\neq}, \vec{F}^{\neq}\right)$ is alternating. Applying (C.9) to $\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}^{\neq}}\left(\vec{f}^{\neq}\right)=0$, centering the $\vec{f}^{\neq}$and repeating the argument of the first part of this proof (from (b-i) to (b-ii)) with the application of (b-ii) instead of (b-i), one finds that $\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}^{\neq}}\left(\vec{f}^{\neq}\right)=0$.

We can apply Prop. 7.4 with $h$ replaced by $h^{\neq}$(notation introduced in Sec. 7.4):

$$
0=\varkappa_{\mathrm{k}^{\neq}}\left(\vec{f}^{\neq}\right)=\sum_{\substack{\mathrm{h}^{\prime} \leq \mathrm{g} \\ \Pi\left(\mathrm{~h}^{\prime}\right) \vee \Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\neq}\right)=1_{q}}} \varkappa_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime}}(\vec{h})=\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})+\sum_{\substack{\mathrm{h}^{\prime}<\mathrm{g} \\ \Pi\left(\mathrm{~h}^{\prime}\right) \vee \Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\neq}\right)=1_{q}}} \varkappa_{\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right), \mathrm{h}^{\prime}}(\vec{h})
$$

where in the rightmost sum, $\leq$ has been replaced by $<$ to indicate that the case $h^{\prime}=g$ is excluded. As in the proof of Lemma C.1, since by assumption there exist $1 \leqslant \ell<\ell^{\prime} \leqslant q$ such that $Q_{\ell} \neq Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$, and since by definition of $h^{\neq}$, the connected components of $h^{\neq}$only involve $H_{\ell}, H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ generated by the same element $Q_{\ell}=Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$, the condition $\Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}\right) \vee \Pi\left(\mathrm{h}^{\neq}\right)=1_{q}$ imposes every $\mathrm{h}^{\prime}$ in the rightmost sum to have at least one connected component involving both a $H_{\ell}$ and a $H_{\ell^{\prime}}$ with $Q_{\ell} \neq Q_{\ell^{\prime}}$. Since $h^{\prime}<g$ we can apply the induction hypothesis to $h^{\prime}$, which is also a melonic invariant of paired tensors, thus concluding that the rightmost term is zero. We have therefore shown that $\varkappa_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=0$, which concludes the proof.
Remark C.6. In Lemma C.5, one may replace in (b-i) $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ by $\mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ and in (b-ii) $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{G}_{D, \mathcal{D}_{l}}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ and $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}\left(\vec{h}^{\prime}\right)=0$ by $H_{\ell} \in \mathcal{A}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell} ; \mathbb{1}_{D}\right]$ satisfying $\phi\left(h_{\ell}\right)=0$ and $\phi_{\mathrm{g}}(\vec{h})=0$. The proof is mutatis mutandis the same.

# C.2.2 Proof of Thm. 7.6 

Since the proof is very close to the mixed case, we only specify what differs. We start with the equivalence between the first and second point (analogous to Lemma C.1).

In the pure case, the fact that the second point implies the first point is trivial. We can assume that for all $i, \overline{x_{i}}=x_{i}^{\prime}$. In the second statement, one can just choose each $H_{\ell}$ to be $Q_{\ell}=X_{\ell} \otimes \bar{X}_{\ell}$ (and not a more general element of $\mathcal{G}_{D}^{\mathrm{m}}\left[Q_{\ell}\right]$ ). Then a melonic graph g of $\vec{H}$ is

a purely connected and melonic $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ with canonical pairing the identity and $1 \leqslant \ell \leqslant q$ identifies with $1 \leqslant i \leqslant n$. Since $Q_{\ell}=X_{\ell} \otimes \bar{X}_{\ell}$ with $\left(X_{\ell}, \bar{X}_{\ell}\right) \in\left\{\left(T_{a}, \bar{T}_{a}\right),\left(T_{b}, \bar{T}_{b}\right) \ldots\right\}$, one has $Q_{i} \neq Q_{j}$ for some $i \neq j$ if and only if $x_{i} \neq x_{j}$ (which is equivalent to $x_{i}^{\prime} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$ and $\bar{x}_{i} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$ due to the fact that $\left.\bar{x}_{i}=x_{j}^{\prime}\right)$.

Conversely, the fact that the first point implies the second point is proved exactly in the same manner as for the mixed case: since it is obvious if $\bar{x}_{i} \neq x_{j}^{\prime}$ for some $i$, one only needs to prove it under the assumptions that $\bar{x}_{i}=x_{i}^{\prime}$ for all $i$, and that there exists $i, j$ such that $x_{i} \neq x_{j}$. In the pure case, $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ first order is purely connected melonic and with canonical pairing the identity. One has to consider (7.35) instead of (C.5). It is still true that $\bar{x}_{i}=x_{i}^{\prime}$ for all $i$ both in $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ and $\boldsymbol{\rho}$, that $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ has no connected component involving some $x_{i} \neq x_{j}$, and that if $\boldsymbol{\rho}$ was to also satisfy the same property, then it would not be possible to satisfy $\Pi(\boldsymbol{\rho}) \vee \Pi(\boldsymbol{\tau})=1_{n}$, so all $\boldsymbol{\rho}$ in the sum (7.35) have a connected component involving $x_{i} \neq x_{j}$, and $\varkappa_{\mathbf{g}}(\widehat{h})=0$.

We pursue with the equivalence between the first statement of the second point and the first statement of the third point (analogous to Lemma C.3). Here nothing changes with the mixed case, due to the fact that if there exists $i$ such that $\bar{x}_{i} \neq x_{i}^{\prime}$, then it is also true for one connected component of every $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ such that $\boldsymbol{\tau} \leq \boldsymbol{\sigma}$ (here $\eta=\mathrm{id}$ ).

Remains the equivalence between the second statements of the second and third points of the theorem (analogous to Lemma C.5). For this part, the proof is as for the mixed case.

abstract:
We address the question of the asymptotic description of random tensors that
are local-unitary invariant, that is, invariant by conjugation by tensor
products of independent unitary matrices. We consider both the mixed case of a
tensor with $D$ inputs and $D$ outputs, and the case where there is a
factorization between the inputs and outputs, called pure, which includes the
random tensor models extensively studied in the physics literature.
  The finite size and asymptotic moments are defined using correlations of
certain invariant polynomials encoded by $D$-tuples of permutations, up to
relabeling equivalence. Finite size free cumulants associated to the
expectations of these invariants are defined through invertible finite size
moment-cumulants formulas.
  Two important cases are considered asymptotically: pure random tensors that
scale like a complex Gaussian, and mixed random tensors that scale like a
Wishart tensor. In both cases, we derive a notion of tensorial free cumulants
associated to first order invariants, through moment-cumulant formulas
involving summations over non-crossing permutations. The pure and mixed cases
involve the same combinatorics, but differ by the invariants that define the
distribution at first order. In both cases, the tensorial free-cumulants of a
sum of two independent tensors are shown to be additive. A preliminary
discussion of higher orders is provided.
  Tensor freeness is then defined as the vanishing of mixed first order
tensorial free cumulants. The equivalent formulation at the level of asymptotic
moments is derived in the pure and mixed cases, and we provide an algebraic
construction of tensorial probability spaces, which generalize non-commutative
probability spaces: random tensors converge in distribution to elements of
these spaces, and tensor freeness of random variables corresponds to tensor
freeness of the subspaces they generate.
